description:
What an awesome find during my trip to SF.  My friend had bookmarked them on Yelp and we thought it would be the perfect spot to hit up during a quick lunch break.  The space is very small and the line twirls around in a sort of organized chaotic manner.  We managed to squeeze about 12 people in line in this tiny space.  
The menu is not huge but almost everything on the menu sounded appetizing.  Although they have some yummy sounding bowls on their menu, I figured that for my first time eating somewhere like this, I just have to order Onigilly.  They offer vegetarian Onigilly, as well as chicken, beef and pork, but the star for me was the seafood options.  I ordered the spicy shrimp and the snow crab Onigilly, getting a filling lunch for only $6.  What a steal!
It was awesome watching the staff construct the food.  They are definitely a well-oiled machine as they had an perfectly timed assembly line in the kitchen.  The kitchen is open to the small entry space so you can watch everything being made.  I had my order in my hand within 3 minutes of ordering.  
I was super, duper happy with my experience here.  If I lived nearby, this would definitely be a weekly lunch.
author: Annie M.

description:
Always good efficient and fresh lunch : snack here.  Prices are reasonable at ~$3 per onigiri.

However, my last 2 visits were not as good as I remembered it... try spicy shrimp was too saucy (too much cream or mayo) and similarly, the crab one also has too much mayo... which over powered the rice and the seafood taste itself.

BUT, the rice is always and consistently good -- perfect texture, taste and that makes that onigiri comes out perfectly warm...  mmmmmm...
author: Winnie W.

description:
Just want a small meal or snack and don't want to spend too much?  Onigilly is a good option.

Their onigilly rice balls are really cute and delicious!  They're a great snack, though not the most filling.

Each onigilly rice ball runs around $2.76 to $3.75, so it could be a small, cheap lunch if you only order a couple.  There are also other set meals that you can order.  I believe I usually order the snow crab onigilly.  The onigilly tastes good, but nothing mind-blowing.

Service is usually friendly and pretty quick.  The food is prepared in an assembly line and you can see them make your order.

One thing that I would suggest for improvement is to label the different onigilly or point out which one is which.  Perhaps when it's busy, they don't have time to do that, but it would be nice to know which one I'm eating.  It would also be nice to have a sauce bottle to add more flavor!  They have chili and salt available at the side counter where you can serve yourself, but some Japanese mayo or something would be nice.
author: Stephanie Z.

description:
So excited that I finally got lunch from here! The staff were really welcoming, friendly, and helpful, (which isn't always the case in FiDi), so I appreciated that. I wasn't sure what to order, so the woman taking the orders recommended a few options. 

I decided on the Edamame Set with 3 Onigilly: Unagi , Real Crab, and Ume. Service was quick and I loved the presentation. The food seems simple--a sushi rice sandwich with one filling wrapped in seaweed, but it was SO yummy, flavorful, and balanced. I want to go back again! (...I did learn that I'm not a fan of ume as the pickling was too strong, but that's my palette and I just wanted to give it a try.)
author: Lori C.

description:
Great fast and casual lunch spot in the Montgomery district! 

An Onigilly is a triangle (not a ball) of rice wrapped in seaweed, and you can choose what fillings you want inside the center of this amazing combo of carbs and kelp. I got the combo with miso soup and two Onigilly's with imitation crab and eel. The eel one was super yummy. This combo was also very affordable, costing less than $12.

Not a big space, very little seating - would advise to just take them to-go and eat back in the office.
author: Kimberly K.

description:
I happened to be at Super Duper Burgers and looked up and, BAM, it was love at first sight. Right across the street was Onigilly. I am a huge fan of gourmet rice balls, so I raced over to give this place a try.

I must admit, I wasn't blown away by the menu. Nothing I haven't seen elsewhere, and definitely nothing innovative. These "onigiri" rice balls are shaped into a triangle. No, this does not qualify as "sushi." Everything is made with brown rice. I'm not a fan of brown rice elsewhere, but here it's quite sweet and good. Definitely a fan of how they prepare the onigiri. Each one is made to order, so expect to wait for your food. Lots of vegan and gluten-free options, too.

The ordering system here is not fun. The little shop gets so crowded that the few seats available can't even be used. You'll likely become incredibly cramped and uncomfortable. There's no real line for ordering and picking up, so patrons just curve toward the inside of the shop and it's a struggle to walk in or out.

I went with the Snow Crab for $3.45 -- simple, fresh, and with lemon aioli. Yes, this is real crab meat. For the price, it's a little high-end. In general, the rice balls will run you between $2.76 and $3.75, before taxes. However, I'd expect 2-3 to fill you up and that's not too bad for a nice lunch. I devoured my Snow Crab rice ball in seconds.

Here are some other options:
- Teriyaki Tofu
- Renkon (Spicy Lotus Root)
- Shiitake
- Spicy Bacon
- Spicy Miso Beef
- Unagi (Eel)
- Grilled Salmon
- Tempura Shrimp

Besides the rice rolls, they offer salads and soup. They also do small dishes like edamame and fried chicken karaage. There's even organic matcha lemonade.

Expect a 3.5% mandate surcharge "to help offset the additional regulatory costs of doing business in San Francisco." Yeah, yeah, yeah.
author: Kathy Z.

description:
Great little lunch spot located in the Financial District. The restaurant was small and there was little to no seating, so I immediately knew I would be taking my lunch to go. I was initially worried due to the fact that the line wrapped around inside the restaurant, but the assembly line was super fast and I was in and out the restaurant in under 10 minutes. 

The matcha lemonade was a unique and refreshing choice, and I had downed the whole thing by the time I got back to the office. I ordered the onigiri combo: three pieces (snow crab, salmon, & eel) and a side of edamame for a steal. The onigiri themselves were all delicious, but the snow crab stood out as my favorite. Next time I would be keen to order all three as snow crab!
author: Callie G.

description:
One star off because of the really short opening hours. 11-4pm on Monday to Friday, closed for the weekend... I've wanted to try this place for a long time but was never able to because I hustle hard everyday and by the time I get off work this place would be closed. Thankfully we moved our office near here recently, and I was able to finally try it because I left work early today due to being sick.

I was a little afraid that they would take onigiri and bastardize it, but I'm happy to report that the onigiri is very unpretentious, delicious, and a great value for money (at least by SF standards). 

I had the miso soup combo that comes with two onigiri, and the soup itself was pretty good, which is usually a good indicator for how the rest of the food will be. The soup wasn't too salty, but definitely give it some time to cool a bit so you can enjoy the flavours without burning your tongue.

I ordered the tuna salad onigiri and the tarako onigiri. Both were nicely seasoned, relatively filling without making you feel bloated, and easy to eat on the go. The important thing to keep in mind is that this food is definitely not meant to be compared to fine dining, and for what it is (quick, tasty, convenient), it pretty much checks all the boxes.

I would have loved if this place was open in the morning so I can grab an onigiri for breakfast, but sometimes dreams are meant to stay dreams.
author: Calvin Z.

description:
This one is for my fellow sushi aficionados who don't like wasting dimes on too much rice/cheap greens/subpar proteins. 

Ok, I gotta tell you, I'm loathe to write this less than rave review. I used to super like the ol' Onig and even had them at my office to rave reviews all around. So, yes, I super enjoyed them in the past, and I'm sure many folks still do, and will into the future. 

After my first few orders there, each one has left me dissatisfied he past couple years when I've tried again. I took a long time to consider it before I posted it and I do so very subjectively. Got yer grain of salt?

Onigilly a nice option to have around I guess. (Doesn't Bamboo Asia have similar bowls w more variety for same price/cheaper? Hmmm think so...next review). Perhaps they've gone down hill, perhaps I'm a sushi snob on a budget (duh). 

My opinion: Bland, Pricey, Meh service, hipster, long lines all around the lunch rush that take around 20+ min. Then everything you ultimately buy is mostly rice or salad w smallest portion of maybe 2-4 oz (?) depending on what size/s you pick. 

Feels like the now typical hipster gimmick to get me to pay $13 for 3-4 oz of low-med quality fish usually drowned in sauce bc thats how it tastes good. I promised myself I'd never go again after the last time. 

{Interlude, interlude my little pear...'}
I gotta keep reminding myself: this isn't Oori Triangles over near Berkeley (they're doing something amazing over there). Check out if you're ever there--on a quaint (tho a bit bougie street mostly full of mom n pop shops and the various sundry results of moms and pops doin their thing (watch out for the tiny people on scooters). Right off the Bart bicycle path under elevated BART tracks. Pretty. {'if you got that reference PLZ lmk you will blow my mind and make my day}

Here comes your REWARD for reading this far!! I hope its worth it...

I have DISCOVERED the super special awesome secret hack to succeeding in getting some of the quickest, best, cheapest sushi in SF if you find yourself at Onigilly NOT wanting to deal with it for whatever reason but still facing the need for sushi speed. I FEEL YOU...YO (yay! I found a non-gendered pronoun! Thanks NYC upbringing! I got my yo! :p)

Ok here's the deal:
Standing in front of Onigilly? Maybe waiting in slow moving line? Turn around. Look almost directly across the street kinda next to SuperDuper Burgers to its right from where yr standing is a place w smaller black signs you may not see til ya cross the street. Its a place called Tanmatsu. 

Tenmatsu is 3x as fast as Onigilly in&out even when the line looks long - the older lady cashier is always there during the rush and she moves like lightning but isn't impatient. She also remembers repeat customers and is sweet and kind. I thinks she's great, I really like her. 

Also its cheaper if you do the math, it has all diff offerings/prices (and cheap authentic udon/ramen/etc prepared as you like it before your eyes in a couple minutes). Basically you get more fish. And I think at least 50% better quality fish than Onigilly and most pickup sushi joints in the city. And this place is pick up ONLY- you can eat in any nearby park or in front of 555 California in their public area, or wherever. 

All locals in the know sell Tenmatsu out by 2/3PM each day. I see same employees each day and a super organized operation with fresh offerings being put out all morning, just made. They're all kept refrigerated or in a temp controlled heated unit. You can order a lot of things to be made immediately and its always so good. 

The make-now stuff can take up to 15 min if theyre busy. You can also call and order ahead or do so through Ritual app(calling to check order went through w app is wise). 

Tenmatsu is also locally/family owned and so AUTHENTIC! Cool philosophical and Japanese quotes cover 2 walls behind counter. You feel the soul of the place in the people, food, its good vibes. 

No charge for extras like spicy sauce/extra condiments. Cheap yummy $2/3 handrolls up front! Incredible- would never go anywhere else for quick sushi with this place nearby! So if Onigilly fails, you have your solution across the street here!
author: Viv R.

description:
There is something about that salt. 

Look man, I'm simple. Once I find something I like to eat I often crave it and seek it out. And that one thing is onigiri. Been on the hunt for some good onigiri grub eventhough I can technically make them myself, the simple one anyways. So when I moved to the area I was hype to see Onigilly and had it bookmarked. 

Recently realize Onigilly is a few steps away from my favorite boba place, so finally decided to seek it out. I tend to prefer seafood so I'll probably never get the chicken or the pork:

3. Salmon: very basic onigiri filling, though not as good as I've hoped. Sort of bland. I mean it's salmon but its not OOMPH salmon. Will pass next time. Or perhaps spicy salmon would have been a better choice: IF that was available, which it is not. Yet.

2. Snow crab: damn girl now you talking my language. Shhh so good. So addicting. Taste fresh, perfectly seasoned, beautiful with every bite. Always a go to.

1. SPICY SHRIMP: this. is. everything. As tasty as the snow crab, the spicy shrimp is a whole nother level of deliciousness. A must get if you're sane. Addicting, I love everything about this. Could eat it all day. 

Got the rice bowl with teriyaki chix, spicy bacon, and soboro for the leech but he said it was too spicy and didn't eat a whole lot. So like I said I'll probably not go for those flavor in onigiri form either. Skip skip skip

Although the leech did enjoy his zosui chix so maybe something I'll try myself next time. 

Onigiri aside: THE salt and pepper seasoning (???) on the side that you can get yourself is AMAZEBOMB. 
Like ok this is how pathetic I am: I buy my onis then get like 2 thing of the salt and the pepper seasoning and then I HOARD that shjt and eat it with my onigiri at home AND I got some extra so I'll be sprinkling it all over my own rice and my own seaweed and I am obsess with it. Someone tell me if they sell this or where I can get my own giant bottle because I need to put this on all my food. Thanks!

Service is quick. No hassle. Its only long wait when you're waiting behind indecisive customers. Them onigiri are make quickly though and for the seafood ones I've seen them really pilling it on. I don't see any skimping vs the way other reviews tell 'em. So I'm very happy with the proportion of filling to rice. Perfect. Love it.

Only sadness is the hour is not long enough. I guess they cater to the working hours. Q.Q But I get out so late and on my off days I wake up at 3pm how am I gonna make it there in time. T.T Also close on weekends? And holidays (them mondays holidays) as well? Why hast thou forsaken me, I want my onigiriiiii
author: Quynh Nhu D.

description:
This place has quick service. I was in and out in about 10 minutes (including the time I spent stuffing my pie hole).

The mushroom shiitake was a tad on the salty side but had great flavor.

The snow crab was good but had just a little too much mayo for my taste. It overpowered the flavor of the crab. They use real crab, so I feel like it's a waste to dump that much mayo in it.

This place didn't blow my mind, but maybe it's not supposed to.
author: Anita W.

description:
Interesting concept...rice balls with different types of fillings from beef to 
bacon to more exotic fillings like snow crab and lotus root. They were good.
author: Sunil R.

description:
OMESSHHHHIIIIIIIIIIIII~

Came here today for lunch for the first time! Walked in a little bit before the rush and was able to order pretty quickly. The menu looked pretty simple but with a lot of items I wasn't used to. 

Me and a friend ended up with 6 different onigilly (SOBORO, SPICY SHRIMP, SNOW CRAB, SPICY BACON, CHICKEN TERIYAKI, SALMON) and a TOFU ZOSUI. It came out really fast! Great for those who want a quick lunch! By far my favorite was the snow crab!!! It was super tasty and reminded me a little bit of a lion king roll with the mayo base they use (totally missing everything else though haha). Next up would have to be the spicy shrimp. I think it's hard to go outside of seafood for something that's basically a hand roll on steroids, but my 3rd option would have to be the soboro. Kind of like a rice stew thing. Loved it!!

Like I said earlier, OMESHIIIIIIIIIII~
author: Daniel O.

description:
I've always seen lines at this place so naturally I was curious. 

Finally stopped in and tried a couple of their rice triangles. 

Essentially to me it was like a musubi but in the shape of a...wait for it...a TRIANGLE. 

They run about $3 and I had the Teriyaki Chicken and the Soboro - pork . 

To me there was too much rice and not enough meat in the triangle. I know this is a tough proposition since you don't want the triangle to fall apart. Nevertheless, each bite i felt like I was eating predominately  white rice. 

Would I return....eh...probably not based on my experience. I love sushi, spam musubi etc but this place was just not my cup of tea.
author: Rod M.

description:
I feel like a damn onigilly after eating here, tummy full of rice. But hey, can't go wrong with affordable and decent lunches.

Pros:
+ Costs ~$3 to fill up on rice triangles and protein
+ Not too heavy of a lunch...
+ Yet filling...mm saucy rice
+ Compostable take-out containers, yay!

Cons:
- Small space, more of a grab and go spot

What I Got:
- Teriyaki Chicken, 3/5; kinda bland
- Salmon, 3/5; lacks flavor, tastes healthy though

Not exactly impressed since the triangles I ordered were a bit bland (and that's saying a lot for someone who isn't much of a sauce person), but the rice is freaking yummy! Onigilly came with edamame and ginger, not sure if it's because got the trio combo (I think so).

Will be back to try the spicy bacon, beef, and maybe another seafood onigilly.
author: Fanny W.

description:
For a quick small bite at affordable prices to fill the hunger fast; this is the place to go.  You will fill up quickly on that rice!  Otherwise, it was nothing exciting enough to get my pants wet.  I mean, sure, the little rice triangles wrapped in seaweed is cute, but there is so much more they can do,  I ordered a chicken and shrimp tempura.  The chicken almost tastes like Filipino adobo (plus one star) Shrimp tempura was straight up shrimp tempura.  No extras- garnishes, sauces or toppings. Had there been, I didn't notice. Perhaps one of those mayo sauces would be nice. 

Several yelpers have mentioned that they use a lot of rice; it's true.  However, this part doesn't bother me.  I like rice anyway, and  there is a lot of flavor in the mains already. Much of it is not needed.

Would I come back? Sure.  Probably.  Most likely if I'm not looking for anything in particular.  Or need a quick snack.
author: Leslie G.

description:
If you are curious what this place serves and what they are famous for, I can clear that up for you. 

Rice Triangles. 

Apparently there is some filling in the middle too, but basically you are getting a seaweed wrapped rice triangle. I wished for more. So much more. I ordered 3 different varieties to see what I liked. Eggplant, Eel and Shrimp tempura. All of them were disappointing. It's all the worst parts of sushi in triangle form. My coworker enjoys the salad, and that seemed to be more filling, so I might try that next time. But it's hard to even say that the salad would be a more filling option for lunch.
author: John W.

description: So good!!!! The staff was very nice and the guy up front was super cute and friendly. We tried the pickled plum, sautéed mustard greens, eel and barbecue, sautéed eggplant, and the salmon onigillies. They were all excellent. My favorites would be the pickled plum and the eel and barbecue. Everything pairs well with the side of tamagoyaki. The matcha lemonade is on the sweet side and also excellent. I'm going to miss this place when I go back to the central coast!
author: Graesyn H.

description: This is a cool idea and we got three of them, which is enough to fill an adult. Super fresh and served in a clean but small store. We got em to go, which was good since it was pretty packed in there with the small seating area. I'd love to go back if we lived here.
author: Ben T.

description: Amazing service and a delicious, savory snack or meal if you're in a sushi mood! Onigiri is more popular than sushi in Japan, and for good reason. The cashier recommended the Shitake, Salmon, and Unagi. The Unagi melts in your mouth - highly recommend!
author: Sarah R.

description:
I'm a big fan of onigiri and there is pretty much nowhere to get it where I live (Phoenix) so just the concept of a place like this scores points in my book. 

I just wanted a snack to tie me over before dinner so I ordered two onigiri - a teriyaki chicken and an unagi. I always use soy sauce so I was surprised that I had to ask for it but they did have some, luckily. 

I started with the teriyaki. It was okay but it could have used more sauce. I thought it was a little dry. The unagi was much better - a good amount of sauce and the flavor was great. Definitely the winner between the two.

This is more of a grab and go place but there are a few small tables. Considering I can only wish I had a place like this in my town I really can't say anything bad! But besides that it's worth checking out if you want a snack or a light meal.
author: Holly R.

description:
I spotted this lunch spot within the food shops at The Embarcadero where many small restaurants are found. I was dying to try this place out as I love trying out new types of Japanese food.
When I saw the menu, there were a lot of varieties for all the food lifestyle choices - vegetarians, vegans. Bowls, rice bowls, edamame set, a lot of onigiri types.
I chose 2 today for lunch: Soboro (A soy sauce braised shredded angus steak), and a Spicy Miso Ahi Tuna. So they were reasonably priced like around $2.50 to $3. These were packed uniquely because they have they own molds which is the triangle in shape instead of the round ones. The fillings are sandwich in 2 triangle-shaped sushi rice and wrapped with nori tightly. These morsels are so good, and just perfect for my tummy and satisfying. I enjoyed the Soboro which is great, delicious and notes of umami-ness because of the soy sauce marinade. The Spicy Miso was spicy in a level of 3/10 but salty.
This lunch spot is so worth going and eating. If you want to try a trendy and delicious food spot. This one is a great food gem.
author: Jade M.

description:
I got the miso soup set with Miso Nasu and Shiitake. The Miso Nasu stands out and is the most flavorful! The soup is lackluster on it's own, but it's bland enough to balance the slightly salty onigiri. 

Get the daikon pickles on the side for depth, and don't forget to add that spicy power at the condiments station!
author: Victoria L.

description:
Good place to fill that carb craving, while still eating relatively healthy.  I enjoy the shiitake, snow crab, eel.

Zosui was also good for the winter months, kind of a heartier liquid risotto like texture.

The salad bowl not filling enough, and not enough salad, would just stick with the rice balls.
author: Jonathan C.

description: This is my go-to spot on my way to work when I haven't had breakfast. The staff is friendly and patient. I always get the spicy chicken and shrimp tempura. Space is limited but don't let the line intimidate you; the wait time is usually short.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I arrived around 11:30am and ordered the salmon, miso tuna salad, and tarako onigiris along with a side of miso soup. The total came out to be $16. This location is a bit cramped as a ton of people started to pile in around 11:40am, but we managed to get one of the 2 small tables. 

The rice isn't made out of sushi rice but brown rice, which was surprisingly delicious. I loved the miso tuna salad onigiri but was a bit disappointed with the salmon. I'll probably pass on the miso soup as well. This was more a 4.5 for me, but I'm definitely going to be back to try more flavors!
author: Dee Dee T.

description:
Always a wait at this location because it gets poppin' during lunch! They have a lot more selections at this location hence why there is a longer wait.

They used to be open for dinner for HH but no more. I enjoyed their hot appetizers more than their rice balls. 

Rice balls are more like rice sandwiches with the filling in the middle. Good portions.
author: Kay H.

description:
I like Onigilly! My favorite are the natto and salmon onigilly, either in the edamame or miso soup set. The ume (pickled plum) is super sour so it isn't recommended unless you'll know that you'll like it.

The only downside is that it will likely not fill you up (esp. compared to the surrounding restaurants that give larger portions) and it sort of feels like you're only eating rice (which is kind of true).
author: Vicki L.

description: Not too bad! Some of them are salty but that's personal preference. Great for a quick lunch.
author: May M.

description: Pretty good. Good place to come if you want something you can eat as you go, but three onigiris don't fill me up :(. Nice selection. Would love this place and come back more often if the serving sizes were bigger. This place gets poppin during peak lunch hours (many companies around the area), so be prepared to wait for ~15mins (to order and to get your food).
author: Annie S.

description: Very good food. Crab meat and unagi are my favorite! You should try them! I recommended them to my classmates!
author: Henry L.

description:
Simple, clean, healthy, delicious to-go spot for Japanese onigiri (triangular rice ball snack with filling wrapped in seaweed), caters to the weekday lunch crowd. I think Onigilly might turn out to be one of those places I CRAVE. Well, actually, I already know it is because I went on Friday, and was already wishing they were open on Saturday, the next day, so I could go back (they're open only Mon-Fri). 

I couldn't decide between getting a salad bowl or a rice bowl, and discovered with the help of the nice cashier that they can do half salad half rice! I did the half-and-half, which comes with edamame and pickles and dressing, and for the 3 toppings, I chose Shiitake (delicious, perhaps my fav), Snow Crab (also delicious, fresh, and their most popular topping), and Tempura Shrimp (good, but gets soggy when you get it to-go. Might opt for the Spicy Shrimp or Spicy Bacon next time). 

I also ordered a teriyaki chicken onigiri to save for later, but curiosity and fatassery got the best of me. I popped that onigiri to-go box open for "just a bite" but ended up inhaling the whole thing despite being full already from the salad/rice bowl.

Can't wait to return to try some of their other offerings!! So. excite. !
author: Ashley S.

description: We were running back from the exploratorium to our hotel and needed a snack for the kiddos. The soboro Onigiri did the job!  It was not a massive rice ball with a little filling. It was a delicious marinated ground chicken filling with a little rice and crisp fresh seaweed. Perfection!
author: Wonder W.

description:
I love Onigilly! There are so many options to choose from, something for everyone. Their combos are great if you want a little soup or edamame with your meal.

It can get a little crazy at lunch time, but if you come a little before or after the rush, you'll be fine. I normally get the Tarako (little fish eggies) and the braised ground beef and it's super filling + satisfying for under $10.

All in all, such a sweet spot for an awesome quick lunch in the area.
author: Angie S.

description:
Onigilly is one of those brainless lunch spots. When I can't decide where to eat, there's a good chance I will end up here. Even when the line is out the door, it moves quickly because people are in and out in minutes. They are known for their seaweed wrapped "rice balls" which which can be purchased individually or in a set. I usually order the edamame set, which comes with 3 rice balls and a side of cold edamame.

My favorites include:
Tempura Shrimp (only available at Kearny location!)
Unagi
Snow Crab
Spicy Bacon 

This is an easy lunch and I like picking this up when I just want to grab something quick. I have tried the rice bowl, which comes with 3 toppings over a bed of rice but it just wasn't the same. I enjoy the rice balls significantly more, must be the seaweed! Worth trying if you are in the area!
author: Mandi H.

description:
What I ordered: 
- 2 Ume onigiri ($2.76):
  - Rating: 3/5 - I love Ume (sour plum) and maybe it's because my expectation was too high, it didn't really meet my expectations. The rice was a bit hard and it was a bit too sour than normal so I had to take out a few sour plums. 
- 1 Unagi onigiri ($3.22): 
  - Rating: 5/5 - This was my favorite onigiri! I didn't expect this to be this delicious but the Unagi tasted really good and fresh! I would definitely come back again for this onigiri :) 

Pros:
- Onigiri is quite filling (not that small) 
- The price was moderate 

Cons: 
- The rice was a bit hard for me
author: GrapeOolong W.

description: A good place for a snack so don't go hungry and they will always be out of the chicken. There will be more rice then filling. Easy on the go food and something to try so not a repeat spot to grab food at.
author: Sandy S.

description:
Onigilly is a great place to go to for a quick healthy bite. There's something on the menu for everyone. A few that I have tried are: Snow Crab, Spicy Shrimp, Salmon, and Spicy Bacon. Of all that I have tried, the spicy bay shrimp is the best- especially if you enjoy spicy food! It has the perfect amount of spice, but it isn't too overpowering where it becomes too spicy to enjoy. 

I'm very fortunate this location isn't too far from my work because I plan on coming back to try the rice bowls, salad bowls and even the miso soup combination which comes with 2 onigilly. 

Service has always been great as usual. Keep up the great work!
author: Ingrid E.

description:
This is awesome!!!
Takana, Renkon, Miso Nasu, Soboro, and Unagi are my favorites :)
Unagi is really good!
author: Kazuki N.

description:
This place has a lot of hype for some reason, or there's always a line when I walk back so I decided to actually stop in for once. I came as soon as the place opened so only one of two people already there. I can't really speak on the true wait because of that. The service was fast and friendly and it was actually pretty interesting watching the servers make the food. 

I ordered the soboro (pork), miso tuna, snow crab, and salmon rice triangles (yes I like trying a lot of new things). It was quite filling and in order of the ones I would recommend:

1. Miso tuna: very good balance of flavors (less filling than the others tho) and relatively light
2. Salmon: a little dry but the sauce and the seasoning they put on helped
3. Soboro: was a little too strong in flavors for me 
4. Snow crab: in my opinion not as worth the price but still good

Overall, this place seems like a fast and relatively cheap and healthy place to stop by for lunch. Will visit when I can again, but I wasn't interested in any other flavors than the ones I listed above so I'm not completely sure. Would definitely recommend at least one try!
author: Michelle L.

description:
I wanted to try out this place for lunch as it was kind of like sushi (which I love) but is different. I got the Wakame Set which came with 2 on onigilly and a side of seaweed salad. I got the miso tuna which was pretty good. Not as much miso flavor as I had hoped. I also got the spicy bacon which was actually pretty spicy and packed with flavor. The seaweed salad was really good as well and I'm glad I got that set.

Overall, it's pretty much filling of your choice inside a rice ball (or triangle), but it's pretty good. I think I still prefer sushi as this is mostly rice.
author: Sophia Y.

description: This is by far one of my favorite places for lunch to grab something to go and eat lunch at some steps or at a park. They offer Rice Triangles reminiscent of those rice balls in anime shows. You can buy a bundle of 3 which is filling or you can order 1 rice ball. I always order the seafood onigilly. What I really like about this place is that they are quick depending on the time you go and another reason is that it is filling and I don't feel heavy after eating one. Honestly there are so many food selections around this area, it all depends what you are craving for. Overall I like it and would come back again if I am feeling something light.
author: Alliver V.

description: Really really really good. All the little elements you can choose are all super delicious and coherent in taste. The pickled ingredients (e.g. radish) is sooo good. I may get a bowl just for that . My favorite is the salmon because it's super clean and flavorful, also it's the least 'sauced up' option.
author: Alina Y.

description:
This is not what an onigiri is supposed to be, but I think I like it anyway?

Onigilly is right next to my office, so I've had them on more than one occasion.  The fillings are actually not bad, and they give you a pretty generous scoop in each.  The whole construction of the onigiri seems a little wrong to me, because I'm used to triangles of rice lovingly shaped by a mother's hand.  But I also enjoy having filling in every bite, so I'll sneak these up to my office and eat them at my desk away from the eyes of the Japanese food gods.

My favorite fillings are the tarako and miso tuna salad, the addition of mayo makes everything better!  It gets a bit pricey ($2-3 per onigiri), but we are in Fi-Di and they do boast about the quality of their ingredients (canned tuna is canned tuna IMO).

Tips and Tricks:

-They have a stamp card so you get your 11th meal free.  Stamps are only given if you purchase a meal though
-Zosui is not really zosui as much as it's chazuke (just rice in broth with your choice of meat)
author: Jessica L.

description: While in Downtown San Francisco, we like to try food variation some fancy and other times hole in a wall casual dining.  My husband and I were in a bit of rush to get to our meeting down the street so we decided to give this place a try.  We sampled the spicy shrimp and snow crab rice triangle, and their set bowl with their special soup and unagi rice triangle.  We are pleasantly surprised, everything was so good our lunch was satisfying and reasonable.  I wasn't able to take photos of our lunch as mentioned our schedule was so hectic.  But this place is a must try.
author: May A.

description: Please train your staff!!!!!! Multiple times I have ordered a salad with tempura shrimp and they only give me one shrimp and no dressing. By the time I notice I'm already back in my office and don't want to take the trip back to the store. You're paying $14 for a salad, at least have all the ingredients! I like coming here all the time, but I have to tell the staff that they messed up and watch the order every time.
author: Elena O.

description:
I've been here a few times and pretty much keep it simple by ordering either a couple onigiri's or the Edamame Set, which comes with 3 onigiri's, Edamame and Daikon.  I grew-up eating onigiri's that my mom used to make for us.  They are a good snack or quick lunch option.  

Onigilly offers a different twist, by using partially milled brown rice, versus the standard white rice my mom used to make.  We had them with or without nori (seaweed) growing-up, but using nori makes them easier to handle.  

Their menu has a wide selection of flavors, so there's something for pretty much everyone, including those that are gluten-free or vegan.  I stick to the meat options and prefer the Unagi, Spicy Shrimp, Snow Crab, Teriyaki Chicken and Salmon.  

It's not a large restaurant with very limited seating.  However, don't be surprised to see the line snaked-out the door during lunch.  Needless to say, I typically go after the lunch crowd to avoid the lines.  Make sure to review the large menu board to see the entire menu, including their sets.  The price is right as the Edamame Set is $10 for 3 onigiri's.  I have yet to try their Salad or Rice Bowls, but that will be for a future visit.
author: Lon H.

description:
Only tried unagi and snow crab. Snow crab was soo good! Unagi was good too but at the same time, it's not that special since you can order unagi at most places that sell rice balls. I will definitely come back to try the other flavors. 

Also, my bf ordered their side of chicken karage and boy was it really a side. They only gave 4 pieces but he said it was good so if you want that, go for it! Just be aware you'll be only paying for 4 pieces of chicken.
author: Joanne K.

description: Recently ordered a Rice Bowl.  I still think it's weird having onigiri fillings on the side but it's nice knowing theres a place I can get healthy japanese food for lunch.
author: Adrian C.

description:
Pretty upset from my visit today... 

There was a new worker who was being trained. I came right before the lunch rush so I didn't mind that she was making my rice ball extra slow. 

I do mind that there was barely any meat in my onigiri. I frequent this establishment quite often when I'm not feeling our lunch at work. I'm pretty disappointed that my unagi rice ball is mostly rice and sauce. Ugh. 

I tend to get the wakame set. Two onigiris and a seaweed salad. It's just enough food for the average person. I actually get full off one plus the seaweed salad. 

If my experience wasn't so poor today, I probably would give this place 4 stars.. Oh well.
author: Dianna C.

description:
Gourmet musubi onigiri (rice balls) filled with sushi a tasty assortment of flavors:  teriyaki chicken, unagi, tarako (spicy fish eggs), snow crab, baked salmon, or seaweed.  They place your choice of filling between two triangles of white rice, then wrap it in a sheet of pressed seaweed.  
This restaurant offers several ways to market their  onigiri:
Edamame set:  2 choices of onigiri with takuan and edamame.
Zosui set:  1 onigiri and a cup of broth, rice and protein.
Bowl:  three topping over rice, takuan, and edamame
author: Richard H.

description: Wasn't impressed. These are triangle shaped sushi rice filled with ingredients. There is some seaweed in there too to hold it all in. It seems like a quick and healthy place to grab a snack while walking around the City. It is pretty quick too. The shrimp one was ok but they also have some unfamiliar ones. We had a meat one that wasn't that great. Bottom line is our meal was less than memorable.
author: Valerie M.

description: Quick and easy meal on the go - picked up the shrimp tempura and the spicy shrimp onigilly and it comes with pickles and edamame.  I love onigiri and this is a definite stop the next time I'm in the area.
author: Susan C.

description:
Ridiculously satisfying lunch place! 

Often times, there's a line out the door because it's such a small shop. But trust me, it moves so fast. You can get your lunch within 15 minutes. You can also see them making your food right in front. I love it when you can see the kitchen and fresh ingredients -- it just shows how confident they are in what they serve.

I've tried the rice bowl and onigilly(rice balls). Both exceptional. Take your pick based on your preference. Definitely try out the set meals if you're ordering more than 1 onigilly. 

My favorite:
* Rice bowl with 3 onigilly fillings on a bed of rice w/ organic mixed greens, edamame, and pickles. ($10- $12 range depending on your choice of filling). The presentation was perfect, hot (rice + fillings) on one side and cold (salad) on the other. I was satisfyingly full, which is great because I didn't feel bloated after the meal!

The following fillings are great:
+ snow crab
+ unagi
+ chicken teriyaki
+ shiitake

I'm looking forward to trying the chicken karaage ($3.68) next time. It's unfortunate that it's only a side and can't be a filling :(
author: Jenny H.

description: Its ok. The problem with these little onigilly is that you have to eat them on the spot otherwise the seaweed gets wet and soggy. I would prefer it if the seaweed was separately wrapped. Which is how I usually get it at Berkeley Bowl.
author: Jen S.

description:
Onigilly
On the really
Rice ball circus
Piccadilly

Rice so fluffy
Seaweed cuddle
Three in one box
Rice ball huddle

Salmon all cooked
No wasabi
Soy based protein
Edamame

Hipster diet
Veggie worries
Menu party
Pumpkin Curry

Give me one more
Spicy Bacon
Diet fitness
Got forsaken

This not sushi
This not bougie
10 young moneys
That Lil TuneChi
author: Ringo M.

description:
After seeing snaking lines all around the financial district for these sushi sandwiches, I finally took a dive and showed-up early to try one of these things without waiting for them.  In order to get the full experience I tried one of each from the veggie menu which included exotic varieties such as a soy braised shiitake mushroom sandwich, eggplant in red miso with sesame and green onion sandwich and a baked organic tofu with teriyaki sauce sandwich TO NAME A FEW.  
First off - you guys rock for providing so many wonderfully delectable vegan and gluten free options!
They were amazing and at only $2.76 a sandwich - A FANTASTIC VALUE.  You only need 2, maybe 3 of these sushi sandwiches to be satisfied.  I have nothing but good things to say about this place.
author: Khash C.

description:
I come here once in a while to spice up my lunch routine :) I have never had onigilly in other places, but this has totally gotten me hooked. I'm now in a hunt for more places that offer this. After all, onigilly doesn't open till very late :'(

I love their new Zosui set (Japanese rice soup w/ one onigilly), though sometimes I'm very tempted to get more onigilly... My favorite onigilly selections are Unagi and Snow Crab. There are times when I get the Edamame set (three onigillys) with just Unage for all three. It's absolutely delicious. 

They don't have much space to dine in, so I usually do take out and eat in the park nearby on Pine street. When the sun is out, this is particularly enjoyable to do. Since the place is small, you most likely need to wait in line for 15 minutes or so. Try to avoid the 12pm lunch rush if you can.
author: Angel C.

description:
I came here after finding out that Sushirrito across the street was closed for the day, so I somehow managed to scurry myself through the door after looking a their menu outside.  They have a simple concept featuring japanese rice balls with various filling inside.  The service here was good, and they answered all my questions in regards to which rice ball would be the best based on my personal preferences.

After looking through their menu, I decided to order various rice balls such as the Salmon, Shitake, Miso Nasu, along with an order of the Edamame Set meal.  For the most part, my favorite was the Salmon, it tasted decent, but the other rice balls were lacking in flavor and did not taste that good.  For the price I paid for each ball, I could have went across the street to Sushirrito and had myself some fine dining.   To make matters worst, the Edamame Set wasn't worth it, the edamame did not taste fresh and was lacking in salt.  The dressing had a very weird carrot taste to it and did not taste well when poured over the set.  Overall, the mixture of flavors in the edamame set bowl just didn't mesh well together.

If I was to come back here again, I would probably stick to the Salmon rice ball and that's it.
author: David L.

description: Good to see this location get customers, used to never have a line. With more customers the ratio of fish to rice in the bowls has come down dramatically. A dollop of fish with mounds of rice.
author: E L.

description:
Its a fun size snack.

In my review, I think my opinion may be affected by the fact that I started eating it like an hour after purchase. I basically had a feast that included sushirito as the main course. Okay so my friend and I came here for lunch on Friday, and of course this whole financial district is just super crowded during rush. Line goes out the door but the orders move by fast.

I ordered the edamame set which included 3 onigiris (spicy kogi, snow crab, & salmon) w/ edamame/pickled daikon.

So I've had onigilly once before in the embarcadero area, and I would say my first time was better. The ones here don't seem to have as much filling or of a strong taste to them. Maybe it's because they have a bigger demand of customers? Who knows? Again if I had eaten them right away, it probably would have been better. I liked them all, each having a unique taste. The seaweed wrap doesn't fall apart, and the rice holds together well. Quality overall was only decent.

My favorite of the 3 in order are: 1) salmon 2) snow crab & 3) spicy kogi.

I might stop by again if I'm in the area.
author: Kevin S.

description:
This is definitely me and my coworker's go-to lunch spot!

Not a suitable place to dine in-- its more of a grab and go lunch spot as the lines get super crowded and the tables are tiny. The cashier is always so friendly and is a great conversationalist --always a fun time talking to him. 

My usuals-- the salmon zosui (a winter offering, but so delicious), the takana (sesame mustard greens), miso tuna, and sometimes when I get a salty craving the tarako (pollock roe). 

I've tried the karage (runs our quite quickly), snow crab, and spicy shrimp-- the snow crab is a favorite among most people but is usually too saucy and mayo-y for my taste. 

Overall, food is delicious and filling a great lunch option but can get quite long during prime lunch hours. 

P.S.
I really wish they still had stamp cards-- though it doesn't really stop me from coming back for more!
author: Maggie Y.

description:
Oh Onigilly, you do the onigiris right. Thank you!

What can I say? The okra is delish... The snow crab is amazing!!! And an awesome deal for a set of 3 + edamame, I must say ;9

It's a very popular spot in FiDi so be prepared to wait, but trust me, it's worth it. Every. Damn. Bite!
author: Olivia S.

description:
This place is literally RIGHT next to plentea. They close at 4 and I went in at 3:50 and they were nice enough to let us eat there past 4. Sorry :P I work in food service so I know how you guys felt but we wouldn't have had anywhere else to eat!! 

First, you choose a set meal (3 onigilly edamame set, wakame bowl, miso soup set or rice/salad bowl). 

I got the rice bowl which comes with half rice and half salad. I got to choose 3 onigilly fillings. I chose the Hijiki (braised seaweed & carrots), teriyaki chicken & salmon. It comes with a side dressing for the salad & some edamame as well. So worth it because you get a little bit of each. It's the size of a chipotle bowl, so it's pretty filling! This is something I've never tried because there's nothing really like this in LA so I'm glad I got to try this place. I want to come back and try the onigilly next time!!
author: Winnie L.

description:
The perfect snack!

I'm more of a savory person than sweets so this place is perfect for when I crave a small snack in between meals. 

They have cute rice sammies where you can choose what filling you want wrapped in seaweed. They also have combinations where you can pair with miso soup or edamame and even make a rice bowl. I think their seafood choices are the best especially the spicy shrimp!

They're priced at about $3-$4 dollars and do fill you up. The line moves quickly and the wait is never too long. I would recommend going at off hours to avoid the lunch crowd :)
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Pros:
- Onigilly are well constructed with an assortment of flavors to appease any palate.
- Snow Crab onigilly is made with real snow crab (delicious!) 
- Haven't tried an onigilly that I haven't liked
- Seasoning salt on the counter is a delicious addition to the white rice used in onigilly

Cons: 
- A bit pricey in relation to portion size and ingredients. Profit margins must be huge!
- Location is a bit small and crowded for the lunch hour rush
- Not located closer to my home (Ha!)
author: David D.

description:
I'm not thoroughly impressed with them yet as I feel I end up throwing away more than I eat. 

The toppings and flavors aren't that great, and it's just kinda mushy inside the rice patties... 

But I've figured it out- just combine the sides and make that your meal instead!
author: Mandi W.

description: It was alright. The teriyaki rice "ball" (more like a sandwich) was the only decent thing about my meal. The "salad" was awful. It was slimy, not fresh, and was tiny.
author: Mia C.

description: Got the wakame set with spicy shrimp and unagi onigiri! Definitely recommend, especially the unagi. So yummy and perfect for a quick lunch during the work day. The line was out the door around 12:15pm. I think I waited about 5-10 minutes in line, then only, like, 30 seconds to actually get my food (they're fast)!
author: Alexandra L.

description: Love love love the onigiri here! There's a great variety of vegetarian and non-vegetarian options, but my hands down favorite is the miso nasu aka eggplant. It's just so perfectly salty and savory. I like getting the onigiri set with 3 different types of onigiri and edamame. Definitely going back to try to zosui set~
author: Lakshmi M.

description:
Quality of the rice used here is not just that great. I can tell they are using a cheap kind. Sadly toppings are not exactly tasty, they are overly sweet, everything tasted like straight teriyaki sauce. 

Miso soup with two tiny tiny cubes of tofu is classic! 
Please don't cut tofu short in the miso soup. Just sad... 
With the price they are charging, they should really consider major upgrading on their rice( can't emphasize this enough!) 

Casual and popular but it doesn't work for me..
author: K O.

description: Great lunch spot. I came here missing the awesome food options that Japanese convenient stores (i.e., Lawson's) offers. I tried 3 options - tuna, salmon and BBQ. Tuna was my favorite. BBQ was disappointing, too salty for me. I would return here again. $10 is a good deal for a satisfying lunch.
author: Katy H.

description: Onigilly has a fun take out Japanese fast food vibe to it. I went on a Tuesday lunch time to pick up some food before Ben and Jerry's Free ice cream cone day and found that there will always be a line at lunch so expect that. I ordered the sadoko, the scallop, and the miso tuna, but wasn't particularly impressed by any flavours in particular. It was satisfying to have a warm freshly made onigiri, but I found the overall dish to be lacking in complexity. Each rice ball only had one filling in it and did not have much extra oomph in terms of texture.
author: Ian L.

description: We tried the ground beef, spicy shrimp, salmon, crab, and eel. All the meets were delicious, the staff was very friendly and helpful too. I loved the concept and the flavors were just delicious. My favorites were the eel and the spicy shrimp, they were succulent and flavorful. The matcha green tea lemonade was pretty good.
author: Mery R.

description:
The short: yummy onigiri

Onigilly is a fun play on the Japanese word onigiri, which is this tasty rice ball (usually in the shape of a triangle) with some sort of savory filling inside. This place is so cute and I actually heard one of the onigiri preparers speak Japanese with a guest, so that's a huge bonus when the authenticity factor is there! The cashier also takes the credit card and returns it with two hands, Japanese style (over the typical American hand-over with one hand). 

Order from the cashier (there's a menu outside the door and also above the cashier) and somebody will yell out the order number. There's 5 tables for 2, and my friend and I scored a table just as we finished ordering. Score!

I ordered the: soboro (ginger beef) and tarako (pollack roe fish that's really salty). Two onigiri turned out to be filling and with an addition of the wakame salad combo, I felt very satisfied :)
author: Catherine W.

description: This place is great for a quick and simple meal, I got the edamame set which includes 3 onigiris of your choice, so zip got the salmon, unagi, and chicken. It was all very good and filling. Definitely shareable with a friend.
author: Garrett P.

description:
I want to take this restaurant home and put it in my neighborhood.
All around great place.   The food is wonderful, the staff is kind and helpful, it's quaint, quiet, good people watching spot, relatively inexpensive, eco friendly....
We both ordered a edamame set.  Its plenty of food.  Fresh and wonderful ingredients.
I want to eat lunch there everyday. :)
author: Barb N.

description: I really think it's just okay. Nothing super special. Rice wrapped in protein/veggies. Wish they put more filling inside between the rice. A little on the pricey side but its the FIDI, everything is more expensive. They have good lunch combos. Many options to choose from. Fast service.
author: Sandy B.

description:
Just so so... I guess Onigiri is the new trend, it tags along with the spam musubi trend

Originally, the rice come a couple different ways, with salt, sour plum, salmon, or maybe pickled green leafy vegetables

These guys went with the more is better attitude... I kinda to keep it simple myself, but it would be hard to build a whole restaurant around the 4 rice balls.

Here the biggest competition. Is sushirito....
author: Kev M.

description: Spicy shrimp and snow crab are my favorite, fast service and great food
author: Nan L.

description:
Onigilly is one of my favorite lunch spots. I love pairing their soboro pork with miso soup. I usually go there at 11:30am to avoid long lines. 

There's not a lot of tables and the space is pretty small (esp when lots of people are waiting in line) so it's not an ideal place to sit down and have lunch. But perfect to pick something up and head back to the office.
author: Julia C.

description:
Onigilly is super good! My friends and I were walking around and exploring SF, looking for a place to eat lunch when we walked by Onigilly. The pictures of the rice balls looked so good so we decided to give it a try and we all loved it! The prices are pretty decent, my friends and I spent around $8.00 - $12.00 each, depending on how many rice balls & what combo. 

For those of you who haven't tried it, the rice balls aren't really anything like sushi. Our rice balls were served warm and the meat inside is all cooked. I ordered 3 of them, teriyaki chicken, bacon, and salmon. My favorites were the chicken and salmon. Two definitely would have been enough to fill me up, so if I ever am in SF and decide to stop by, I'll definitely be getting only two.

They don't have much seating inside, but then again, it's fast food and they serve it in to-go boxes. Also, there were some bugs flying around inside, which was a little irritating, but our food came out quickly and we ate our food elsewhere, so it wasn't much of a problem.

If you're in SF and looking for a quick, easy, unique lunch, give it a try!!
author: Ashley A.

description: A wonderful place to go to lunch. I got the edamame which comes with 3 onigiri and a miso soup on the side. It was enough to fill me up until dinner time. You really can't go wrong with any of the choices, but I just went for one veggie, one meat, and one seafood.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Rice Balls.... or rather.. Rice Sandwiches.

They mold and make 2 thick slices of rice.
Put protein in between and warp it up with seaweed.

3 pieces combo came up to be around $15.  

Novelty food.  Flavors are so - so.  Price point is so-so.
author: Luke T.

description:
I love the name, Onigilly. So, this spot if a good spot to hit up for a quick grab and go snack or lunch. FYI: They are closed on weekends and closed at 4pm weekdays. 

My first meal when I got situated in my hotel room. I knew I wanted something quick, yet filling. I sure came to the right place. I got a meal set in which I chose 3 onigilly fillings over salad. Likewise, got 3 more rice balls. I got traditional onigiri fillings and some not so traditional. Also, an order of Karaage. Walking SF can work up an appetite! 

I was pleased with the food. Nothing particularly memorable, though. 
Food: 3.5 stars.
Service: 3 stars.
Interior: 3 stars. 

I would come back to grab a quick rice ball or two.
author: Danica D.

description: Onigilly is a lunch time staple for me. I love the healthy options for fillings. My favorites are shiitake, salmon and miso tuna. The Kearny Street location has expanded their menu beyond onigiri and salads to "jook" and soba noodle soup. It's pretty expensive but well worth it especially since food options in fidi aren't amazing.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
My go to downtown lunch spot since I started attending the data science bootcamp at general assembly. Great for when I want something light, fresh and tasty that will keep me full and happy without the afternoon slumps. 

I usually get 3 rice balls with salmon, shrimp and the lotus root and at $9.50, it's good value. The taste is pretty good although personally I think they could add some spices or sauces to make it more flavorful - ask the cashier for soy sauce and mix that sh%$ in!! Boosts the flavor way up and I'm not even usually a fan of soy sauce. 

Peace!!!
author: nathan z.

description:
Great lunch spot during the workweek. Line is usually about 10-15 mins around noon. A great alternative to having Sushiritto again.

Three of these rice triangles are all you need for a filling lunch. Each one is made of filling sandwiched between two triangles of rice and wrapped in seaweed. Prices range from $2.50-3.50 each. 

++ Eggplant- marinated in garlic ginger, definitely my favorite with soft and room temp eggplant
+   Soboro- ginger honey beef, a little on the sweet side, but very flavorful
+   Spicy bacon

Only thing I would want is some more texture in the filling. Everything is pretty soft and texturally similar where you can sometimes confuse what fillings you're eating.

Not much seating- maybe 6 tables. If you're coming with a group, it's probably better to get it to-go.

No more reward card. :(
author: Alice T.

description: Very simple, delicious lunch option. Each onigiri is a good sized triangular piece of rice with seaweed and your choice of filling from meat to veggies to seafood. You can tell the food is high quality and it's the perfect portions of food to fill you up! Everything I've had has been great!
author: Kelly N.

description:
3.5 stars. 

I love onigiri. Whenever I'm back in Asia, I would either grab them cheap but solid ones from a convenience store, or head to one of the fancier onigiri places in the food part of a large department store. They are easy to eat on the go, have tons of variety, and best of all, there is tons of rice which I can't live without!

Imagine my amazement when a restaurant dedicated to onigiri opened up in SF. I didn't manage to go for years due to my office being in the South Bay, but oh it has been on my list for-freakin-ever. 

Yes, I'm going to be nitpicky even though there isn't another good substitute for this restaurant anywhere this side of the pacific.

First, the rice. Brown rice?! It isn't sticky enough to create that nice texture, and the onigiri fall apart easily because of that. 

Second, the way it's wrapped. It's more like a rice party sandwich (rice/ingredient/rice) than a proper onigiri where rice is all around everything. It's got a nice aesthetic but it's at its best a rice sandwich. 

Third, the fillings. I'm wayyy overjoyed to see my favourite staples like takana or tarako on the menu. It's a treat, and will be the reason why I go back again, but some of the stuff I got was way too salty. Remember the sandwich analogy? Because of that, they filled each onigiri with too much filling. The filling are loyal to the Japanese roots and quite salty - that means you really don't need that much of it! Plus the salt really masks the taste of the natural ingredients (the poor eggplant...)

Anyway, I'd recommend this place if you've never had an onigiri before. However, if you grew up on them, you might be a tad disappointed.
author: Alice C.

description:
Guilty: of loving this place without having stepped inside the store!

My friends and I were at a conference nearby when they said they were going to get onigiri and I couldn't walk with them so they offered to pick one up for me! I took one bite and said I am going to go back and try more of the fillings...the next day it was closed! #bummer 

So I'm going to have to go back the next time I find myself in the City because this place was so good with just one bite...I can't even begin to think of the other menu items that are going to hit my taste buds just right!
author: Grace B.

description:
My (Japanese) Mumsy used to make onigiri for us on our Sunday picnics - sort of Japanese version of a sandwich. Of course, these don't come close (you can't beat mother's home-made), but I did a little skip of joy when I saw this was so close to my new workspace. 

AND, they have natto - it's an acquired taste...a funky, fermented bean product that has viscous texture and smells like old socks. SO delicious, oddly enough (and high in Vitamin K, if you're interested). Love the ume (very traditional) and the spicy bacon (not at all traditional but yummy). I like it with takuan (the yellow pickled daikon) and the edamame. 

I also  tried the hot soba noodles with one shrimp tempura. The broth has great "umami" (yes, an overused word), and with a single onigiri, is a filling lunch.
author: Mi M.

description:
Small and simple sushi sandwich yet packed with great amounts of flavor with every bite. I have been here twice and I gotta say that it is the perfect place to grab a quick snack before getting somewhere. The presentation is very cute and the miso soup is hot and extremely tasty!

Customer service is great! the cashier helped me out when I did not know what kind to get. She offered her opinions and informed me of what other people usually get. You can definitely tell they love their own product.

I would definitely recommend trying this place at least once.
author: Jackson G.

description:
Convenient for a quick grab-and-go snack or lunch. They have a variety of veggie, meat and seafood onigilly ranging from $2.76 to $3.45. They also offer meal sets with 2-3 onigilly and a side as well as bowls with 3 onigilly fillings over rice or salad. The rice balls are decent but not particularly memorable.

They accept payment through the PayPal app, which seems to frequently offer $3 discounts, making 1 onigilly essentially FREE depending on which filling you get! Honestly, probably the only reason I'd return.

=================================

-UNAGI ($3.22) - 4/5
[with sweet BBQ sauce]
Pretty standard unagi flavors but I liked that the sauce wasn't too sweet. Unagi is soft

-SPICY KOGI ($3.45) - 3.5/5
[with honey & gochujang sauce]
A special flavor that's not normally on their menu. The sauce isn't bad. Tangy and sweet, but not overly so, and not particularly spicy. I wasn't a huge fan of the ground beef texture though. I think I would have preferred actual beef.

-RENKON ($2.76) - 3.5/5
[spicy sauteed lotus root with sesame]
It's actually spicy! Flavor is pretty good, but the lotus root could be crunchier.

-SNOW CRAB ($3.45) - 3/5
[with lemon aioli]
Not bad but I don't think I'd get this again. The crab is super soft, but the flavor didn't really stand out to me and the aioli was too creamy for my liking. I thought a "lemon" aioli might taste lighter and more refreshing, but I couldn't taste anything lemon. I think some acidity would've helped with the richness of the mayo.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Great onigiri selection although the line is always super long during lunch hour. 
Highly recommend the salmon and unagi rice ball although I find the price a tad on the high side.

The restaurant itself is pretty small so I'd recommend ordering to go and eating somewhere else. And if you're not satisfied after your meal, you can hop next door to get some boba!
author: Christina N.

description:
I don't know why I like onigiri so much. It's just rice wrapped in seaweed with some filling inside. So simple, yet so delicious. 
The ones I've tried here are the...

Spicy Shrimp ($2.76) - bay shrimp w/ spicy aioli
Miso Tuna Salad ($2.76) - cooked wild albacore w/ miso aioli
Unagi ($3.22) - broiled fresh water eel w/ sweet BBQ sauce
They are all very tasty. The onigiri are made with triangle molds; a triangle of rice in the mold, then filling and a second triangle of rice, and wrapped carefully with nori. At Onigilly, you pay a little more than what you would pay for a cold onigiri at an Asian convenience or grocery store. But the ones you get here are rather large, and of course, warm. Not only that, they give you a good amount of filling. It's not one of those rice balls that have a ton of rice, and a tiny, measly bit of filling deep in the center.
If you pay with the Paypal app, there's often some sort of deal, which makes these rice balls a steal. However, there are often complications with this payment platform.
If I came back, I'd like to try the Tempura Shrimp. The staff is friendly. They work pretty quickly serving these yummy onigiri.
author: Joy W.

description:
Onigilly makes these delicious little...onigillies....what the heck is that you ask?  It's basically a tea sandwich made from rice, filling and nori.  They mold brown sushi rice into two small triangles (if you put them together to form a square, they would be about the size of a slice of sandwich bread) then they put some filling inside and then swaddle the little "sandwich" in a piece of nori.  There are all different types of fillings.  I have tried the snow crab ($3.45) and the soboro ($2.76) and both were delish. I would never have even tried this spot because I thought it was a sit-down restaurant or something but my coworker asked me to try hers and I was instantly hooked!

Cheap, yummy lunch in the Financial District!
author: Emma H.

description:
My coworker took me here for lunch earlier today since she warned that sushiritto would probably have a line. We walked over at around 1 pm and the line was out the door (literally). I was worried but then I realized how small the place is inside and the register is right by the doorway. 

The food is made to order so there will be a bit of a wait. But you just go up, order, and they make your rice balls for you. I was torn because they have so many choices. Not to mention, their three specials, which I'm assuming are seasonal. I love salmon but I hate it with cream cheese in sushi rolls. I love lox with cream cheese though. So it's kind of weird hahaha. Anyway, they had a few other specials but none of them appealed to me. 

I ordered the eggplant, unagi, and teriyaki chicken. I was super tempted to order the spicy bacon but I'm glad that I didn't. I love bacon but my other coworker ate it an she said that it was pretty spicy. I have no tolerance for spiciness so I'll remember not to try it. 


I'll definitely have to come back to try the crab and other meat rice ball (I think it was beef)! It's only a few blocks from work, so I shall return. That and I need to get stamps for my samurai club stamp card! For dessert, they make their own mochi- which looks so good. My coworker got it and she said it was delicious. I'll have to try that next time. Oh and I can't believe I almost forgot... The pickles are so good. I feel like they can almost be too sour but these have more of a hint of sweetness to them. Which makes them amazing with the salty rice balls. Ok, I'm getting hungry writing about them and it's dinner time. Good thing I'm not close by anymore.
author: Venna Q. T.

description:
Don't be fooled by the serving size! I always get a onigilly set and it would fill me up until dinner time! 

TIP: Use their online app and order ahead of time so it's ready by the time you pick it up. I made the mistake of coming in at 12:30PM and it was packed (took about 20 minutes to order and get the food). The store is pretty small too so there wasn't that much space. 

(+) Unagi. I think the unagi is probably my favorite so far! Love the sauce that accompanies it. You definitely won't need any extra sauce with it. Sweet and savory goes so well together! 

(+) Snow Crab. This is probably my second favorite. The crab is super fresh and filling. Definite worth it if you don't know what to get! 

(/) Spicy Crab. I think it was better my first time but it tasted so bland my second time. I will probably pass on this next time and try something new. It definitely wasn't as spicy as I would like and it's lacking some flavors. 

For $10, it is on the pricier side but definitely work it if you're looking to try something new for lunch and something that's quick and easy to eat! :)
author: Tram N.

description:
Ever since I went to Sunny Blue in LA, I've been craving and looking for an onigiri place in the Bay Area. While onigiri is sold in many of the major Japanese markets, I always find those to be too much rice and not enough content/I feel like specialty places do it better. Was pretty stoked to hear about this place from a friend so we decided to check it out.

We ordered the onigilly set and got a soboro, salmon, and chicken. The set comes with edamame and daikon. Only get the set if you want the edamame and daikon--we thought that we were going to get a discount but it's actually the same price. Three is quite a bit of rice since each individual onigiri is actually pretty big so I'd go with two.

The onigiri itself was pretty meh. The soboro was a little too gingery for my liking, and the salmon was a bit dry and flavorless. I thought the chicken which was teriyaki flavored was alright, but nothing standout. It's pretty interesting that they use brown rice here, but I guess it just goes with the whole being healthy value which is pretty cool. Great portion sizes, but meh flavor. 

tldr; will do if you're craving onigiri that actually has some meat/content rather than just being a pure rice ball, but the flavor itself is not particularly outstanding
author: Jasmine X.

description:
First of all, let me just say that this is the best place to come for lunch in the financial district! 

During lunch rush, it is a deeply long line but is somewhat fast! It is a great location cause you can get a drink right next door! 

What I usually order from here is the rice bowl set which includes the 3 toppings of any sort that belongs in the rice ball, side of salad, and pickles. The price varies on how much that piece of topping is. It is really flavorful and my favorite is the spicy bacon which tastes like beef jerky!
author: Brittany L.

description:
Filling, delicious, and affordable! I was a pig and ordered 4 onigiris which was WAY too much... haha. At least I got to try a variety!

I recommend the crab and the eel. Both flavorful and drool-worthy.

Although salmon is my favorite seafood, it tasted dry... and the tuna wasn't as flavorful as the others.
author: Janet H.

description:
I'm a regular at this place and I prefer dinning in if I have time. It's located right next to my school and I go here almost every week between classes. The onigiri are awesome, the service is great, the store is great, EVERYTHING IS WHERE IT SHOULD BE! :D
The casher is super nice and would recommend on the onigiri if you couldn't make up your mind. The waiting time of all order is around 3 to 5 minutes, which is another reason why it's great for a quick lunch during class breaks.
I always order the 3 pieces edamame set if I'm very hungry, and it comes with beans on the side. If I'm just ok-ay hungry, I'd go for the miso soup set, which comes in 2 pieces onigiri and soup on the side. I'm allow to choose almost all type of onigiri to put int the set. They also have japanese tea drinks and soda as well. There's a buy 10 get 1 free set lunch card ( which I always forgot to get :[ ) for discount as well. The total price of lunch often comes down to around $10-15 per person.
As for recommendation on orders:
Unagi ( be careful with bones)
Salmon
Snow Crab
Teriyaki Chicken
Soboro
strawberry mochi: a MUST try, but it's seasonal only.
author: Yilin Y.

description:
I love onigiri. Even though I know better (high school Japanese, anyone?), I have a tendency to refer to it as "triangle sushi." But seriously, something about the rice (not quite sushi rice, it seems) and the filling (usually salmon or another delicious fish) put together into a little triangular package is so delicious. And Onigilly is a great place to get your onigiri fix in Financial District. The lunch line is long, but fast, and the employees are super friendly.

The way it works is you can order a set of 3 onigiri for $9 (there's also rice bowls, which I hear are delicious as well). There's a lot of options, but here are the onigiri I've tried:
- spicy bacon: sounds weird, but it is actually quite delicious; note that this is definitely one of the greasier options
- snow crab: a lighter taste of delicious fresh crabmeat; rounds out the greasiness of other options
- salmon: probably the most "traditional" onigiri; tastes like fresh salmon and a bit of japanese mayo
- unagi: if you love eel like I do, you'll love this one; tastes like an unagi nigiri at a great sushi place, but with more unagi!

The portions are decent (but not huge) and they aren't skimpy with the filling. If you're eating in, enjoy your onigiri with some free barley tea.
author: Brittany C.

description: Love these little rice balls!!!  We got the edamame special and it came with the little beans as well as 3 balls!  All 3 were delish. Love love this place!
author: Julia D.

description:
I really really wanted to like this place. Really badly. The staff was really friendly, it was quick, clean and no bad things for the way they operated. 

The rice balls were really just that. Rice balls, for basically $4 a piece with meat. However, the meat in all of the riceballs were dry and without something worth trying. Not sure how the tuna was even dry but it taste like tuna from a can, heated up. The seaweed salad was tiny and bitter, nothing like what was expected from a basic seaweed salad.
author: Jonathan Q.

description:
After experiencing a delicious onigiri shop in Southern California last year, I was excited to find one in SF! It's a small little shop among other eateries on Kearny Street. 

I read past reviews talking about how the line gets long around noon. We planned to arrive around noon and we were in a time crunch, so I wanted to order ahead online. Unfortunately the service was unavailable. When I arrived, the line was all the way to the back. I waited about 10-15 minutes until I reached the register to order, and our food was ready within 5 minutes after that! We were even lucky enough to snag the only 2 seater table outdoors, which was perfect because we had our puppy with us. 

I ordered the onigilly set: miso tuna, teriyaki chicken and spicy bacon. Surprisingly my favorite was the teriyaki chicken. It was tender and had just enough sauce. The miso tuna was bland. The spicy bacon had an odd texture but I liked the spice. I was happy that the onigiri didn't fall apart after the first bite. and it was easy to eat. The set also comes with takuan (pickled radish) and edamame. 

I ordered the matcha green tea lemonade. It's an unappealing color due to the matcha but I wanted to try it anyway. It tasted mostly like plain lemonade, although I'm not sure what kind of taste I was supposed to expect. They also offer fresh strawberry mochi. It was tempting but I'm not a fan of red bean so I didn't get it. Wish I did! 

The service was fast and the cashier was very polite. I would definitely come back if I was in the area looking for something quick but healthy and tasty.
author: Ashley C.

description: This place is a yummy and convenient place for lunch. I had their Edamame set and chose the Crab, Salmon, and Hijiki. It came with crunchy pickles and edamame. Gotta love sides! I was not a fan of the Hijiki. It was too sweet. But the great thing is there's so many other ones I haven't tried. I would definitely be back. My only complaint is there were no seats, but that is how many places are in SF. This can easily be brought back to the office as well.
author: Fran P.

description:
This place is literally a block away from my work so I always pass by this restaurant. Finally decided to give this a try. The cashier was really nice, genuinely friendly and eager to help this first timer. I ended up ordering a salad bowl with toppings of their spicy shrimp, spicy bacon, and snow crab. I also ordered a matcha green tea lemonade with the food. The wait wasn't long as I went in just a little after 11 am. 

The matcha green tea lemonade is interesting. It tastes mostly like lemonade, but it's got a slight matcha after taste. Not too bad. Terms of food, I should've stuck with their onigilly's or gotten a rice bowl. The cold food did not go too well with greens. The snow crab tasted a bit off, and the spicy shrimp was just okay. The only thing I liked was the spicy bacon. Some of the salad greens at the bottom of the bowl were bruised.... boo :(

If I could give 3.5 stars I would.
author: Ava F.

description: I'd like to make it clear that the only thing I ever eat in any and every Japanese restaurant I go to are Teriyaki chicken, Teriyaki salmon, shrimp tempura & miso soup. I don't eat sushi, I don't eat anything else. I was able to try Onigilly because my husband was doing UberEats. They gave him a free meal for delivering for them so they gave us Teriyaki chicken and salmon Onigilly. I was hesitant at first because I don't like seaweed and I didn't expect it to be in a sushi form, I thought it was going to be a Teriyaki bowl lol. I was surprised by how much flavor both teriyaki and salmon had and it wasn't raw (which is why I don't eat sushi). 3 pieces of Onigilly was actually enough. I looked at their menu to see what else they have and it was a simple menu. The portion was just right and it was cheap. They sell the Onigilly by the piece or in a set/meal. I tried their Chicken Karaage (Japanese Fried Chicken) and it was also good. I also tried their shrimp tempura Onigilly and it also had flavor! I am looking forward to trying other food on their menu. I love them. By the way, they are also located on Sansome, Embaracadero & Market.
author: Raina J.

description: One of my go-to places to grab a quick lunch when I'm in the Financial District. I usually like to get the set of 3 onigiris, and pick one flavour from each column (meat, seafood, veggies). My favourites are the soboro and the unagi. Recently I tried the rice bowl with soboro, unagi and teriyaki tofu and really enjoyed it!
author: Michelle C.

description:
Egad! There's that name again, the one I hate because it plays up the stereotype that we roll our r's into l's. I no talk right that. No tickee, no lice ball. So solly. Why not cast us all in a WWII propaganda film raising our bayonets and shouting "Banzai!" Am I making too big a deal over a name? Probably not. I was just watching "Gentleman's Agreement", and anti-Semitism in that movie starts with a tasteless joke. Perhaps the Yellow Peril resurfaces with a single rice ball. It's onigiri, my friends...with an 'r', not an 'l'. But you want to know about the rice balls, not my balls, right?
