Anyway, this was once a nondescript pop-up cart that showed up at the Heart of the City Farmers' Market, and now there's a spot in that alley of shame next to the Hyatt Regency and this larger, sit-down spot on Kearny. I noticed they sell lunch sets, which I assume to be bento-like creations but not really. But it was kind of a deal, $9.95 for two rice balls and a bowl of noodle soup (photo: http://bit.ly/1lAqfot). I went for the Spicy Bacon with garlic butter and chili paste and the Soboro, the ginger-honey-braised angus beef option (photo: http://bit.ly/1gYi1VP). They are prepared Chipotle-style in rote assembly fashion, and while the ingredients lent some interesting flavors, the execution not so much.

The rice balls at least were decent albeit unmemorable lunchtime fare, but the Tofu Noodle Soup was a rather drab concoction purportedly made of all-natural ingredients including the noodles made of "tofu-yam" whatever that is. The miso itself was too milky for my taste, and the only ingredients I enjoyed in the broth were the shiitake mushrooms and the seaweed (photo: http://bit.ly/1sJoQQ9). The whole experience always makes me miss my mom who was a true onigiri master with more traditional fillings usually involving daikon or natto (which they do offer here). But if you need a faux-fix, you can overlook the rolling r's and give at least the rice balls a try.

FOOD - 3 stars...rice balls Chipotle-style but avoid the noodle soup
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...not much to it, grab a table when you can
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...not as nice as you would think...oh, that's right, we're not in J-Town
TOTAL - 3 stars..."Rice balls!", said the Queen, "If I had them, I'd be King!"
author: Ed U.

description:
OH MY GOD. A shop that focuses solely on onigiri?!?!?!! I am sold.

I'm relatively far from here, but I have put it on my Top 10 places to get lunch when I'm at work. I will gladly walk the 10-15 minutes here to have an early lunch at 11am.

The portions are larger than what I'd be able to find at grocery stores like Nijiya. They also look a little different from regular onigiri. I ordered the salmon and the soboro. The soboro was awesome. The way they fashioned the rice around it was like using two rice patties, then wrapped with nori. Soooo good. Plus, you can get tamagoyaki on the side, which puts a huge smile on my face. My meal of choice is essentially two giant onigiri and a tamagoyaki. The best part of it is, it's quite affordable. It's only a dollar or two more than what you'd get at a Japanese grocery store, and they make it for you when you order it, so it's fresh and not wrapped in those plastic onigiri wrappers. Man...I love onigiri. It's just such a happy-sounding food.

For me, that's an entire meal. It keeps me full but not overly stuffed, like most FiDi lunches would normally do for me. Plus, Asha Tea House is on the way back. It's a win-win for me all around.
author: Robbin A.

description: My co-worker took me to this location to try this dish. I've been around the area but suprisingly    have never been to this venue. We walked in and there were a few individuals in front of us and the menu was pretty extensive. They're known for their little triangle wraps which are known as "onigilly". There are various things you can chose from for what you would like the "meat" to be. I chose three different ones - the spicy shrimp, the snow crab, and the terriyaki tofu. Overall, I felt like everything was very "clean" and "fresh", but missing a tad bit of a taste, specifically the snowcrab. The others were okay, but I think if they drizzled some sauce on top, it would have been 100. I definitely didn't think a few of those onigillies would fill me up but it definitely did. 3 later, I was stuffed. I did see their bowl and salad which looked very appealing. But given the option of poke bowl or these snacks, I would probably pick the poke bowl. I like things with more sauce, something a little more sweet and tangy. I wouldn't say in particular this is a must go place, because I didn't think the taste was 100. Most of the littl sandwiches are anywhere from $3.20-4.50.
author: Amy Y.

description: tried the tarako, gave me food poisoning :/
author: Kitty M.

description:
This place is awesome!!! The rice triangles are so cute and delicious to consume (my mouth is watering atm while thinking about it ) 

I only had the chance to try the unagi and the spicy shrimp. Very simple but the flavoring is on point! Although I liked the spicy shrimp, I loved the unagi so much that I allowed myself to get seconds. Another thing was that I really did wish they had more toppings on the seafood sections. 

Overall, nice and quick place for lunch where service is friendly, the price is kinda high but it's San Francisco so ¯\_(ツ)_/¯


I'm coming back regardless.
author: Mai N.

description:
I ordered the teriyaki tofu, spicy shrimp, unagi, and snow crab. 

The teriyaki looked the least appealing but it was tasty because of the teriyaki sauce. I wished it was made with fried tofu instead of soft tofu so it will add more texture to it. i wasn't able to taste the tofu because of the overwhelming amount of rice compared to teriyaki. It felt like I was eating seaweed and rice with teriyaki sauce. 

The spicy shrimp was not that spicy but good nonetheless. It was made with baby shrimp. 

The unagi and snow crab was good but nothing special. I like how they use real crab instead of the imitation stuff. 

They said they use brown rice but it looks like white rice. 

Overall, this place was okay. Not somewhere I see myself coming back to because it's not my type of food.
author: Michelle T.

description:
Super busy little place that lives up to the long lunch lines. I remember when these guys were a food truck. Glad to see they didn't skimp on quality ingredients and decent combo options when they opened their own shop.

I like onigiri (rice balls with vegetables or protein inside wrapped in seaweed). It's like Japanese fast food. Soboro (ginger honey ground beef) is a love/hate option. I can understand why some find it too sweet. It reminds me of Filipino menudo when the cook puts a little too much sugar in it. If you want to play it safe stick to the vegetarian side of the menu. You seriously can't go wrong with shiitake mushrooms.

I winced a little bit at the price of my lunch. Then again they are in the Financial District. Everything in the area comes with a slightly higher price tag.
author: Christine L.

description: Delicious Japanese rice balls were perfect t for a healthy fast food lunch. Had the Takana, spicy pickled mustard greens, Miso Nasu, flash fried eggplant, and the Spicy Shrimp, sandwiched between two large triangles of rice and wrapped in Nori. Came with a side of edamame - it was perfect.
author: Elissa V.

description:
Have I really not written a review about the place I crave all the time? The place that satisfies all my cravings and tastes like home? 

I love onigilly!!! The 2 I constantly get is the Tarako and unagi onigilly. They come out warm and a perfect triangle. The snow crab and well, basically all of them are good. But TARAKO is my favorite and I don't even know where else to find that! 

Get the combos! There's always a line for lunch but it goes quickly. They close early so buy dinner too earlier on in the day. They take card and have an onigilly express in the embarcadero center as well! Something so simple, made so well and so good. I love you, Onigilly!
author: Joanna S.

description:
Onigilly is a triangle rice ball filled with happiness :) A great lunch spot in Fidi  

- Gets crowded during lunch hours, so try to be there by 12PM.
- Great place with vegetarian and vegans options too.  Tyy their shiitake mushroom 
- Must Try - The TRIO , 3 onigilly of your choice with pickel and edemamme $10.
- Wide variety of fillings to choose from, vegetarian, meat and seafood options.
- MUST TRY: shiitake mushroom, teriyaki chicken, snow crab, spicy shrimp
- To Avoid : Salmon, its too dry
- Each onigilly range from $3-$4 each
- Its simple, healthy, light, quick and reasonably priced lunch
author: Payal B.

description:
Traditionally, Japanese onigiri (rice balls) are filled with salted salmon or pickled plums.

Here at Onigilly, you can get fancy fillings such as miso tuna salad, spicy shrimp and snow crab. They have veggie, seafood and meat options so everyone can have something to suit their taste. 

Service is friendly and the restaurant is really small with limited seating, so it can get uncomfortably packed. I wouldn't suggest coming here if you're hungry enough to eat a horse... They're rice balls; don't expect a heavy meal!
author: Christine W.

description:
A small lunch spot in the Chinatown area. Great if:

1) you want something you can eat on the go. The small rice balls with meat are easy to eat and come with edamame if you choose the combo, which I think is a good deal.

2) like a variety of items in one meal. I like that I can mix and match vegetables and meat in one order. This place also doesn't have the usual meats, but instead have spicy bacon, snow crab, and soboro.


It's not so great if:

1) you have a party of larger than 4 people. There's no space in there.

2) you don't like rice, The ratio of rice to meat is astounding; you're likely to get full off of the rice alone.

I asked the cashier what was popular/good, and she basically listed everything on the menu, which was funny but not entirely helpful haha. Overall, the food is not likely to blow you away, and nothing about the meal warranted a return either.
author: Jonathan B K.

description:
I am surrounded by so many Asian restaurants and it is a blessing. Onigilly offers those delicious Japanese seaweed sushi triangle as lunch. I love them but I wanted something more fulfilling so I tried out their rice bowl. I was really impressed with the food! 

I had 3 toppings including tuna salad, ocra with bacon and another ground meat option. The rice bowl comes with a side of salad and some Japanese pickles. It is definitely satisfying but not overly fattening. 

This is place is usually crowded during lunch hours so try come after 1PM. Your wait will be much more reasonable.
author: Athena C.

description:
Remember when they were just a food cart? Well it's no surprise the tasty treats of Onigilly were able to make it to the brick and mortar. I've been coming since they opened and I'm always impressed at the friendliness of the staff, especially the gentleman at the register who hands me my credit card back oh-so-formally like they did in Japan. Plus, it's a relatively fast and healthy option (although, like Emily C. mentioned, they could up their filling to rice quotient).

Perhaps my affinity for this place is a little biased... it reminds me of studying abroad in Japan, saving up my food stipend for gifts for my family and friends back home and subsisting only on the onigilly from 7-11 or Mini-Stop. Those were the days.

Get the popular miso tuna, the spicy bacon or one of their seasonal veggies.

Also, many options are GF. Pro-tip!
author: Nikki M.

description:
I love onigiri, they are tasty, portable, and oh so yummy when done right. Unfortunately, onigilly is just passable, but not satisfying. I would have liked the option of mixed grain rice. And the portion of rice to filling is too much. Need more filling. I ordered the edamame meal and got exactly nine edamame pods, yes I counted them. Please, why so skimpy on the edamame? Is there a shortage that I don't know about? 

Dear Owners,

Onigiri can be so delicious, please up your game, so that we can all enjoy yummy onigiri. I would be sad for someone new to try it and be disappointed and be turned off to this delectable treat.
author: Sanda C.

description: A simple, well packaged, healthy and tasty lunch or snack with the right price. Many options to choose from including Vegan
author: Seth P.

description: This place rocks! A lot of people in the reviews mention the lines, but if you come later enough in the day (around and after 3pm is a good bet), you'll find the line is either drastically reduced or nonexistent. I typically go for the Edamame set - three ongiri with a side of pickled radish slices and boiled soybeans. I prefer the vegan ingredients they have here over the meat ingredients, as the mouthfeel of the former is better imo, and I haven't particularly tackled the pricier Seafood fillings. I had their vegan Miso soup once, and though I like it, I'd rather get the three rice balls over two + soup. Definitely recommended though.
author: Brandi R.

description:
Love how fast they get your order to you. While I was paying for my order at the cashier, I feel like they were already scooping the fillings to my onigiri! 

I wasn't kidding, because after I decide to settle down at the small table in the back near the tea/utensil station and take some pictures of their flawless assembly line, I heard my number get called. I thought I was taking a picture of my order, but it was actually for the two guests that ordered after me. Mine was already done and ready for pick-up. Ha!

I ordered an onigilly set of three onigiri (snow crab, unagi, and salmon) with a side of edamame and pickled radish. I absolutely loved the snow crab onigiri. Sure it was with mayo, which I'm normally not too fond of, but this was my 
favorite flavor out of the three. Unagi/eel is good with the sauce it usually comes with, but I've had more flavorful unagi. Something about it was also pretty unique flavored though. Salmon was too dry. 

Would come again though, especially if I'm in the area and craving some onigiri!
author: Sara T.

description:
Good Asian food is difficult to come by in this city, and sometimes it gets frustrating. Sure, it's a first world problem, but as someone who has been raised on Japanese food for most of her life, not being able to find a restaurant with authentic Japanese food is like being homesick... except it's your stomach that's crying.

A couple of friends and I met up here when it was surprisingly not crowded, especially for a weekday lunch. I decided to get the Onigilly combo with Spicy Bacon musubi, Tarako musubi and Miso Eggplant musubi. While waiting, I got some of their mugicha (barley tea) which, oh my goodness, tasted so authentic.

My musubi came out really quickly, and though they looked great... they were uber triangular, which was a little strange. Regardless, the filling inside the musubi was REALLY fresh, though sometimes it was a little strong, especially in the Tarako musubi.

My favorite out of the three was the Miso Eggplant -- a little unfair since I LOVE both miso and eggplant. I was still very satisfied with the food (a tad expensive, at $11 for a combo). 

Ah! If only Onigilly were in L.A. so I could try all of the other different flavors. Perhaps I can squeeze in one more visit before I move back...
author: Sara C.

description:
If there's a long line, don't worry. It goes fast!

I ordered the crab, beef, and roe. Bear in mind that these are larger than traditional onigiri. I saw some reviews mention there was too much mayo in the crab, but I didn't think so at all. It was just enough to keep the filling together. Pork was a solid, delicious choice. Roe was salty with a bit of spice.

I was surprised by how crispy and juicy their karaage were. I'll definitely be coming back to try the other onigiri--and for any random karaage cravings.

Edit:

I went back to try the spicy bacon, unagi, and tempura shrimp. The unagi was the best of the three, but I was disappointed that the tempura shrimp came with only one piece of tempura sandwiched between the rice. The tempura:rice ratio was way off and left me feeling unsatisfied.
author: Gabrielle G.

description:
Make all the jokes you want, of course I like rice balls. 

You get a well-balanced lunch of three onigiris with their lunch set. They're moderately sized but if you choose your fillings wisely it'll fill you up. I was originally lured in by a deal offered by Paypal. If you downloaded their app and ordered at certain eateries you'd get $5 off. Sadly something was wonky with on Onigilly's side and they couldn't process the offer. The cashier told me to send Paypal customer service an email but it wasn't a huge deal to me. Paypal app deleted.

Overall solid quick lunch option. Have not tried the rice bowls yet but they look enticing. My favorite fillings are the chicken, snow crab and salmon so far. Onigilly set (9) and you're set for the rest of the day :)
author: Jenny Q.

description:
Delicious place! Different  experience.

I got the edamame set, it came with 3 onigillys, edamame and pickles.. 
I ordered the teriyaki chicken, tuna, and unagi. I really like the unagi and teriyaki... The tuna I thought would be like the spicy poke or spicy tuna you get in sushi.. It wasn't. It was  like a tuna salad type thing which tasted weird with rice.. 

The edamame was good, but cold.. The pickles were a nice touch.

The service was quick.. There is usually a massive line outside. (Always a good sign).

Definitely coming back to try other flavors.
author: Daniella G.

description: My main grief with onigiri is that there is rarely enough filling.  This is the way it ought to be, particularly in Japan, b/c they use very high quality rice, and that is supposed to be what is highlighted in the dish.  However, I don't have a refined enough palate to differentiate rice quality, so for me, though I enjoy onigiri, I usually pair it with side dishes to give it more flavor.  Onigilly makes onigiri with enough filling that well seasoned and delicious.  I can't remember having them as good anywhere else.  It may or may not have the best quality rice (they do use a calrose), but it's good to me.  I would visit again.
author: Lan N.

description:
Omgeeee!!!! Onigiriiii!!!!

Yeah, that's exactly how I feel. This was my first time actually trying onigiri and I've always wanted to since I watched Fruits Basket. But it's an interesting little snack. I don't know that I'd say it's enough for lunch but I love the idea. And the guy at the counter was all smiles behind his glasses and he was really nice! I'm a sucker for smiley people in customer service. He was also very patient when I got up to the counter while hesitating on my order.

I got the Edamame Set, which means I got to pick 3 of the "onigilly" on their menu - comes with a tiny side of edamame and pickles for $8.74. Personally, I think Spicy Bacon is a MUST. It's BACON! I also got the Salmon and Shiitake. I LOVED the Shiitake - it's sweet and mushroomy. I can do without the Salmon next time though - cooked a little dry.

I'm definitely planning to go back and I'm excited to try the other things. There's normally a line but I went at around 3:30pm so right before they closed, which was awesome. I did almost steal somebody else's order though - my bad for being so excited to try the rice balls...

And it probably really is "as good as it gets" because I've never tried anything else like this!
author: Athena C.

description: Totally hits the spot when craving masubi. It's so simple and so well done, no complaints here.
author: Justine L.

description:
Love this place! I went in at around 11:45am and there was no line.

The employees were welcoming and friendly as I walked through the door. 

I ordered the Edamame combo with the snow crab, spicy shrimp, and unagi oginillies and they were delicious. I felt like the size of each was just right. Three oginillies was just enough to fill me up, but not make me feel bloated. 

My only issue was with the spicy shrimp. I took my order to-go and by the time that I got back to work the sauce had creeped through the seams of the seaweed and the bottom of 2 of my oginillies was covered with it and it became a very messy meal.
author: Gail M.

description:
I walk through the door, hear kyary pamyu pamyu blasting on the speakers, and I already know I am in a good place.

Onigilly looks like one of those Asian fusion places that have been disrupting the food industry while catering to the tastes of young tech professionals in the slowly gentrifying San Francisco. It is what it is. Onigilly takes the simple concept of the onigiri and offers both traditional offerings, such as the various fish, shrimp, and other staples to Japanese cuisine, as well as fusion offerings following recent food trends, such as bacon. They make no effort to hide the fact that it's a really simple concept, having been developed primarily to have a simple meal that already wasn't in the market.

And you know what, Onigilly does it right. The image is traditional enough, yet accommodating to its environment. It wanted to deviate from all the preconceived notions of how Japanese cuisine was to be in the United States, added the niche that was missing in America given that we don't have conbini here, and pulled it off very well.

For easily under $10, you can have a filling meal, and it's a great balance of carbs and proteins. Really, if I lived by here, I would literally eat here almost every day.

They also make all their onigiri with organic stuff and brown rice, so if you're into that, or want to at least be pseudo-healthy, it's good for your conscience as well.

All in all, Onigilly is simple, elegant, and gets the job done fantastically.

TIP: Bacon onigiri is dope.
author: Brian L.

description:
This place is small and crowded for a reason.
Onigilly is BOMB! I get the shrimp tempura, snow crab and teriyaki chicken. I shy away from raw fish because it's really warm in there, and I don't know if the food sitting on the line is cold enough to prevent bacteria or not. 

I'm a huge fan of the miso soup, their tofu chunks are huge! Seaweed salad is good. I wish the guy at the front didn't always ask you for a tip, it's awkward. 

Catering is excellent. Easy to contact and order, they even deliver if you're in the area! Always a hit in the office.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Compliments to the PayPal app, my friend and I ventured out to try this place during the lunch rush.  Spend $5, get $5 back from PayPal, just link your banking account or credit card and be sure to "save offer" first before paying through the app.  Basically, you get 50% off, I'm sold!  

You have a couple of options here:  Rice Bowl (which I got), Onigilly set (3 choices of onigilly), or the Soup set (2 choices of onigilly with miso soup).  The rice bowl comes with a side of edamame which I wasn't too crazy about but it's healthy.  After looking at so many options, I went with the snow crab, spicy shrimp, and soboro.  The snow crab was surprisingly fresh and oh so yummy, by far my favorite out of the three that I tried!  The spicy shrimp had a nice kick to it and had just the right amount of spice with the rice.  It was just so flavorful!  The soboro was a delicious and filling and filled me up.

Reasonably priced and a healthy option for lunch that won't induce you to a food coma when you go back to the office!
author: Kevin C.

description:
This is starting to become my favorite place to grab lunch in FiDi. It's fresh, filling, delicious, healthy-ish and not too expensive. I always choose from the seafood onigillys - miso tuna, spicy shrimp, snow crab, fish roe... they're all really good. I usually get 2 onigillys with a side of pickled radish. The chicken karaage is just okay. 

Moreover, everyone here is SO friendly and the line moves quickly, even when it looks long. Love this place!
author: Melody Y.

description: I came here around lunch time and line was outside the door. Don't let the long lines scare you, they make the food asap. I wanted to order the endaname set, but I didn't know what I should order. The cashier kindly recommended some choices. We got our food not too long after we ordered, but had trouble for finding seats.
author: Melanie N.

description: A quick, simple, and light lunch. Snow Crab and Salmon are my top two faves for Onigilly. I like the onigilly sets better than ordering as a bowl; it's more satisfying with the wrapped in seaweed in my opinion.
author: Briget P.

description: Interestingly shaped food and also takes great. There are a variety of options (I like the shrimp and eel ones). The rice and ingredients are pretty fresh and three triangles can definitely fill you up!
author: Caley Z.

description: Fast service and perfect for a quick snack or you can make a meal out of it! We came in for a lunch date and beat the lunch crowd that started to pile up around 11:50AM. There was a large selection of different types of onigiri from vegetarian to meat lovers to seafood! All the ones we tried were delicious! My favorite was the flash fried eggplant one! My husbands favorite was the spicy Kogi! The rice was perfectly cooked and the seaweed wrap was crunchy. The fillings were well seasoned and they don't skimp on stuffing the rice ball. They put your onigiri in a little to go box so you can enjoy them on the go! We will come back next time to try more flavors for sure!
author: Hilary C.

description: I had the salmon zusui, delicious and the price is quite fair. Recommend! Will try some others next times.
author: Peng G.

description:
Just get the Unagi, you won't regret it. I've tried the spicy bacon, snow crab one, shiitake and the salmon. I personally prefer Unagi over anything else because it's consistent and it tastes good. The spicy bacon was a bit salty and so were the shiitake and salmon. And for the snow crab, it was overpowered with mayonnaise, which was kind of gross in my opinion. Great place to grab a quick bite though. Oh and if you like miso soup, I suggest skipping it here. I've tried it a few times in hopes I just came on a bad day for it and to my disappointment, it always tastes watered down :( 

Would give this place 5 if there were many more things on their menu that I like.
author: cadence p.

description:
An ideal lunch spot for people in the area because of taste, convenience, quickness, and fair prices! While there is usually a line that builds up for the lunch rush, the line moves quickly. I would recommend getting there fairly early if possible as both times I have gone, they have run out of certain flavors. I love that onigilly is such a convenient size and cute shape, portable and easy to eat - great for a quick lunch or maybe even a picnic lunch.

Favorite flavor so far is Spicy Bacon - but it packs a lot of flavor compared to some others so you may want to save it for last if you order several onigilly. 

So far, I haven't really found the combos to be that impressive or cheaper by any significant amount. The edamame is only okay (served cold, unseasoned) and the miso soup is actually a little disappointing (ended up throwing mine away). The one flavor that I tried that I also didn't find to be impressive was the chicken teriyaki because it lacks flavor.
author: Josephine T.

description:
The word "onigilly" is a play off of the word "onigiri," which is a Japanese rice ball with filling inside....which makes sense because onigilly is basically an "americanized" version of onigiri. They have many fillings to choose from (including some vegetarian and vegan options) which are all really tasty (the only one I do not recommend is the salmon because it is quite bland and costs a bit more than the other fillings). The sets are nice too but I usually just get the onigilly because I'm not a very big fan of their edamame or soup. 

Keep in mind that this is a very small place and they make your onigilly to order so it's best to come before/after lunch hours if you can.
author: Anna H.

description: Lol ~$4 for 4 tiny pieces of chicken karaage...definitely a ripoff. but their zosui is good.
author: Evanny H.

description:
If you love small, cute food, and are looking for a quick bite, look no further! 

Quality: Pretty good quality, and really healthy, because they claim to use 30% brown rice in their rice balls and honey/agave as natural sweeteners instead of sugars and artificial sweeteners. Also, there's no need for soy sauce, as the rice ball as a whole is already pretty flavorful depending on the filling.

Size: The portions are small, and perfect for a light meal. They have a 3 rice ball combo for a little over $8, and a 2 rice ball combo with miso soup for around $6, give or take. Take advantage of these combos because you get your money's worth, as each rice ball can range from $2 something to $3 something, depending on the filling.

Service: Great, friendly service! The cashier was helpful and patient with my indecisiveness. 

This was my first time here, and I loved the ones I tried: unagi, chicken teriyaki, and shiitake. The green tea lemonade was tasty as well. It wasn't too sweet, and I could taste the tea in it. I definitely will come back to try the other fillings since I work conveniently nearby.
author: Corinna T.

description: Tried it when I went to the French Consulate. It's very tasty and the price is fair.
author: Emily L.

description:
I've loved this place ever since I met the owners selling the onigiris from their food cart.  Now, they have a full-fledged restaurant and express lunch stop in the Financial District, so I can pick up their healthy vegetarian-friendly Japanese cuisine anytime.  

I've been trying to learn as much as possible about vegan Japanese cuisine before my first trip to Japan so I stopped by Onigilly for lunch this week to try more of their menu. I asked the cashier about which vegan items contained sesame since I'm intolerant to them and it's a common ingredient in Japanese food.  The cashier was very knowledgeable about the menu and double-checked with the chef on the ingredients before suggesting the hijiki and shiitake mushroom onigiris and a potato korokke.  

When I picked up my order at the counter, I was delighted that along with some delicious veg rice balls, the cashier included a note to teach to how to ask about my food allergies in Japanese for my upcoming trip!  What awesome service and true care about their customers!
author: Kimberly J.

description:
Onigiri is my favorite snack to eat while in Japan. So I am happy to have Onigilly around. very tasty rice balls. fast food at its best. long line but quick service. 

small place and seatings around 20 occupancy. you might have to share tables when it comes down to it. but most people take it to-go. 

I like their vision of healthy eats and sustainable practices. hope they open up more locations in the city. this one caters to the hours of FD workers so they close early.
author: Jules L.

description: Food is ridicously good here. Got the snow crab and the spicy shrimp, teriyaki chicken. This place definitely gives Sushiritto a run for its money because here you get to try more things at once which is a big win win for me. Only complaint is probably the seating, they have an upstairs office it seems but it always seems empty, it would be cool if they could turn it into a seating area for customers.
author: Navdeep D.

description:
Came here late on Friday afternoon and there was no line.  The onigiri is so familiar, from travels in Asia - and it's done really well here.  We had the spicy bacon, which was good, and the snow crab, which was excellent.  

The prices are OK, but it is a fair amount of rice and filling, so I think it's good.

Definitely stop by for a quick snack, or get three and make a meal (it's cheaper!)
author: Jason H.

description:
I went here recently with some friends, and the idea sounded very cool! Very "San Francisco" LOL. It is an adorable shop next to Plentea, and luckily we got seats in the very small store. I got the edamamme kit, with pickled radishes, and the cashier recommended the unagi onigiri, and based on Yelp reviews I got the fish roe paste one and the fish salad one.

It was so filling. I could only finish two in one go and saved the rest for later. It's a bunch of rice so no surprise. My friend thought the fish roe one was too weird and I do admit it's kind of a strong flavor, but I enjoyed it! The unagi one was delicious, and finally the fish salad was good. 

It was all good, but I feel like this is something I could make at home. I used their pepper powder thing and it was so good! Overall, at around $12, what could you expect from San Fran? I would drop by here to eat for a quick snack that's not too pricey compared to other things.
author: Michelle V.

description: Yay! I'm a fan. Fast, delicious, filing little triangles of goodness. This is the place for you if you want something fast without feeling that fast food sluggishness.
author: Thao T.

description: Loved the concept. Mushroom one was great; Unagi one was great; Tina one was too salty; salmon one was too salty; green tea lemonade was very wired; shrimp one was great.
author: Anya C.

description:
If you need a quick and fresh handmade lunch, Onigilly is the perfect place to go to!

For those of you who have no idea what Onigiri is, it is a japanese rice balls! The most casual and traditional Onigiri is filled with Ume (japanese pickled plum). Which they also have on their menu!

But they have so much more! And here are my top list of must haves in their menu:
Spicy Shrimp
Miso Tuna
Spicy Bacon
Ume

Most of their rice balls range from $3-$4 each. Very cheap and worth the price because they realllyyyy stuff them rice balls with them fillings!

I suggest to go between 2-4pm because
11-1pm and 5-6pm are lunch and dinner rush, the wait can be pretty crazy!

Cheers!
author: Inge C.

description:
It's such a simple operation, but I feel that their make to order quality is excellent. Assembly is done very efficiently and it's just kind of neat to watch from behind the counter.

Plus, what's not to love about two perfectly shaped triangles of rice with a filling of your choice sandwiched lovingly in between? 

I thoroughly enjoyed my two choices of teriyaki tofu and snowcrab. The snowcrab was definitely the runaway winner in my book - sweet but not overly mixed and broken up (like imitation crab in a california roll). I didn't get a lot of tofu in my teriyaki tofu, but teriyaki and rice are certainly a match made in heaven regardless. Paired it with a matcha lemonade which proved to be very refreshing on a hot summer day in San Francisco.

Lunch came out to under $10 - a steal in downtown, in my opinion at least!
author: Elaine Y.

description: I love these little Japanese rice balls. Luckily this place is open until 4 so I missed the lunchtime rush. I got the 3 onigilly set that comes with soy beans and pickled radish. The three I choose were eggplant, spicy bacon, and snow crab. All three were delicious. They are also extremely filling! I also love that they are made fresh! I definitely want to go back and try some of the other flavors.
author: Nia R.

description: Yummy!! First time here and will defiantly come again super fresh and tasty I got spicy tuna and shrimp just the right amount of seaweed in the outside . Price is right in the financial district small but the line moved fast! Will be coming here again soon great place for lunch downtown!
author: lyn m.

description:
I love this place for multiple reasons. 

1.  Its the only restaurant (that I know of) of its type around the area.  Haven't seen rice balls anywhere outside of Japan so.... yes! Bring more awesome, authentic and diverse cuisine to San Francisco :) 

2.  It's cheap. ~5 for a rice ball and soy beans and if you're tired (like me) of paying $10-15 for way too much food that you force yourself to eat and then you get food coma at work... yeah this is great.

3.  Its delicious. It's clean. The japanese do it right.   They know how to package their food in a way that you can eat the packaging!  Clean, tasty, warm finger food. 

4.  Its fast. ~15 min to get your order.

Love love love!
author: Kristin C.

description: Great for when I want a quick grab, definitely would be a happier customer if they used half the rice, but then again that might just be a personal preference. :)
author: Xer C.

description:
This is one of the best "Fast Foods" you could eat - It's real food, but made really fast without the sacrifice of nutrition

I ordered the Unagi, Salmon, and Snow crab because I like seafood and I like the traditional Japanese flavors. The Onigilly's meat, rice, and seaweed work in perfect harmony to create a delicious yet simple meal. You can't go wrong with this since what you see is what you get and nothing less. 

The restaurant is small and perfect for a quick bite there or to go. 

I would be a regular if I worked closer, but definitely a solid place for lunch or a snack.
author: Richie C.

description:
AHHH this place is SO GOOD! 

I've had it on my list for awhile...was craving fish/japanese food so I finally made my way over here. 

I decided to get the salad bowl with Spicy Shrimp, Unagi and Spicy Bacon while my boyfriend got the same combination but in a rice bowl... oh and we shared a miso soup.

I feel that the prices here are more reasonable considering that the food is of really good quality and extremely flavorful. An adequate healthy lunch for less than $10!

All of the meats we got were delicious! Super flavorful! I personally think I liked the unagi best while my bf said the shrimp was his favorite. You can't go wrong with any of them though. 

My boyfriend was surprised that the rice was brown, said it tasted like white rice... which is a good thing for the picky rice eaters, healthy without compensating flavor (although I personally enjoy brown rice). 

The miso soup was good too, not too strong or salty; I loved that it was completely natural so I know that I was getting some of my probiotic intake for the day :D 

They have TONS of options for your onigiri/salad/rice bowls. If you're vegetarian or gluten free this is a great option for you guys too! If you're in a hurry onigiri is very friendly for on the go eating as well.

The restaurant is pretty small/cramped and busy. We went at an odd time..around 1:30-2ish but there was a steady flow of customers coming in... if you're dining in you're gonna have to choose on whether or not you wanna stick your ass or frontal area in someones face since the tables are really close together =p 

But that's not the point! I definitely recommend this spot and am looking forward to coming here again!
author: Melissa C.

description: This place is right next to Plentea. I came here around noon and the line was super long. I ordered the edamame set (choice of 3 onigiri). The Unagi one was super good. There is limited seating but overall I prefer Sushiritto.
author: Wendy C.

description:
This is by far one of my favorite new places to go for a quick snack. After all we are talking about triangular shaped rice filled with 100% awesomeness! Plus how could you go wrong when you can just head over to Pleantea next door and get some boba while you wait right?!

So what I find super awesome about this place is that for a snack, this place kicks ass. They even have natto!! Think of a Chipotle for Onigiri. Everything is super simple, decor is awesome, and you get free tea there. You can't go wrong with it. 

Also I highly recommend looking at the menu and asking them how the fish is served. I got a salmon, but it turned out to be cooked salmon and not the shashimi one that I thought. Drats. Nonetheless a definite place to go!
author: Nathan L.

description:
Cheap!!!! Cheap cheap cheap!!!! Yes cheap!! 

Though what you get looks like an onigiri, it isn't your typical stuffed rice ball. The onigiri itself is more like a sandwich in the shape of an onigiri, with two rice patties wrapped in seaweed. This is better because there is a more equal filling-to-rice ratio than in usual onigiris. The rice isn't my favorite - a little stale and sticky - but it doesn't really impact how much I enjoyed these.

Soboro ($2.76): ginger honey braised ground beef - I wouldn't order again, but I did finish it all. So salty. 
GRADE: C

Miso Nasu ($3.22): flash fried eggplant in red miso with sesame and green onion. YES the eggplant is fried until soft and pasty. The eggplant stuffing is actually cold inside the warm seaweed and rice wrapping. When I left it overnight and ate it the next day, it developed a Chinese black bean sauce taste. Still good though. 
GRADE: A++++++

Unagi ($3.22): broiled fresh water eel w/sweet BBQ. The menu says BBQ but the sauce is the Japanese sweet soy-based sauce you usually find in eel rice bowls. The eel is soft and good but nothing special.
GRADE: B+

Takana ($2.99): spicy pickled mustard greens sautéed in sesame oil with sesame seeds. I love pickled mustard greens. 
GRADE: A+++++++
author: Irene K.

description: I live all the way from peninsula but I usually come here just to get an Onigilly. I recommend everything, from spicy shrimp to teriyaki chicken, snow crab, and them best of all was the miso soup! Awesome food guys!
author: Deo I.

description:
Love love love this place! They're quick, delicious, hot or cold.. I wish it was open later but totally understand and see why they don't need to be. I just don't get off work until 5-7pm and would love them for a snack option. 

Been here 2-3 times now, have walked past so many times I finally found the times to get here and pick up a snack on my way back to work after a lunch stroll or getting errands done. Love love
author: Stephanie A.

description:
Went here and tried a bunch of the vegan onigiri. I'll probably get the Takana (mustard greens), Teriyaki Tofu and Renkon (lotus root) ones when I come back.

The shiitake one was okay but I wasn't really a fan of the miso nasu (fried eggplant) and the hijiki (seaweed + carrot). Also tried the seaweed salad, which was well flavored, but way too small for $3.50, especially compared to the prices for the onigiri. The edamame were served cold and weren't so great.

It's nice that the options here are fairly healthy (only brown rice) and that the vegan options are well labelled. The location was also pretty clean. Unfortunately all of the Onigilly locations only open from 11-4 Monday through Friday, so I probably won't have the chance to come back anytime soon. It's too bad they don't have normal weekend hours :(.
author: Josh B.

description:
This place is awesome! It's basically brown rice seaweed wrap but they add enough filling and sauce so the entire thing is juicy and flavored, nothing like those you can get from mitsuwa.

I love the way they make this making process into a fun fast food like assembly while it's still super healthy and interesting to watch!
author: Micco W.

description:
Onigiri here is disgusting compared to Onigiri from Japan, even those you get at a 7/11 in Japan is way better than this. Maybe that's why they call it "Onigilly" because it's not onigiri at all.

Rice is bland, filling is disgusting (I had ume, salmon, and crab). Stay away, real onigiri is delicious, this is not.
author: Davis W.

description:
This review is for the " Izakaya Happy Hour" menu Mon-Fri 4-8pm.

Items here that are good, are really tasty. Items that are not good, are really horrible. 4 stars if you order the right items.

I would recommend:
Beets Salad - pleasant surprise. simple dish but very good!
Tofu Noodle Soup - the noodles are made from tofu, really chewy and delicious! Don't need to worry about soggy noodles here!
Age Takoyaki - de-freaking-licious! it doesn't have that many octopus but it is so good
Karaage - normal, good, karaage chicken over a bed of greens. squeeze that lemon!
Agedashi Mochi - very interesting, first time trying fried mochi. very sticky but it's something you should try
Agedashi Tofu - good.
Ii Dako - grilled nicely, nice marinade
Fried Asparagus - gooooood. a bit oily.
Kaki Fry - crispy outside, gooey inside, yum

I would NOT recommend:
Steamed Clams - IPA was not reduced, almost inedible
Yaki Onigilly - was so excited for this, it was way too salty but no flavor
author: Jessica L.

description:
Onigilly is like walking into someone's small, steamy kitchen, getting a hug from whoever lives there, and being served simple, quality ingredients that warm your soul on a rainy day. There is a large variety of options all with that cohesive theme. The staff is super welcoming and really helpful if you don't know about onigilly or how to navigate their menu.

You can stuff your face or get something small and satisfying. Definitely making this a regular spot during my hectic work week.
author: Loe L.

description: This a great fast lunch is this area of town.  The onigilly concept is pretty simple, rice with tasty, highly flavored fillings.  Easy to eat, not messy and filling!  Perfect.  There is plenty of vegetarian options, as well as some great meant ones.  I must admit I am partial to sour plum.
author: Victoria N.

description:
I really wanted to like this place... and onigiri in general. it was my first time trying both. The people at Onigilly are so dear and nice. I feel bad even thinking about this less-than-five-stars review.

I ordered three assorted types. I can't even remember the other two but one was the tuna salad one. They arrived so cute and compact. Again, really wanted to LOVE these little things. However maybe I ordered wrong. The tuna one just kind of turned my stomach. It was warm, mayonnaise-y based, and super-fishy smelling. I just did not like it. No flavor to speak of other than canned tunafish.

Can't recall the others but they were equally unimpressive.

I worked across the street for about 3 years and even with the lack of good sit-down lunch spots, I never went back.

I would try onigiri somewhere else (Tokyo?) but as for this establishment, I won't be returning.
author: Emily C.

description:
Onigilly is definitely a great example of the paradox of choice. With so many potential combinations of fillings to stuff into triangular seaweed-wrapped rice balls (or a noodle salad or a rice plate or a bowl of noodle soup), we were honestly paralyzed by the decision in the beginning. Thankfully we came slightly after lunchtime so we weren't holding up the line. 

In the end, we both decided on a preset lunch suggestion. "Try set C!" they said and so we did - the seafood classic (noodle salad). Overall I enjoyed the flavors but found several ingredients to be extraneous. The hijiki and the pickles provide a nice counterpoint to the tuna salad and spicy shrimp and when combined with the greens and light dressing, worked very well together. I just found the noodles and the plain onigilly to be out of place in the dish - total afterthought. 

Not a bad stop for lunch but Kearny is a competitive street for lunchtime FiDi eats. The flavors of Onigilly remind me of Delica - one of my ferry building faves. If I don't have time to head over there, I might be back to Onigilly again and hopefully have a better grasp on the menu then.
author: Jon L.

description: I liked this place before but that has changed from a recent visit. The guy behind the counter was wrapping the order, in the middle of it, he picked up the phone and helped the lady at the cash register with the glove on. He didn't put a new glove on afterward and continue the order. That was gross and  not sanitary.
author: anita s.

description: Needed a small snack to hold me over until dinner and heard about this place so decided to check it out. Small place but made for convenience for sure. You can order and pay ahead of time online and you can call in orders. Simple menu with veggie, meat, and seafood choices. Tried the snow crab and unagi and both were tasty and just the right amount for us not to be hungry but not too full for dinner!
author: Esther S.

description:
I would recommend studying how the menu works before popping into this sushi cafe.  If you don't know the system, you will get anxiety from trying to figure out how to order.  The stress of seeing the line form behind you will put you into panic mode.  That's what happened to me.  Since I didn't know what to do, I impulse ordered the set combo deluxe seafood meal.  Whew... Stress relief.

So, I got a seat, waited less than 5 minutes and they called my order out.  I picked up my bowl from the counter and got my utensils and water from the utensils and water table.  I was pleasantly surprised that everything tasted fresh and yumsie.  The crab was REAL, the unagi was warm, and the shrimp tempura was still crunchy.  They threw all this on top of brown rice made to perfection.  And as a bonus, there was a small gourmet salad on side, edemame and ginger.  I quite enjoyed my bowl of deconstructed sushi.

I'll def be back.  But this time, I know what to do and won't sweat over the ordering process.
author: Jenny T.

description: Visited this place on a Thursday afternoon. First time here and I chose to try something subtle. Decided on the salmon and snow crab (real crab meat!) Filling was flavorful and the cooks were not skimpy. Line gets long during lunch hours but the cooks were quick.
author: Diana L.

description:
The assembly line concept for choosing your grub is becoming something of a trend these days. It's a great concept for sure, one that brings the goodness of ethnic cuisines into the hands of office-goers who are looking to grab a quick lunch. I'm glad that Onigilly has applied that concept to Japanese food. 

The crowd favorite seems to be Onigiri (indeed, most of my friends ordered that) - Japanese rice-balls sandwiching a filling of your choice wrapped in seaweed and presented in a cute triangular form. The standard Onigiri fare comes with three such rice-balls. 

I went with their rice bowl instead, which is basically a lot of rice (and I mean A LOT!) and an assorted selection of veggies and tofu, and some greens stuffed in the gaps. Unlike the Onigiri's presentation, the rice bowl's presentation wasn't anywhere near as cute, but probably a lot more filling. They have about 6 different options for vegetarian sides/filling, but most of them are variants of Tofu, Mushroom and Seaweed. My 3-star rating of this business might not be fully representative because it comes from a vegetarian who dislikes seaweed. And so I wasn't a big fan of the food, given that everything tasted like seaweed. But I can imagine why someone who likes Japanese food flavors might enjoy coming here.
author: Srivatsan S.

description:
I got the miso soup lunch with two onigiris.  The miso soup was full of seaweed.  The Hijiki onigiri was good but a bit soggy.  I also had the soboro onigiri.   

The homemade ichigo daifuku was awesome!!

a bit expensive for rice and fillings.  but worth a try
author: claudia y.

description:
This is pretty much my favorite lunch spot. It's so fun to make a lunch by mixing and matching 2-3 onigilly(ies?). You don't think it -- but they are quite filling.

I loved eating onigiri in Japan so was very happy to see the fusion take on it back in SF.

My favorite is definitely the snow crab and the spicy bacon. I highly recommend the chicken karage as well if you can eat that much food.

I JUST finished my punch card and can't wait to cash it in :D
author: Kendra W.

description:
Onigilly is one of those places I'd never had the chance to try since they cater to the Fidi lunch crowd and close down early.  So while in the area last week, I finally sure to drop by for a quick solo meal, and was really happy with everything I'd tried.  

Miso soup seems to  be made from scratch, with my small cup containing seaweed, tofu and even a whole shitake mushroom.  Both onigiri (snow crab and miso tuna) were tasty and filling, especially with a generous amount of chilli pepper powder sprinkled on top.  The green tea and cold barley tea (both free) were also really nice.  

Now I just wish I worked closer so I could come by more often!
author: Joanne G.

description:
This was my first time trying Onigilly & I was pretty impressed! 

I love their concept - Japanese "fast food". 
Their Onigilly sets are an incredibly great deal. 
You get to choose any 3 for $9. 
They have veggie, meat & seafood options. 
On their own, each Onigilly ranges anywhere between $2-$4. 
My coworker got a bowl & it looked pretty damn good too. 

Overall, I love having a unique, somewhat healthy, & affordable option in the FiDi.
author: Sylvia N.

description:
Tucked in FiDi area, can be packed during lunch hour

I have been meaning to try this place and finally found time to do so.  It is a small shop with few tables for sit in.

They have a good variety of flavors for vegetarians and meat lovers.

I got six flavor and the total came out to be $16, not bad but a little bit pricey.

Some of them were plain and boring and tasted blah...i think my favorite was the one with bacon....and that was just creamy with bacon so it had to be good.

Overall....i had better
author: Laurie W.

description:
Had the Edamame Special. Really good. Three onigiri were technically too many. I could have been happy with two.

Well presented, tasty (if a bit too much rice). Price was acceptable.
author: Marty R.

description: This place is AWESOME! I ordered a combo, which comes standard with edamame, japanese pickles, and your choice of 3 onigiri. I tend to like the salmon, crab meat, and cod roe. Definitely a seafood fan here, but they also offer meat and veggie options too. Don't forget to try their matcha lemonade.....delicious!
author: Chase B.

description: I will defiantly be coming back here every time I am in financial district, the prices are stupid cheap and food is great quality! I ate the chicken onigilly.
author: Vincent G.

description:
Always a line out the door when I walk past it so I followed this wayward path and decided to eat here with my fellow lamb sister. There's a long line during lunch rush hour, but it dies down a little closer to 1 PM. Even then, shouldn't be THAT long of a wait. Waited 5-10 min. for our food at 1:30 PM. The vegetarian options I chose far surpass the meat filled rice balls~~ 

VEG:
Miso Nasu $3.22: eggplant in dark miso with sesame seeds and green onion // warm onigiri was filled with (I think) intentionally cold eggplant filling with a taste reminiscent of zha jjang mian (black bean noodles). Is so good & the best & such delight much delight. The rice to filling ratio is pretty great. The rice is a tad stickier, but still good! The togorashi is in squeeze bottles on the side of the restaurant so fill up paper cups with your preferred amount of spice and bring back to your table~

Takana $2.99: pickled mustard greens sautéed in sesame oil with sesame seeds // YUM! I love mustard greens i do 

MEAT:
Soboro $2.76: ginger honey braised ground beef // As a lover of all things beef, I was beckoned by this ground beef filled ball only to have my hopes and dreams dashed! tarnished! unwittingly disappointed! Some have said that the meat filling was too sweet but no, it was too salty -- also very one note. But if someone bought it for me, I'd probably eat it. 

Unagi $3.22: braised fresh water eel with BBQ sauce. Tastes like normal bbq eel? Nothing too special, but if you like to order eel sushi rolls that are often glazed with sweet teriyaki, I'm sure you'll find this satisfying~
author: Iris K.

description:
I finally got to try this place and it was so worthwhile. We got two rice bowls and one of their new offerings: the strawberry mochi. While their rice bowls were quite delicious, I was more in awe of their mochi. It's made fresh daily and their staff was thoughtful enough to warn us against refrigerating the mochi. The mochi is the perfect texture and sweet red bean to strawberry to mochi ratio was just right. I only regret not having the foresight to order more. I think this is a wonderful addition to their menu and will definitely be back for more. 

I work in Palo Alto and live in San Jose so it was a rare treat that I was in SF on a weekday for lunch. Please could you guys open on a weekend day, maybe once in a while?? Better yet, please consider opening another location closer to the South Bay!
author: Maggie L.

description:
So, I've had my fair shares of Onigilly restaurants. I have one near my office and discovered this restaurant in the Embarcadero location. I've got to say, this location is the best out of all the of them! 

To be completely honest, this was the only place where they made their rice in a way that it wasn't a soft mooshy mess. Other branches would always make their rice soggy, but this location, it wasn't super hard nor was is super soft. It was perfect. It reminded me of eating onigiris in Japan (which are always fresh at the local 7-11). Now, for these branches, even though the rice is perfecto, I have to gripe about the seaweed. I think I was just spoiled in Japan (duh) but the seaweed is chewy. Now, at this location, it isn't as chewy as others but still, it's not fresh. I just wish they found a way to open those packets of seaweeds and just keep it fresh. Maybe use a green bag? Who knows. But, if I ever want onigiris, I think I'm going to come to this location even though it's further. That's how good it is compared to the other two =P.
author: Denise L.

description:
With the generous amount of filling, it's made more like a sandwich with the bread slices substituted with triangular chunks of rice than an onigiri XD But it was really good lunch food.

Had the edamame set that comes with 3 onigiris. The fillings I chose were teriyaki chicken, miso tuna and eel. All 3 were delicious, especially the eel one (even more so after sprinkled with shichimi spices). The volume looked a bit small at first, but turned out to be perfect as I didn't feel hungry the entire afternoon. Definitely coming back later to try out some of the fancier flavors.
author: Da W.

description:
This place is tiny, and it takes some time to look through their entire menu. Take too long being indecisive, and you'll find yourself moving over for the line forming rapidly behind you. Except there isn't much room for you to stand and browse, because again, it's TINY which can get pretty frustrating. 

I got the onigiri set - 3 for $10. Tuna, salmon, and some sort of ground beef. Also made another separate order later for an unagi onigiri. Of the four, I liked the salmon and unagi the best. The tuna one honestly tasted like a tuna sandwich to me but with rice and nori instead. 

Overall, I thought the fillings were too salty and the rice lacked flavor. It just didn't taste as good as I expected. Also, the nori was soggy, and not crispy like other onigiri's I've had. The service was good and they get their food out pretty fast.

Glad I tried this place but in no rush to make another visit.
author: Lena L.

description:
Healthy, affordable, and fast! Can't think of anything better for lunch.

My favorite is the spicy shrimp onigiri and their fresh made strawberry mochi. They are the two that you have to try! 

We came here during lunch hour. Although the line wasn't short, the staff were every efficient and made the line moving quite fast. If you want to grab something fast but delicious and healthy, this is where you should go.
author: Wen S.

description: Great for a quick bite! Hit this place up today for lunch, miraculously managed to step in right before the line formed. Got the Edamame combo with the unagi, snow crab, and salmon. It was delicious, fairly cheap, and I was happily full afterwards.
author: Ava H.

description:
This place is absolutely awesome! I actually stumbled upon it while looking for sushirrito but this place dishes out nice comforting food quickly and for a reasonable price. 

Onigiri is like a hand roll but shaped into a triangle and here at Onigilly they have plenty of options for toppings. I got the onigiri set which is three onirigi of your choice along with some edamame and pickled daikon radish. I chose the unagi(eel), miso tuna, and the spicy bacon. The miso tuna was decent but didn't blow me away, it tasted almost like a normal tuna salad would, the unagi however was nice and flavorful, and finally the spicy bacon was surprisingly delicious.

The idea behind this restaurant is quite simple but also very clever and they execute their craft quite well, I plan on coming back to try their other flavors soon!
author: Zach C.

description:
I ordered the combo that comes with three rice "balls," pickles, and edamame. I also added on a side of wakame salad.

The beef and unagi rice balls were ok, although altogether too laden with their respective sauces. The shrimp tempura rice ball was my favorite, because, you know, it's tempura... :)

The wakame salad was THE BEST; it totally redeemed the meal. Also the pickles rocked, and there was unlimited, free chilled barley tea (which also rocked). The edamame, on the other hand, really didn't taste like anything.

Final impressions: As another reviewer mentioned, I really wanted to love this place but came away disappointed. They seriously need to work on their fillings. After another visual inspection, I realized that all the non-vegetarian ones looked about as saucy as Subway's tuna salad. I might be back to try the lotus rice ball, but realistically, there's so much other non-Americanized/non-McDonald's-ized Japanese in SF.
author: Lane B.

description:
This is a great spot to grab some lunch. The onigiri is fresh and delicious! I came here recently to try it out with some coworkers. The line moves quickly and the orders are made in no time.

At Onigilly, you can order one of many different set deals. I opted to go for a set of three onigiri with the soboro (ginger-honey braised ground beef), a special with some sort of smoked salmon, and another special with braised mushrooms. I really enjoyed the smoked salmon and the mushroom ones, but was less of a fan of the soboro one.

Just this week, I ordered the special set that they had with spicy bacon, spicy shrimp, and hijiki (braised seaweed and carrots) in a rice bowl and a side of miso soup, all for less than $10! When you order the rice bowl, they have a bed of rice, with three "fillings" that get put on top and some sprinkled nori. They also give you a healthy amount of mixed greens for a side salad, edamame, and some pickled radish. The sweet braised veggies were great with the spicy, salty bacon and shrimp.

This is starting to become one of my favorite spots on Kearny.
author: Vivian L.

description: Returned to SF and the financial district after many years in the east bay, and the food situation is breaking my heart. I'm sorry, I don't want to pay over $10 for lunch, like, ever! Luckily, I found this amazing spot! Tasty, fast, affordable, just plain perfect lunch spot.
author: Bethany H.

description:
Had a meeting at the BOA Center and only had time for a ninja snack before heading on to my next destination. Walked down the street and around the corner to find this adorable (and tiny) place called Onigilly! Quality fast food for those of us who want a quick & light lunch. 

You can purchase your onigiri a la carte but I went with the Miso Soup set ( 2 balls + 1 miso soup ). It came out a little over $7 before tip. It reminded me of mornings at Mitsuwa. Perfectly shaped BROWN-RICE BASED onigiri with fillings like Hijiki ( seasoned seaweed + carrots ) & Unagi ( eel ). I wanted to dive into the snow crab but I couldn't handle any more food. T_T

For onigiri, it's a little on the pricy-side but considering the location, quality of ingredients, filling selection (VEGAN FRIENDLY), and top notch customer service, it's worth it. If I'm ever in the area, I will be sure to make a ninja stop at Onigilly.
author: Yuhi K.

description: Great place!! I order the edamame set and was so full afterwards!! Highly recommend Onigilly!!
author: Arian I.

description: I love this place! But I think some of their menu items have flavors that can be a bit overwhelming. I also have no idea if they are traditional or fusion. My favorite onigilly are the crab and shrimp. And I think the miso set is a great value. Looking forward to trying the soba!
author: Heena K.

description:
I was pretty impressed with this place for a quick lunch option. I came before noon so there was no line and I can't speak to his crazy it gets during peak lunch hours. 

The salted plum is fantastic if you like the sourness of ume. A bit saltier than most ume onigiri but I love the intense sourness and saltiness. Big flavor, go big or go home. 5/5

The spicy bacon is exactly what it sounds like. A bit of heat with bacon (the meaty kind not the fatty kind). I enjoyed this one immensely also. 5/5

The braised ground beef was flavorful and tasty. You could really taste the ginger-honey. 4/5

The snow crab one is basically a California roll in a rice ball. I was hoping it would focus more on the crab, and I couldn't taste the lemon aioli. 3.5/5

The miso tuna sounded interesting but ended up being just a can of Chicken of the Sea in a rice ball. Just tasted like basic supermarket canned tuna which isn't awful I suppose. 2.5/5

The fermented soybean was my experiment for this meal. I couldn't handle it but to each his own. I personally just don't like that flavor.

Overall it's a nice light lunch, about $10 for 3 rice balls that you can also combo with Edamame or seaweed salad. Not the most filling (I had 5 of them and I was satisfies but still not full) but that doesn't mean it's not a good meal! Would definitely come again to get my favorites and try the many other flavors.
author: Kevin T.

description:
Love this place. Always stop by when I'm in this area of SF and I want a quick bite to eat but am not up for trying anything new. I'm a big meat connoisseur and I also eat my fair share of sushi, so its nice that they have a little something for everyone. Including you vegans and gluten free people too.
The Edamame Set w/ a side of Wakame salad (not pictured) is the best way to experience Onigilly but you have to get there close to the time they open (11:00am) because they run out of wakame salad fast.
Anyways! Definitely would recommend trying out this place at least once if you find yourself in the area. 

(From top to bottom) teriyaki tofu, snow crab, and salmon. The unagi is also a must try.
author: Jaclyn M.

description:
Unagi!! Get the Ungai! Their Tuna is good too but GET THE UNAGAI! LOL 

This place is good but I have to get around four to five rice balls to be full. The price can add up..
author: John L.

description: Very cheap for SF. Not high grade sashimi by a long shot, but $3 for a Onigilly, you can't go wrong. Personally, I'd prefer them offering a more expensive version with more fish, less rice.
author: Tuan V.

description: Was at Plentea and saw this spot with a line out the door. Decided to try some. I love the concept of a lunch spot that specializes in just onigiri. I haven't had that many in the past, but these ones were pretty good! If I worked nearby, I would totally get lunch here often! Sometimes onigiris have too high of a rice to filling ratio. This one was not too bad. The salmon one and mushroom (maybe?) were good. The crab was a bit hefty bc it has mayo in it. I think they were about $3.50-$4 for one.
author: Kathleen C.

description: So so good! I had the salmon and bacon onigilly and they were both delicious and filling! My favorite was definitely the bacon. I had a side of karaage which was equally delicious. The service was friendly and the lines moved fast! Great option for lunch in the Fidi.
author: Samantha S.

description:
Food: 2 stars
+1 for convenience, speed, and friendly workers.

Rice to filling ratio is too high. Filling itself is not bad, but just waaaaaay too much rice where your mouth gets dry and there's just too much chewing involved. 2 made me full though. [I had the shrimp and the shiitake mushroom ones)

Otherwise, it's a quick and fairly healthy option for lunch on Kearny, there always seems to be a line but I'd much rather go to Sushiritto if I want my quick Japanese fix.
author: Emily C.

description: Fresh. Organic. Great price. & super great customer service. That's all that you need to know.
author: Melinda W.

description:
I liked my lunch at Onigilly but am pretty sure with a few ordering modifications I might've loved it. The restaurant specializes in onigiri - triangular shaped rice balls wrapped in seaweed.

I ordered the miso soup set which comes with a choice of two onigilly and picked tempura shrimp and shiitake. I really enjoyed the tempura shrimp but found the shiitake too sweet (I'm guessing that's due to the agave soy braise).

Definitely pay attention to the seasonal fillings - as I spent more time looking at the menu I saw that I could've replaced the cloying shiitake with kabocha squash!
author: Miriam W.

description:
I love edamame. I don't like salty food. 

That being said, I had to downgrade them a star because they were out of edamame and failed to let me know, thus I feel jipped. They were cooking a bunch when I was leaving...and my bowl is edamame-less. AND, all the toppings are pretty salty. 

Went out for a late lunch and picked up a rice bowl...tip...you can customize your own and don't have to stick to the three that they have. I went with: hijiki, spicy shrimp and saboro (ginger soy beef). The portion is large and they are generous with their portions, but don't be deceived, half the bowl is just salad. 

I get it, the toppings are probably overly salty because if you do get an onigilly, it needs to compensate for the rice, but still...salty. And if you're not a fan of mayo, I would probably stear clear of anything with mayo mixed in...because it's pretty heavy. 

Overall, a good lunch option in the FiDi, just choose your toppings carefully and make sure there is edamame. It'll make
author: Annie S.

description:
Stumbled across this place as I was walking around the area after an interview. The interior of the little shop is clean and modern and very cute. Wood with green accents. 

They have a selection of dishes in addition to the onigiri. They have miso soup, edamame, rice bowls, chicken karate etc. they have an extensive selection of onigiri (basically rice wrapped with seaweed with a filling). It was hard to choose but I ended up trying: miso tuna salad, spicy shrimp, and the snow crab.

The miso tuna salad was amazing! It is very standard filling and the flavors go so well with the seaweed. A must try! The snow crab was also good but the crab tasted a bit fishy (salt water) so it was a tiny bit unpleasant the first bite but it got better as I ate. The third one I tried was the spicy shrimp and it was really good but in my opinion a little too saucy (the sauce was runny). Would've liked a thicker sauce. 

I can't wait to come back and try the tempura shrimp and salmon one. I heard the pollock roe one is also amazing! I came here 10 mins before closing and they ran out of a lot of the fillings so id come sooner next time! Such a great find!

All onigiris are approximately $2.50-$3.50 each. Decently priced.
author: Isabella L.

description:
Great place to get a light lunch for much cheaper compared to the $12 salad places that dominate this area. Conversely, if you're hungrier, you can order more onigiri or a rice plate for a hefty carb and protein filled meal. 

For $6.25 I got the miso tuna and the mustard greens onigiri. the filling is sandwiched between two triangles of warm mixed white and brown rice wrapped in a piece of seaweed. I preferred the mustard greens because of the sesame scented flavor. The miso salmon tasted a little too much like canned tuna salad for me.

Overall, food was satisfying,  fairly cheap, and the service was friendly. Solid lunch spot.
author: Kailin L.

description:
The meal is so cutely made, it's hard not too like it before taking your first bite. :)

MUST TRY THE CRAB ONIGILLY! Super yummy! I would love the salmon if it was raw, but it it's cooked so it felt a little dry compared to the crab onigilly. 


I got the two onigilly and miso combo which came out to be around $8. I was pretty full after that meal, so definitely not the cheapest meal but it's filling! 

ENVIRONMENT
it's a small restaurant that seats about 15 people, but there is never a line for a seat since people usually take this to-go. 
It's clean and nicely decorated. The guy working the cash register is super friendly! 

The food comes less than 5 minutes after ordering! The line outside may seem long, but it goes by so quickly because people are just grabbing their food then leaving!
author: Sabrina L.

description: The girl at the register was great and helpful. I had three Onigily. The spicy shrimp was tasty, but a little salty. The beef was too over flavoring for my taste. The salmon was plan. I would like to try other menu items.
author: Nina M.

description: So good and yummy. If you are a fan of this kind of fish, you won't be disappointed. Really Hit the spot. Service is friendly. Good prices that won't kill your wallet too.
author: John G.

description:
I used to be a regular at Onigilly's pop up cart at the Civic Center Farmer's Market. Their seaweed wrapped brown rice balls were fantastic and I loved the assortment of fillings that each one had.

I finally had a chance to check out their permanent location today. Their staff were extremely friendly and it was evident that they're still very excited about making sure that they deliver top-quality products in their new space. 

I had the rice bowl - which included their local brown rice, salad, as well my choice of three toppings. The toppings range from a variety of meats, pickled vegetables, tofu toppings, and much more. It also comes with a light dressing - which adorns the salad and rice beautifully. I also had extra avocado on top of it.

I thoroughly enjoyed my rice bowl and while I wish it had a bit more greens on it - I was impressed by the toppings and loved how hearty the dish ended up being as well.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description: Curious about this place.  I walled by this place after getting my soup.  The menu caught my eye and prompted my to go in.  I asked the cashier his recommendation.  He's more of a seafood so his recommendation came to waste.  It's a snack alternative to sushi.  Basically it's a large sushi with added toppings.  They have traditional toppings such as salmon to the exotic spicy bacon...Lol.  I tried the spicy bacon.  The bacon is really spicy with a touch of sweet cured brown sugar.  It's a good snack with a friendly staff to make it enjoyable.  If you need like one sushi to snack on... This is the place, SON
author: Chris P.

description:
I always walk by this place to and from work.  Grabbed some lunch here yesterday. I ordered a variety of onigilly's. Yes, they're only about $2-3 bucks a piece, but when you buy 12, it can be pretty costly.  It's kinda like sushi, but made on brown dry hard rice.  My coworkers got the rice bowls and they said it was quite filling.  

Pros: 
- Credit Cards
- Discount Cards available (but i didnt get one)
- Order online

Cons:
- kinda bland
author: Stephanie Y.

description: Want a quick yummy lunch? Onigilly definitely hits the spot! I got the miso soup set with a snowcrab onigiri and an unagi onigiri. Both were delicious, but snowcrab was def my fave! The miso soup was light and ok. Not the best, but it's cleansing. Seating can get tricky since it's a small spot, but people come and go rather quickly. Service was fast and friendly!
author: Wendy S.

description:
My go to place for a quick, light lunch in FiDi. I usually get the miso soup set to combat the year-round chilly-ness that is SF. I also like to eat there so I can take advantage of the complimentary barley tea. 

The food is definitely on the pricey side from a cost to volume perspective, and I've tried a number of the different flavors and some are definitely better than others. I've settled on a few as my favorites, namely the torako (pollock roe) and snow crab.

I'm very happy this place exists!
author: Willy W.

description:
What a healthy lunch meal!  They have delectable Onigiri fillings to choose from and I got their Soboro, which is their ginger, honey, soy braised ground angus beef and Mentaiko, spicy bacon.  

The meal comes with 2 Onigiri and they serve it with a side salad.  Their meat was very flavorful and nicely marinated in their signature sauce.  The meal was clean, in good proportions, fresh, healthy and you don't feel heavy afterwards.  

No food coma happening here after eating their delectable Onigiri. 

Mini place that offers a seating area downstairs and upstairs.
author: Tiffany D.

description: 3 words: speedy, delicious, and friendly. Not only did the food arrive in a timely manner, the cashier was also extremely friendly and helpful. The tuna salad was a really well-done classic, spicy bacon was definitely something worth a try and the soboro was yummy as well. Would definitely recommend to people who want to grab a quick bite!
author: Michael C.

description: I had the chance to try Onigilly when my husband was in town for the VMware conference. I ordered the bowl with unagi, tanaka, and snow crab. They accidentally subbed the snow crab for ground beef which is ok because everything was delicious!!! My only wish is that they open a branch in LA! Will definitely be back next time we're in town.
author: Diana M.

description: This is a great little lunch or snack place on Kearny in the heart of FiDi.
author: Evan Z.

description:
I stopped by here with my friend after we had lunch in downtown. I tried their unagi and chicken teriyaki and my friend tried their spicy shrimp and snow crab . After trying all four of them this was what  I thought taste the best. 

1. Unagi was the best one  [5/5] 
2.Snow crab[4/5] 
3. Chicken teriyaki [3/5]
4. Spicy shrimp [3/5]

But this place is pretty cool, I would definitely go back to try the other flavors!
author: Sophia L.

description: Today, I had the tofu noodle soup (miso soup with lots of soft fresh noodles, vegetables and tofu) -- note to self: order this again for warm comfort food in just the right proportion.
author: Maile N.

description: Fast, healthy, and delicious. Perfect for those who need to grab a quick lunch in financial district. It's a small place, so there's not much room to sit--best to grab and go!
author: Yanni L.

description: I've tried other omosubi's? (I'm not too sure on spelling) before, but this has to be my favorite so far. They have a wide selection from veggie, meat, to seafood. The meat or veggie option you choose isn't skippy either, they pack it in their and it tastes good. You get the quality you pay for here. They range from $2-3 or you can get the set that's 3 for $10 and it comes with edamame. Only downfall is that they're closed on the weekends.
author: Alyssa M.

description:
I literally to this onigiri shop from work and a sweet employee lets me in at the last 3 minutes before closing! Whew! It was my first time trying it out! 
The man was patient and friendly with my orders, he helped me reccomend the items that were available at the moment. I love how the staff's vibe is so welcoming and cheerful! 

I ordered 6 onigiri:
Snow crab
Miso tuna
Spicy tuna
Spicy bacon
Teriyaki chicken
Miso Nasu

I definitely LOVE SNOW CRAB!! You MUST try one if it's your first time here. I wanted unagi and salmon but it ran out--they're really popular here. My boyfriend agrees along with terayaki chicken. I'm going to come back for unagi, salmon, snow crab, and teryaki chicken next time!
author: Jackie T.

description: We couldn't decide what to get so we went with the rice bowl with choice of three toppings - everything was delicious!!
author: Xuan Hong L.

description:
This is a tribute to my favorite cashier in FiDi.
