Jumpman, jumpman, jumpman, ball, ball, ball. Pronounced oh-NEE-ghee-lee, similar to Gilly on Game of Thrones with a hard "G", as opposed to a soft "G" which would sound like "Jill-y". Rice balls for days son. Heirloom Kokuho Rose organic, partially milled brown rice from Koda Farms, packing heat with the variety from soboro ginger-honey braised ground beef to tarako baked pollock roe aioli spread. Reasonably priced at around $3 each, variety is the spice of life, threesome every time my man. Just a personal preference, my favorites are tarako, snow crab, and unagi. I strongly suggest trying out all them selections as they are all rather different in flavors and texture. 

Lunch time hustling, in the street of FiDi. An occasional who comes upon the man may wonder idly who he was, but seldom pursues this curiosity beyond a casual question. This man as many had accustomed to behind the counter is the cashier, a bandana tied firmly to his forehead during lunch hours, channeling the same ferocity as mythical momotaro riding into battle. In the busiest of hour, in the diversity of downtown, it's not that hard to spot him. One might even notice him with xenophobic eyes, as the only white guy working the line. The white guy with glasses? More than that, he notices your confusion as you stare at the blackboard, every single order, his service unwavering and never falter. His mouth steadfast with suggestions, yet tone soft with resolution. His gestures animated, yet controlled like an artisan that mastered his craft. Keith Haring in the flesh. One might question the validity of being a cashier as an art form, as similarly stances have been taken in regards to performance art, rest assure he doesn't do it for the fame, the limelight, the pay, merely a person with character playing a character.  However trivial, there is no debate about the significant an extraordinary cashier brings to the table on a daily basis for a business. 

There are four different Onigilly locations, he is the reason I frequent this one. With all that said, it is with great sadness that I must say in my last two visits he has not been seen. I can only assume the worst and hope he found his true calling in life and that he has moved on to better things instead of dealing with the hoi polloi.
author: Roy C.

description:
I keep meaning to update my review. I love this place and I really don't think I have encountered better customer service in the area. 

I will continue returning to this location. :)
author: Tiffany F.

description: Presentation looks amazing. If onigilly met sushirito they'd be great. But they don't offer fresh fish and wondering if the cooked stuff is as good of quality. Hasn't sat well since lunch so don't think I can make the voyage back. I did note the fried chicken bites looked good, but not what I ordered ;)
author: Andrew S.

description: Food is great!  Nice change from the typical lunch.  Warm rice, great flavors, reasonable price and very filling.  Definitely recommend it.  The interior decoration leaves a lot to be desired but I think most people take it to go.
author: Nelson W.

description: Super cute place and super cute food! I got the miso soup combo with spicy bacon and spicy shrimp rice balls. And wow! Flavour explosion.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
Mmmmm, my new favorite lunch spot! The perfect place to satisfy your Japanese/sushi cravings without the heaviness of a bento box. 

I came here the other day with my bestie. She tried the salad bowl with a choice of 3 toppings and I had the rice bowl with a choice of 3 toppings. Each came with a side of salad greens, edamame, and pickles. 

The standouts were the snow crab, soboro, and tarako. Note about the tarako: it's on the salty side, but the saltiness is a great contrast to the sweet soboro and the creaminess of the snow crab. The unagi, spicy shrimp, and pickled mustard greens were also pretty good. 

Much, much better than Sushiritto, which I think is overpriced and overhyped. Definitely getting added into my regular rotation of lunch spots!
author: Monelle A.

description:
Really nice place for lunch if you want to try something which tastes good and doesn't have too many spices & oil. Being vegetarian I get wide variety of selection at Onigilly. They always have 6-8 options for Veg lovers and they change based on season.

At Onigilly you might have to wait for 15-20 minutes if you go during rush hours but still I would prefer this place over several other Bento Box places on Kearny Street as you get fresh food unlike at other places where you pick the ready-made box for instant buy.

They also have few seating options although its mostly occupied.
author: Jay M.

description:
Simple, quick, and priced like everything else in FiDi. 

I stopped by with a coworker on our lunch break, and we went with a two onigiri combo for ~$7 each, and a side of chicken karaage. I had to deduct a star for the chicken karaage because the karaage came out barely lukewarm, which to me indicates that it was leftover from an earlier batch and considering we were there right before the noon lunch rush, it's not really best practice. 

I got: 
- Spicy Shrimp: I love spicy food, and find that most spicy doesn't really fit my standards, so I was pleasantly surprised when the "spicy" really gives a kick. Not for the super faint of heart.

- Snow Crab: Tasty, but nothing terribly outstanding as far as flavor goes. Definitely fresh, though.

Coworker got the miso tuna (said it tasted like a tuna salad), and the unagi (said it was good, but a little too much sauce). I ended up getting a tarako to go, and it was definitely my favorite out of everything (on the salty side, though).

Definitely love the concept, and even though it doesn't look like alot of food, two onigiris will make you surprisingly full.
author: Emily Z.

description: Currently in a food coma. So delish!! Got the tuna and salmon onigilly with miso soup. Can't wait to try more varieties!
author: Ali S.

description:
Onigily, yes it can be a tongue twisters, it is pronounced [Oh - KNEE - Ghee - Lee] which is a Japanese handheld sushi that has a filling and wrapped around seaweed. 

This is one of my cousin's wife's place she has to go visit during the food festival. There are different fillings that you could ask for at their restaurant. We ordered their rice Balls that were pretty filling. At their shop, I usually order their unagi, because I really like eel.

Check out my profile to find my official blogs as well as more food reviews
author: Food G.

description: I like their Onigiri so much!!!! I think I can eat it everyday lol. My favourite is Salmon and sanow crab.
author: Orange S.

description: A quick delicious meal with vegan options.  While its plenty flavorful, I wish there was less rice and more veggies in the borderline overly sweet filling of the vegan options.  They also have one with kabocha that I'd like to try, but it isn't vegan :(
author: Wolfe S.

description:
My friend and I were actually killing time as we were on our way to lunch and stumbled upon Onigilly.  We were intrigued to find a onigiri musubi place in SF and decided to try one as a snack.  

The place was a cute, cozy little place and looked promising.  It had an open food prep area so you could see them making the onigiri.  

I had the spicy bacon version and she had the sockeyed salmon version. 
My spicy bacon onigiri musibi was OK.  I think that I just chose a weird topping.  My friend said that her was OK too.

The reason we weren't floored is that they did not use the right rice to make musubi.  It was not sticky enough, so it was kind of falling apart.  If they changed the rice the rating would be higher.
author: Celise N.

description: Ordered the edamame set at around 3:30pm on a Friday. They were out of unagi so I ordered two salmon and one spicy shrimp. I should have ordered all spicy shrimp; it was fantastic. The salmon was ehhhh. I ended up throwing out part of the second one. I also didn't care for the edamame. I think next time I won't get it as part of a set. The pickled stuff was only so-so too, but at least better than the edamame. There were three people ahead of me who had already ordered and were waiting for their food. It took at least 10 minutes minimum before I got mine. Not the greatest if you're in a hurry. Oh, cost of my meal was $11 after tax.
author: Wendy L.

description:
YES, Onigilly is a gem in this city. Who would've thought of a restaurant just for Japanese rice balls! NOT ME, but I do like.

I got the lotus root, and shrimp tempura one. I did like the Shrimp Tempura one more just because it was something familiar to what I've had before. The sauce on the Lotus root was a bit sweet so I wasn't use to that.
author: Joyce M.

description: Can't beat the price! Honestly if I hadn't already eaten 1 and 1/2 sushirittos I most likely would have taken more than one bite. My wife got the unagi and loved it. Said it was flavorful and delicious.
author: Hung L.

description:
Today is the first day of the soft opening.  They will officially open their doors at 11am - 3pm.  Based on their food stand the food here should be very good.  Onigilly is a Japanese Gourmet Rice Balls....usually consist of Rice, Choice of Seafood, Meat or Veggie.  They are wrapped in seaweed.  Samurai use to carry these with them every time they had to venture some distance from home.  Should be very exciting.  Looking forward to it.

Follow the link to check out the menu:

http://onigilly.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2012/08/Onigilly_rest_menu2_rev1.pdf
author: Alan L.

description:
Onigilly is a cute cafe that is best suited for a light bite of healthy and fresh Japanese onigilly.  I think it's important to not have an expectation that you're going to be stuffed after eating here.

I am a light eater at lunch time (typically) and after having two onigilly (1- pork and 1-chicken teriyaki) I was still hungry. Yikes! I wish there were a variety of creative, homemade sauces available for the onigilly, just in case you'd like something other than hot/spicy sauce to dip your onigillys in. I found the pork onigilly to have flavor but was a little bit dry.

Since I didn't do a set meal/rice bowl/salad bowl, I went back to the cashier and ordered a seaweed side salad. This was flavorful and a lovely shade of sea green, the seaweed mound sitting on a few strands of lettuce.

Pricing comes out to about $3.00 per onigilly including tax a la carte. I think the quality of the ingredients and the freshness of product result in this above average cost.

The staff are super polite and are patient!

I like the fact that this business started out as a food cart and has found enough backing to open this shop. If anything else, support this local business and help them grow/improve their business!
author: Joanna T.

description: I think it was fine I just was hoping for sushi being involved and it was definitely Japanese but not quality expected. Ingredients were fresh enough just underwhelming flavors for my tastes
author: Megan E.

description:
Not to make unjust comparisons or anything, but kind of like a Japanese version of Freshroll -- three form factors (onigiri, rice bowl, or noodle salad) with an assortment of "flavors" to choose from.

The bowl is a lot of rice unfortunately. Reducing it to a better-balanced mélange involved some labor on my part: inhaling the undressed salad (mostly a filler) and nibbling away at the edges of the bed of rice till all I had left were the three choice flavors atop a more comfortable mound of rice. The unagi and hijiki seaweed were great choices -- moist and flavorful. The chashu, though, was thin and dry and sat there sort of somberly in the corner of my bowl.

$9.49 for my meal, with the unagi at a 50-cent premium.
author: Alex C.

description:
Wasn't a huge fan of this place. It might be because I'm spoiled by genuine onigiri's in Kyoto...but either way, Onigilly doesn't do the precious rice ball justice!!! SADFACE TO THE MAX.

I love me a good rice ball...and unfortunately, this place does not have my love. Rice to seaweed to topping ratios are way off...super heavy-handed on the rice. :( I get it, it's Fidi, working professionals want to have that quick small but filling bite for lunch between heading back to the grind...but still...$10+? No, thanks.

Went once, probably won't go back again. I'm fine going to a Japanese supermarket to buy some toppings and make my own onigiri's in the comfort of my own home...or I'll binge on onigiri's from Japan.
author: Rachel C.

description:
I'm a fan of Japanese cuisine, so I thought I would try this sushi-cum sandwich outfit. The prices were a bit high, but then again, this is San Francisco, and in the Financial District no less, so the prices were more or less in line with what one might expect to pay for lunch in the area. The staff were friendly, and the cashier hands you back your credit card with two hands,  which I'm told is Japanese custom (they do it at Uniqlo too).

I ordered three of their onigilly: snow crab, salmon, and teriyaki chicken. My friend ordered the miso nasu (eggplant). The eggplant was the tastiest of all; the snow crab and the salmon lacked flavor. 

If you are looking for a unique lunch experience, it's worth a try. A harder sell for more than one return visit.
author: Jason C.

description:
Loved it. A great space, awesome concept, affordable, delicious food. The meat onigilly trio thing with the wasabi cole slaw was a winner! Lots of food!

Reminded me of couture, Japanese version of Chipotle.
author: Andrew K.

description: Onigiri--! yes, they are Japanese traditional food, Onigiri. Their rice is not my favorite but I love their tarako/misonasu/takana. 3 onigiri is $10, good deal.
author: Machiruda Y.

description:
I love this place. I come often for lunch. It's a bit pricey for onigiri, but considering you're in the financial district, I guess it's reasonable.

I usually get the onigilly set and order tarako. I've had the soboro as well. Both are great. They also give you enough filling compared to the amount of rice.

I also like the edamame they give you.

I would come here more often if it were cheaper, but it's still a nice treat every now and then!
author: Ena Y.

description: Very good lunch place. Edamame set gives you a fair amount of food. Excellent customer service.
author: Bryan F.

description:
i had a spicy korean beef onigiri.  
I got it to go... by the time i finished it i wanted to run right back for another one!  yummy tasty spicy and juicy, ahhhh.

i desperately wish they'd open one of these in my hood, or near where i work on the peninsula - but i guess that might be a little dangerous.  I'd be there all the time!
Service was friendly and fast, too.
author: J W.

description:
I am a big fan of the traditional onigiris you can buy anywhere in Japan. I had driven by this place many times but just recently had the chance to go in and try it out. These are a little different in that the fillings are more toppings that come out of the top of the triangle rather than stuck in the middle. You won't miss white rice when you eat the brown rice here, it is very good. I had the yellow daikon pickle one which was good. They messed up my other rice ball so I did not get my konbu one unfortunately.

Interesting place and a good choice for something different.
author: Tricia K.

description:
Great concept in transforming the traditional onigiri with a Westernized twist! I'd say three to four is a good amount of rice in your stomach :-). I ordered the teriyaki tofu (yum!), unagi (yum!), ume/plum (eh...), and their specialty, the miso tuna salad (which tasted just like tuna salad).

I'd love to go back to try some more options - the eggplant sounded fun and who could say no to salmon. Plus they have wakame salad and I loveee wakame salad! :-). Great lunch spot, plus they're next to a milk tea place that's always crowded and has thus piqued my interest!
author: Christina C.

description:
I have been walking past this venue on my way to work and after work and has been wanting to try this for the longest time. Rice balls? Cool! 
  
Its ironic that I found out from my coworker that Onigilly is actually pronounced "Onigiry" with your tongue rolling back by the fourth syllable. 

My boyfriend and I met up for lunch on Thursday around 1PM, holy mother, there is still a line out the door. Luckily, they were nice enough to hand out menus so we can indecisive all we want prior to ordering at the cashier.  
 
They give you three set options for $8.25:
-SET A: Three onigilly which comes with a  side salad and some edamame. 
-SET B: Rice bowl with three toppings. 
-SET C: Salad with three three toppings with tofu noodles. 
 
Also, if you feel like snacking, you can get a onigilly for $2.75. 

Option A please! 
Amongst the 3 ongilly set, you can choose 3 different kinds of meat or the vegetarian option.  

I had the chasu (bbq pork), Bacon (diced into bits), and the soboro (soy braised angus beef that basically tasted like teriyaki).  

I think out of them all, I enjoyed the soboro most as you can never go wrong with teriyaki flavored things. The chasu were in thin slices and the taste was a bit bland for me. The bacon is my second favorite as you can not say no to bacon. 
  
On a last note, I thought the salad was a bit bland as it seems like there were no dressing on my salad. I was right, my bf tasted mine and confirmed that they forgot the dressing. Lame.  
 
Overall, I would give it 3.75 Stars.
author: Becky Q.

description:
What a strange little restaurant. I've eaten onigiri before in Japan, this is definitely a bit of an American take on it. I went here with friends and we all ordered a set of three. 

I feel a bit guilty giving this place three stars. Is it good? Is it bad? I would describe it as a different. As someone who cooks a lot of chicken teriyaki with veggies and rice on my own time, it felt like someone just inverted the dish and served it to me. The taste is very simple (veggie/meat + some rice). Some might say that the point of the dish is the tastefulness through simplicity, but it isn't relying on the same simplicity that makes sashimi tastes good. Braised beef is braised beef and the flavor is contained in the seasoned beef, not the interaction of the rice with the beef. I feel like I would have been more satisfied if I had just gotten gyudon somewhere. 

I wasn't dissatisfied, I just don't think I would come back here. Three stars seems fair.
author: Jake B.

description: Best food in SF. Chef Anthony is amazing guy. Love it. Thank you guys. Keep doing best job
author: Brian T.

description:
Just ok for me. I like the idea of Onigilly, little rice bombs filled with less traditional fillings. Just recently tried Sprogs (http://www.sprogsfresh.com/) and those are a similar idea and quite tasty.

Back to Onigilly....
Each piece ranges from $2.76-3.22. I would say get 2-3 of them to be full, unless you're also getting sides.

I had the spicy shrimp and soboro (ginger honey beef), both were ok but not great. I'd go back and try some of the others just to see if they are better options.
author: Rachel R.

description: Yummy. I really like the simple concept.  I've been an food supporter of Onigilly when they had the street food cart. I'm glad they have 3 outposts now in downtown SF!
author: Jboogie L.

description:
There's a happy hour here?!!! O.O   ZOMG

Anyway, I've had their stuff at OtG food truck/cart.  Which I loved!  I mean, how could you go wrong with brown rice balls with seaweed wrap and stuffed with whatever you want (I love their spicy shrimp!)

Apparently, they offer other stuff, but I've yet to venture outside of the onigilly.  

Prices = reasonable.  $2.75 per onigilly, or get a combo of three with a salad for $8.45.  They do take credit cards when the terminal isn't down. 

Service = friendly!

Seating = limited.  Do take out.  You won't be disappointed!

I'm so glad that this opened near my work... although, my wallet isn't going to be happy about it.   XD
author: Fannie S.

description:
This place really blows out all the lackluster places to eat in the Financial District, out of the water.. dont get me wrong there are some good places to eat .. but they are pricey or overrated... dont get me wrong I consider myself a professional but all the boujie uppity 20 and 30 somethings that mob around the FinDi annoy me.. like cool you spend $20 a day on lunch, you want a cookie? with your grass fed meat, and wheat grass, and kale juice.. OH WAIT thats me to :( LOL

But for those of us that like organic, sustainable food but dont want to spend an arm and a leg, this place hits the spot. Its not sushi but its a triangular thing filled with delicious ingredients. I got the spicy shrimp and the salmon one the other day. You dont need rooster sauce or soy sauce at this establishment, thats for sure. Everything is seasoned perfectly , not SALTY my issue is sodium sometimes stuff is sooo salty its nasty... but not this place... great customer service as well. they appreciate their clients !
author: Mariangeles C.

description:
Here's a good way to add variety into your workweek lunch. The flavors aren't 100% spot on, but the onigiri should keep you from getting stuck in a rut with sushi, sandwiches, and salads all the time. The toppings tend to be salty, so the saltiness tends to mask the actual flavors (especially in the teriyaki flavors). Honestly, they're good enough to overlook the saltiness

Service is great. I wonder if the servers actually speak Japanese or are trained to say "irasshaimase" (welcome) when you enter.
author: Brittany L.

description:
A pretty decent rendition of Japanese onigiri. 

I LOVE onigiri (Japanese rice balls), and so when I heard about Onigilly, a restaurant entirely devoted to them, I couldn't wait to try it out! Unfortunately this place is very popular with the lunchtime crowd, and I got stuck in the middle of it. After waiting 10 minutes or so I finally placed my order: the wakame set with the renkon and snow crab onigiri. I also ordered a green tea lemonade to drink while I waited, which was another 5 minutes or so. 

Inside is quite small but it's okay because most people take their food to go. I liked how they served free mugicha (barley tea) and green tea to customers. While I waited for my food I drank some of my green tea lemonade, and I couldn't decide if I liked it or not. The first sip was far too sweet but it sort of grows on you after awhile. Even so I probably wouldn't order it again. As I watched them make the rice balls I noticed they weren't using the traditional method for onigiri: getting a ball of rice in one hand, placing the filling in the center and covering the filling with a bit more rice. Instead they had a triangle of pre-formed rice, stuck the filling on top, then added another triangle-shaped rice on top of that. Kind of like a rice sandwich? Weird. 

But I guess the aforementioned technique allows you to stuff more filling inside which is good for the customer. The renkon (lotus root) was pretty good, not too salty, a bit spicy, and it had the right amount of crunch. The snow crab was light and delicate tasting, but there was too much mayo inside. I really enjoyed the wakame salad =)

In the end it's a decent onigiri offering considering most people don't know much about rice balls. But they are too expensive.
author: Sam F.

description: Top-notch onigiri! Quality riceballs with quality care and the customer service makes me want to give a gold star to everyone~ The line can be intimidating, but that's why OrderAhead exists :D
author: Cynthia D.

description:
I'm eating my lunch right now, I'm not even halfway done and I'm feeling pretty full! I got the set of three plus the soup for 11 bucks: a great value for all the healthy goodness I just got. The spicy shrimp and shiitake have both been really good and it's kind of fun not using soy sauce or wasabi. I rarely go out to lunch but this is a great lunch spot, especially because of the convenience of ordering online and picking up. As a bonus, you get free barley tea. 
Well done, Onigilly.
author: Drea C.

description:
ONIGILLY ONIGILLY ONIGLLY!

I dont usually EVER find my self in Chinatown/FiDi but if I EVER do BEST BELIEVE I WILL BE STOPPING BY ONIGILLY!!!

Man this place feels like it was made for me! It caters to my tastes precisely!!

While I was taking a summer class at the Chinatown CCSF Campus I got to try the eggplant & salmon onigiri & they were both executed so perfectly & tasted like everything I would ever image & more!

Unfortunately after that first visit I compulsively ordered the same order the next 2 times I came back being so impressed with it but then my class ended & I haven't been back since & I really wish I had a chance to try more of their options!!!

I guess in the mean time I'll just pray that my life can form it's self so I can find myself in that area one of these days again!

Oh yea & the employees there were super nice!!!
author: Zhenya S.

description: I started eating at Onigilly despite its high prices, under the impression that most of the ingredients used were organic. Recently, I noticed the chicken items are no longer labeled as "organic." They used to be. Unless I'm told otherwise, I can only assume that the chicken that they use is no longer organic...which makes me question what kinds of meat they are using for their other meat items. I emailed Onigilly to ask about the menu items being organic, and I haven't heard back.
author: Grace M.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. 

After a few visits to the place, I was reminded from their food at an event last night why I never go back. 

Mushy rice. soggy seaweed, mushy rice. 

That sums up a bad onigiri for me. The fillings are generally very tasty. Shitake mushroom and spicy bacon was my favorite, but the mushy rice.....
author: Susie L.

description:
I love onigiri.  I really wanted to love love LOOVE this place, but sadly I think it's just okay.  I ordered the wakame combo with snowcrab and unagi.

The service was very fast and I enjoyed the barley tea that they had at the restaurant.

I took my meal back to my desk and sadly by time I got there the seaweed was pretty soggy and it made it difficult to eat.  However, what bothered me the most was the amount of mayo in my snowcrab onigiri.  It over powered the snowcrab and all I could taste was mayo.  I didn't expect this and part of why I only gave 3 stars.

The unagi one was tasty but also quite saucy.  I think I prefer the more traditional onigiri.
author: Jacq L.

description:
Too bad they're not open on the weekends and not open for dinner but if you can come here for lunch during the week, you will not be disappointed.

Ordered the Snowcrab onigiri and the Unagi onigiri. Both are really good but the snowcrab one was WOW.
author: Diana Y.

description:
Not bad but not excellent.  

It is a cute Little restaurant.  The wait can be long during lunch hours.  The staffs were very friendly and helpful.  

I got the Onigilly Combo Set (three rice balls and a green salad).  You can choose from any of the toppings.  I chose the spicy shrimp, seaweed and Mahi Mahi (special of the day).  Out of the three, I like the spicy shrimp the most.  The fish was little salty.  Seaweed was very standard.  

Overall, it is OK.
author: Liza T.

description:
I had eaten a good amount the day before, and as I sat in my chair at my desk, head resting in my palm as I stared blankly at my computer screen, I thought to myself, "Ugh, I need something on the lighter side." 

I yelped up any place nearby, particularly craving something on the Japanese side. Onigilly showed up. 4 stars. Rice balls. 5 minute walk from the office. Sold. 

Another thing that drew me was the fact that they used just brown rice. Added some value to the place, since most places would charge more for it. Service was very friendly and took time to explain the menu to first timers. If you don't know what to get before walking in, you will be staring at a lottttttt of text trying to figure out what to get. 

Solid 4 stars. Will definitely be back.
author: Winston B.

description:
I NEVER post reviews... mostly because I try to refrain from making myself sound like a subjective pr*ck, but there's something different about Onigilly. Maybe it's how they combat the rancid air from the construction directly outside of their restaurant or how the cashier always always ALWAYS hands me my receipt and credit card back in a two-hand, Japanese chibi gesture with the most sincere "thankyousomuch." 

Regardless, this isn't a review based off one meager experience, it's based off TWO, people (more than I can say for some of you), of which great and greater Onigilly rice ball experiences will follow, I'm assured. 

At first, they look like unimpressive, little prisms of rice wrapped in seaweed. But coming from someone who always judges books by covers, biting in and discovering the wonderful world of shiitake mushroom hidden beneath is a whole other experience (lookin' at you, Shiitake Ball). It changes you. I find myself spending actual minutes trying to frame the perfect picture of my unimpressive-looking rice balls for Instagram.

They have tons of flavors to choose from but I'm partial to the Shiitake and the Tempura shrimp. Try it. Experience it. Believe it. At ~$2.75 per unit, two of these little guys makes for a more than agreeable FiDi lunch next to the cafe that's charging you $15 for half a sandwich and some seltzer water.  
 
Onigilly, you guys are great. Your food is great. The stuffing in your rice as well as your rice is great. I will forever be your customer.
author: Alexa A.

description: Everyone I'm in sf, I always stop here to eat and bring one back to sj for lunch.  Lthis is an upgrade from what you would normally get from a Japanese supermarket rice ball. Very dilutions with the assortment you can get from this place
author: Raymond T.

description:
I've read several reviews where a lot of people enjoyed the unagi and the eggplant.  Normally I get the unagi and salmon whenever I go to Onigilly.  This time around, I decided to try something new and ordered the Wakame meal, choosing the unagi and eggplant.  The unagi was good as always.  As for the eggplant, It was not good.  It was very salty and it did not taste anything like a eggplant.  Either they got the mix wrong or some of you can handle your salt more than I can.  

I would not get the eggplant again.  I'll just stick with unagi and salmon.
author: J J.

description: The first time I came here, I loved the food so much I went back for lunch 2 days later. The next time, I tried the spicy shrimp ball, which wasn't my favorite but I love the tempura shrimp and the tofu balls. The miso soup could use a bit more flavor, but on the whole, very satisfying. And the staff is friendly and fast.
author: Stephanie B.

description: I had onigiri (rice balls) for the first time at this place today. I bought the edamame set which included three rice balls of my choice along with pickles and edamame. I had the soboro, salmon, and snow crab rice balls and they were all very delicious!! I would recommend this place to anyone.
author: Judy H.

description:
I've walked past this place for the last month and it's always packed with a line outside the door.   Last week, I figured I'd give Japanese Rice Balls a shot.

I got the lunch combo with 3 rice balls:  Unagi, Eggplant, and Spicy Shrimp.   I got a green tea to wash it all down with.

Food seems very healthy, which I suppose is the point, but I gotta say I'll take Sushi any day over Onigiri.   I just don't get the popularity of this joint.   It's good, don't get me wrong, but it's not worth waiting 15 minutes for, in my most humble opinion.

I might come back and eat here if and when I can just walk in, place my order, and get out.   Until then, y'all can eat my rice balls.
author: David O.

description:
Absolutely amazing. I came here for lunch, on the recommendation of a friend. Ordered the Wakame Salad Set with a Spicy Bacon Onigilly and a Snow Crab Onigilly. I also had the Organic Matcha Lemonade. 

Let me be frank: I LOVE LEMONADE, and their Matcha lemonade just became a new favorite. The idea of the green tea threwme off, but I decidied to take the plunge. I'm glad I did.

The seaweed tasted very fresh and the meat exceeded expectation. I honestly believe they use real snow crab. Even the Wakame salad was great.

Definitely a new favorite restaurant!
author: Daniel D.

description:
Healthy and affordable lunch date with my boyfriend right after getting tea from plentea. The line wasn't long since we came around 11am on a weekday before workers started coming for the lunch rush.

We each got the set which included choice of 3 onigiris, edamame, and pickled diakon radish. I ordered the unagi, salmon, and soboro while my boyfriend got the spicy bacon, salmon, and tempura shrimp. Each of the onigiris were delicious; however, the salmon tasted bland, they didn't season that enough. I did wish they added a bit more sauce for each of them. 

I would definitely come back here if I was ever in the area and craved some Japanese food.
author: Jessica Y.

description:
Brings me back to my childhood spent in japan. Love it.

They make each Onigilly at time of order and the rice is still warm. Complementary Barley tea (hot or cold). 

Im not a huge fan of the pickled vegis, too sweet, which is a bummer, but that is not why I come here so its not a big deal. 

Spicy bacon was yummy and their seasonal items tend to be great too. I always go for the 3 Ongilly, cause its so good.
author: Kristan B.

description: Love this place. Quick place to get a light and healthy lunch. I always get the miso soup combo. The onigiri is surprisingly filling and really hits the spot when I want something healthy yet tasty and quick.
author: S. S.

description: The first time i encountered them was June 12, 2012 across A.T.T. park the night of matt cain's perfect game. They had a food cart back then and was happy to find their brick and mortar location. I have my go to spicy aioli shrimp= YUMMMY!!! Try to before the lunch rush though the line may be long it's fast.
author: Jo K.

description:
Walked in here during my lunch hoping to find some authentic onigilly! Happy to reports that I did. They were out of the Ahi tuna, but got the spicy shrimp onigilly to go. Loved the brown rice version.. I know, I know its not true Japanese, but hey I like my fiber, and the texture that it offers!  I think they could have used a tad less mayo, not a biggie though.
Also a BIG plus on the service, the staff were super friendly, seemed like they genuinely wanted to pronounce my name correctly! I appreciate that! Thanks!

Will be back to try other items since my office is soo close!
author: Sravanthi D.

description: This place is a solid snack/lunch spot. I ate a snack a few hours before, so I only ordered two onigiris. I ordered the spicy shrimp and Unagi. The Unagi is super bomb, can't say the same for the spicy shrimp. There was a bit too much aioli in it, making it feel heavier when I was eating it. In many ways there's nothing special about this place, but at the same time, there doesn't need to be. Sometimes all you want is a simple, no nonsense snack/meal and that's what Onigilly is. It wouldn't be part of my daily or weekly lunch spots, but if I was in the mood for something Japanese on the go, Onigilly would be my first choice. Oh, one more thing, this place is a MUCH better selection than Sushirrito.
author: Aaron C.

description:
I'll admit - the first two times I tried Onigilly I was not impressed. It took me about three tries before actually finding the combination of onigiris that impressed me enough to give this place 4 stars.

Below are the onigiri's I've had from least favorite to my current go-to's: 

- Natto - I think many people find this off-putting because of the texture but I actually don't mind it. However, I just felt like the flavor lacked a bit for me. 

- Salmon - This was one of the first onigiri's I got and I hadn't read the description thoroughly and assumed I was going to get raw salmon. I'm not a huge fan of cooked salmon but my coworkers have also mentioned they felt this one lacked a bit of flavor.

- Miso Tuna Salad - Decent but nothing really memorable.Tastes just how it sounds. 

- Spicy Bacon - Pretty good but on the heavy/salty side so I don't typically order this often. 

- Snow Crab - Light but, if you like crab, this one is nice and subtle. Yay for real crab meat! (none of that imitation stuff!) 

- Spicy Shrimp - For a while this was my favorite - it's got great flavor and is a bit spicy but not in an overwhelming way. I've introduced Onigilly to a few friends (without telling them my preferences) and all of them have stated that this one was the standout. 

- Tarako - The new favorite. If you don't like fish roe you might not like this. What I love about this one is the unique flavor. It is on the saltier side but the rice balances it out. 

Other Pros - 

** Nice and clean
** Super friendly staff
** They use brown rice so you can feel like you're eating healthy! 
** Pretty decent lunch deals (esp for the FiDi area). I always get the 3 onigiri special (comes with edamame and picked radish) - Snow Crab, Spicy Shrimp, Tarako - which comes out to $10
author: Feli W.

description: We really needed this place here. This one (of three locations) is located on Kearny just as the Financial District transitions into Chinatown. It's immaculate and bustling. The people behind the counter are friendly and helpful, a good thing because many customers are probably unfamiliar with this food. The nori-wrapped rice balls (triangles, actually) contain other delicious ingredients which you order. These "onigiri" are the items you find in most Japanese kids' school lunchboxes. So it's the Japanese equivalent of a peanut butter and jelly sandwich! Three of them makes a very nice lunch. Choose three different ones!
author: Paula H.

description:
love this place!
the rice balls is super yummy and healthy too!
i always order the ginger beef, tarako and sometimes unagi or salmon,
people here are always friendly too

the only complaint i have is their business hours...
they close at 4 everyday :(
author: Miffy L.

description:
Great place to get take-out and sit across the street to munch on a sunny day.

Their natto is one of the best I've had. The soy beans are bigger and flavorful.

I've run into one more onigilly place in LA - this one is way better.
author: Jen L.

description: Once a coworker turned me on to this place, I was addicted. Highly recommend the Bay shrimp and mushroom ones.
author: Anastasia J.

description: I loved my brown rice snow crab da best!! Perfect amount of rice and filling ratio! Really love the side edammame and yellow pickles on the side. I would still love to try the spicy bacon and other flavor next time!
author: Wendy T.

description: i got a soy-braised shiitake and a hijiki/carrot. both were $2.76 (everything was weirdly priced, and somehow my two $2.76 things came out to $6 perfectly). i found them both to be too salty, and they both tasted heavily of soy sauce without much other flavor. normally i would have complained about too much rice, but the fillings were so salty that the amount of rice was necessary. this might be my fault for getting the ones that people talked about on yelp (i was trying to be more adventurous for once, sigh). i did like that the rice was warm, while the fillings were a bit cooler (which is kind of a weird thing to like, but oh well).
author: Heather F.

description:
My work just ordered a lunch for around 15 people and the whole experience was fantastic from top to bottom. They nailed the order, the person I worked with to place the order via email was super responsive and friendly, the checkout gentleman was incredibly friendly and efficient, the order was on time and I had no problem moving to the front of the line and picking it up. Not to mention the food is super tasty! 
I highly recommend these guys for company lunches that are more exciting than boring old boxed sandwiches.
author: Elana B.

description:
Yummy! The menu has the instructions for ordering and when I was here, there was a worker who was popping outside to answer questions. Yup, there's a line out the door during lunch, but the place is small. I recommend getting food to go since there's limited seating. Walk over to BoA plaza nearby and eat outside in the beautiful weather!

Order in 2 steps:
1) Choose Onigilly set (or individual), Rice Bowl, or Salad Bowl
2) Choose your flavors (the stuff that goes inside)

FYI - the name of the restaurant is a play on the word "onigiri" for Japanese rice ball :)

I got the set of 3:
+Soboro -- ginger soy ground angus beef
+Spicy Bacon
+Spicy Shrimp
The set of 3 comes with a salad too! Wasn't expecting that.

They're trying to get feedback from customers, so they give you a survey when you pick up your food. Fill it out and bring it back for $2 off your next meal!
author: Katherine S.

description:
I've been here a few times and every time I wonder, "why the hell did I spend $10+ here? Not worth it."

I love rice balls. Home made, from supermarkets, wherever, I've eaten them. Unfortunately this place doesn't deliver. The ratio of rice to fillings is too high. I would have found this acceptable if the rice was good. The rice is NOT GOOD. It's not fragrant, chewy, nothing special. It's not worth the calories. I would eat a plain bowl of good japanese grain rice because it tastes good! Here, I am tempted to pick out the excess rice bc it's only giving me negative utility. It's just not good...it's the kind of rice you get as an obligatory side when you get Chinese food that's been sitting out there ready to be scooped into your container. Even then some of those places have better rice. 

Fillings are okay. Some are really salty. Everytime I get a fish filling I get weird bone crap in the onigiri. Sometimes I'm afraid to bite into the unagi one. Also seems heavy on the sauce. It doesn't need to be if you get the right rice-filling ratio and fix the rice.  

Blah. This annoyed me enough for me to whip out the phone and type this out. 

They need to fix the messaging of their "sets". Just say free edamame and sunomono/pickles if you order 3. Would avoid a lot of confusion from the customers. The staff here are very nice (though seems like they've been traumatized by customers angry/confused about the "set" pricing). 

1 star for food. +1 for the staff.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
Nice little spot for lunch. The line can get long at peak hours (think corporate lunchtime), but it's not too bad if you've got a friend with you. The spicy shrimp and the snow crab are excellent, the salmon can be bland. Someone's got an uneven seasoning hand...

2 onigilly is usually enough for me, but people with bigger appetites will need 3.
author: Sharon L.

description:
Fresh, delicious rice triangles with any type of topping you could possibly crave, with seaweed wrapped around it to make it finger food = dreamy delicious.  Delicious japanesey cool.

And, filling!  I couldn't finish three of them with the salad that comes with it.  I saw two big guys who couldn't finish their rice bowls for lunch sitting next to me either.  Good stuff.
author: Melanie C.

description:
The place is not bad. If you're into a light lunch, check out Onigilly.

The eggplant is what you should be getting, the pork belly was a bit dry.
author: Vince H.

description: I've been here at least a couple dozen times; everything is fresh and made to order. I usually get the rice bowl, choose three items to go on top of rice( spicy shrimp, crab, Unagi) plus a mixed green salad topped with edamame  and yellow radish. The staff is courteous and the line at this spot moves quickly.I will be back soon.
author: Theodore B.

description: I might have an obsession with onigiri and just had to give Onigilly a try! Ordered one each of salmon, tuna, crab meat and enoki (mushroom) together with some edamame and plum set for $14 and enjoyed my healthy filling lunch thoroughly! Crab meat was surprisingly tasty! If I live or work anywhere near Onigilly I would be a regular. :)
author: Jan L.

description:
When Hideki Matsui of NY Yankees was playing for his high school team, he was interviewed by TV reporter and he was asked what food he loves to eat. 

Godzilla answered "Onigili and milk- my everyday school lunch made by Mom."

In order to be a world class baseball player some day, you must give up your taste buds for the god's sake. Because onigili and milk can't be matched. 

I don't know the selection of drinks Onigilly restaurant in SF (excellent food and service) offers, but my recommendation is J-tea (o'cha) or water. Nothing sweeten or spiced. 

Japanese food in general requires keen sense to distinguish the subtle nuance in taste. Rice ball is the entry level of such a test. Welcome to the J-cuisine!

And don't drink milk with your onigilis. Thanks.
author: yota L.

description:
Was looking for a light lunch and I ventured over to kearny st and have been meaning to try onigilly for awhile now so I stopped by. 

The place is small and can hold a handful of people in there if you are looking to dine in. Looks like its a better setup for takeout.

The staff were very friendly and helped me choose 2 hand rolls - the curry turkey, the enoki mushroom one, and the spicy shrimp. 3 rolls for about $8

I didn't have to wait long at all for my order so this is definitely a good quick to go lunch spot. 

Overall the hand rolls were just ok to me. The only one that had a lot of flavor was the spicy shrimp. The other 2 were just ok. The seaweed they used to wrap it was a little difficult to bit through as well so I had to use a fork and knife to eat the rest of my lunch.

I would go back to try the other flavors but i wouldn't order the enoki or the turkey one again.
author: Christine W.

description:
Came here during lunch time when line was about 5 people. I got the salmon, the unagi and the spicy shrimp w/ the lunch set (edamame and pickled veg). I asked to swap the pickled veg with edamame.

Everything was made in front of me and delicious. 3 origiri was a pretty filling lunch for me. However, their origini is definitely not the traditional one as the salmon was grilled instead of cured, but other than that, the food is delicious and quick enough for lunch
author: Ruxin H.

description:
Food: 3
Decor: 3
Service: 4

I've been here 3 times for lunch since I work right next door.

1. Lunch Set A (3 onigilly) with meat complete, 9
~Pretty good. Mixed green salad was okay, cucumber salad was quite good, and the onigiri was okay.

2. Lunch Set B (bowl) with meat complete, 9
~Pretty good. No cucumber salad, but I liked being able to mix up the salad, rice, and meat.

Service was fast and friendly.
author: David L.

description:
A very light meal for a not so very light price. That sums up Onigilly for me. It was my first time there and I opted for the combo (3 rice triangles with edamame and daikon). Total came out to $10, ouch!

I got the eel, the snow crab, and the spicy bacon. I wasn't crazy about the eel or the spicy bacon. But the snow crab I loved! If I ever go back, I would stick to the snow crab. It was so delish! 3 triangles, 6 edamame pieces, and 3 slices of daikon (radish) later (yes, they are a bit stingy), and I'm still kind of hungry. It's a very very light meal. So if that's the type of meal you're searching for, Onigilly is the place for you!

It's an interesting concept - kind of like musubis or sushi rolls, but in a triangle. It's cute and Japanese. Onigilly is just ok for me. I think people are amused by the whole concept. But to grade the quality and quantity of what you get - just A-Ok!
author: Junel S.

description:
I first tried their food at their Express outlet in Embarcadero. 
Ate at this restaurant yesterday.

Absolutely love their creation - its simply, easy to eat, tastes great and complete value for money. In about $11, I got 3 onigiris (one too much), some edamame and pickles and a small cup of miso soup.

I'm a vegetarian, so tried almost all their veggies options and liked all of them. They have a lot to choose from, so that's great. Maybe a bit more stuffing in the onigiris would be nice.

The cashier was super attentive (despite the heavy crowds) and the food came quick.

Must try!
author: Sumit S.

description:
I first experienced Onigilly though a Simmr event, I had never heard of onigilly before, but apparently it is much more common than sushi in Japan. It is the sandwich of Japan. I can see why because it is so good! And it's really affordable! I love the spicy shrimp and the housemade lemonade. 

I was impressed with the Onigilly staff during the event. They were so informative and gave a lot of extra food perks to the event attendees.  I will definitely be returning.
author: Moline D.

description: They onigiris are best. Great people, great vibe too. How they localized Japanese tradition is impressive!
author: Aya M.

description: I was in SF for work this week and my manager recommended that I try Onigilly. I'm so glad I did!! First of all, the guy at the register was amazingly friendly and helpful with his suggestions. The food was done quickly, our group's orders were accurate and the food was de-LISH-ous!!! I'll definitely be back when I'm in town again.
author: Mikelle L.

description:
First time trying this today and I will be back! Has the three onigilly plate - 2 teriyaki chickens and 1 spicy shrimp!  WOW  so tasty, the shrimp had a great kick.  Will be back 
recommend you beat the lunch rush if possible
author: Tina K.

description:
So loving Onigilly the last few times, I revisited Onigilly today because they have these Tofu noodles that are super low-carb that I've been dying to try.  I got the Soup and two onigilly lunch special for $9.95, which ended up coming to $12.00.  Now I do understand that not all toppings are created equally but the good options you have without being upcharged are slim so expect to add an extra dollar or two to your order for anything you buy here.  

I got the Salmon Skin and Miso Salmon Onigillys and both were average at best.  The salmon skin was not rich and fatty but instead flaky and dry and the Miso Salmon was an itty bitty piece of fish that was also dry.  I asked for a little container of hot sauce and was told that will be an extra charge.  Also, they advertise the lunch with edamame and kimchi and I got four pieces of edamame and the blandest cabbage (not kimchi) that I have ever had. The soup I got was also super bland and in desperate need of hot sauce and soy sauce, so I'm really glad I got it togo.  I doctored it with siracha and soy sauce back at my office and all was right in the world again!

Onigilly loses a star today for nickle and diming my lunch to a bland, tasteless death!  Another star lost for skimping on everything and not delivering much!  

My how the mighty have fallen!
author: Brandy B.

description:
i lived, breathed, and ate onigiris for a living when i studied abroad in japan so onigiris have a special place in my heart.

we were next door attempting to grab ramen for lunch until we realized the wait was a lot longer than expected.  walked down few stores and stumbled upon onigilly restaurant and decided to give it a try!

perfect for lunch on the go.  healthy even with the amount of carbs because they use 100% organic rice and 30% of which are custom milled brown rice, so don't feel too bad about stuffing 3 onigiris down your throat.

i got 1 sake (salmon) onigiri and salad.  onigiris are standard and the salad was surprisingly tangy and not filled with useless iceberg lettuce, but instead with lots of healthy greens :)  you get to customize your own onigiris so you'll probably find something that will compliment your taste buds. 

not sure how this place is for dinner, but definitely more of a casual lunch spot :)
author: Alice C.

description: Disappointed! I was looking forward to getting authentic Japanese food for lunch. It's overpriced, and dirty... Yes, dirty for one thing most Japanese place isn't. Onigiri is usually salty and calls for water, but this place serve water in a dirty plastic bucket. I know you want us to purchase more but this gives me horrible message that what I am eating is dirty too.
author: Mika G.

description:
Ate an Ume (pickled plum) rice ball at their Off The Grid booth.  Fantastic!  The shitake rice ball was also good.  Not as salty as I'd been warned; I added a little sea salt.

I'm finishing this review months later, and I still have dreams of this Ume rice ball, beckoning to me from three thousand miles away.
author: Jason H.

description:
Better than I imagined! My brother came here for a birthday and wouldn't shutup about some cabbage pancake, so I caved and tried Onigilly for dinner on a Friday. Three of us ordered a pretty significant spread: pork and veg kimchi, asparagus, tempura fried avocado, veggie slider with seaweed, lotus root taco, spicy bacon tacos, (the infamous) cabbage pancake and maybe some more stuff. Everything ruled!!! The server made a goof and thought we ordered mahi mahi. We didn't, but ate it anyways and it was awesome too. Our server endlessly refilled our glasses with sake sangria to make up for it, so no complaints at all!

I had no idea the place closed at 8pm which seems a bit early for Friday. The restaurant is a bit small, so space can be an issue. There is upstairs dining available though.

Definitely will come back! Lots of grub to satisfy both vegetarians and meat-eaters.

Don't come here and ask for raw fish and then act surprised that not all Japanese food is sushi. (that's a jab at a dummy couple that walked in around 745pm, ZING)

And oh yeah...the cabbage pancake totally lived up to what my bro was raving about. It's bomb! Big pancake with kale and cabbage plus some other stuff, with mayo and ketchup-y sauce latticed on top. Also, the fried avo must have been newly menu-ed because the staff kept commenting and laughing that they need a better way to deep fry it. It was served whole (skinless, obv) with the pit inside! Really good, but the tempura batter did fall off...
author: Brittany L.

description: Amazing place!   Authentic-wanted to share healthy and delicious food w/ the world.  Koji,the owner, stands for better eating.   ...and it tastes awesome!!! ;)
author: Mike B.

description:
What is an onigiri you ask? Imagine if a Sushi Hand Roll mated with one of those little Triangle Sandwiches that old ladies serve at tea time... They would produce an onigiri. Replace the bread of the sandwich with triangle shaped brown rice, fill it with some sort of flavorful veggie/meat/seafood  filling and wrap it in seaweed ... Voila! Onigiri! 

It was my first time hitting this spot for lunch and I am in love! The staff is extremely friendly and the food satisfied my sushi craving. I got the Onigilly Set that comes with 3 onigiri rice rolls (I got grilled salmon, teriyaki chicken and bacon) and a side of edamame for a total $11. Since the rice roll fillers have so much flavor they do not recommend using soy sauce but instead they have sea salt, chili powder and sesame seeds that you can add on the side for more flavor or spice.

I highly recommend this Japanese take on triangle sandwiches!
author: Allie B.

description:
You guys, I can't stop! I come here maybe twice a week at least and have to get the seafood classic rice bowl. It comes with the following:
- Spicy shrimp
- Miso tuna
- Hijiki
- Rice
- Salad
- Edamame 

It is the perfect combination of protein, carbs, and green. It's filling and I don't feel sluggish for the rest of my work day.

The man taking orders at the register is always so friendly and remembers me every time. He turned me onto the tofu noodle soup as well which is delicious on a grey SF day downtown.

Remember to get a punch card! 10 meals and you get one up to $10 free!
author: Genevieve L.

description: This place is alright... I had the mentaiko, soboro, and miso tuna three onigiri set lunch with salad and ordered miso soup.  The miso soup was lukewarm and no bueno, the mentaiko and soboro riceballs were tasty but had way too much rice in them and one of them was sopping wet on the bottom.  My favorite was the miso tuna (cooked) onigiri.  The salad tasted like it didn't have any dressing on it.  The pickles were very odd, almost like Korean style, and not the normal tart umeboshi pickles that I'm used to.  The concept of this place is great, esp for lunch, but the quality is not what I expected.
author: Terry K.

description: Delicious snack food.  Freshly made with great flavor.
author: Johnny T.

description: I am pretty impressed with the concept and the delivery of this place. I especially love the variety and for the price, it is a fair deal. My only complaint is that some of the rice balls aren't that good. I love okra, but it was extremely mushy. The unagi tasted like a salt ball. On a good note, the tamako and the snow crab were delicious.
author: S. G.

description:
Come for the Happy Hour! Izakaya style bites, seasonal vegetables and $3 beer. It's really hard to beat that. 

Plus, HH goes on through 8PM. A savior for all who work past 7.
author: Fiona S.

description: This is my little reminder of Japan. I recently went to Japan and have been missing their onigiri that I find in convenience stores and better yet the little store kiosks in their food court with gourmet onigiri. When I found out about this shop called onigilly, I was skeptical at first because it's not even spelled right :O and then i saw pictures where it's not wrapped all inside the rice.. I was like is this legit? And it's brown rice compared to the japanese sushi rice. Anywho, I was in the neighborhood one morning and decided to try some Onigilly! I ordered a variety of flavors to take to go and share with my mom. I got miso tuna, snow crab, spicy shrimp, sapporo beef (my apologies if i got this wrong), and the salmon. I ordered 6, and the gentleman who rang me up was nice enough to give me a buy a certain amount and get one free stamp card and punched it twice since i ordered two sets. YAY!! :) I couldn't wait to go home and eat this, when i got back, i dropped everything and sat down to enjoy these babies. The brown rice WAS NOT BAD AT ALL, it tasted just like sushi rice, i would've been fooled if they didnt advertised the healthiness of it. CHECK, and the taste was good too. My favorites are the snow crab and spicy shrimp! It has many decent size baby shrimps in there, NOM!!! :) As for tuna, I will stick to the japan ones. The tuna and salmon didn't do much for me, or maybe i had too high of a expectation. All in all, i would definitely come back, as this is the closest I can get to Japan for now. Thanks Onigilly!
author: Cindy C.

description:
This is a review for the Onigilly food truck at Off the Grid at Fort Mason. 

The onigiri is a-ok. Nothing to write home about.  I love the idea of onigiri as they are indeed quick bites that contain Japanese rice + nori (seaweed) and sometimes protein.  I had the spicy bacon + chicken teriyaki.  I thought the flavor in the spicy bacon was more interesting than the chicken teriyaki.  I also ate my onigiri after tasting the KoJa Kitchen sandwich, which was way flavorful so that might have tainted my tastebuds.  

$3 for onigiri - doens't break the bank.
author: Alias A.

description:
The staff was very friendly and I was very excited to try this place, but it was a bit disappointing. 

I got the Ongilly Set: 3 Rice balls and salad.

Got the Miso Tuna-not much flavor and it was canned tuna. CAN? Really?

Spicy Shrimp-Not spicy at all. The aioli was good, but not much to it

My favorite was the Spicy Bacon! This is a must. 

I would come back for the bacon and try some other ones. I really hope the other ones are better.
author: Karen H.

description:
If you tried this spot a while ago and haven't been back recently, give it another try. I came back to get lunch here today and was pleasantly surprised. 

They improved their assembly of the onigilly by pre-shaping the rice and placing the ingredients in the middle of the rice. I know this sounds ridiculous and overly analytic, but it makes for a much better eating experience. 

My favorites are the tempura shrimp and the tarako. The tarako is so good, I would order three! Also give the happy hour a try. The dinner selection is excellent and reasonably priced. I'm glad to see a variety of Japanese restaurants popping up in the area. I'm tired of people who think Japanese people just eat sushi all day.
author: Susan P.

description:
These little onigiris were a clutch find on a trip to Japan - cheap, delicious, filling, & available at every convenience store. Onigilly did not disappoint! They do a good job of creating subtle layers of flavor that highlight the fillings, of which you are provided with a diverse selection. My favorite has been the unagi. Free mugicha (barley tea) while you wait.
Note: portion sizes are smaller than your typical American palate, but still plenty to fill you up if you don't scarf them down quickly. If you have a huge appetite, get the rice bowl option.
Healthy, delicious, and a fun atmosphere - will be back!
author: Jacob J.

description:
I love izakayas. It's my constant craving and I'm always searching for a favorite. 

So thus I was disappointed that the closest thing to an izakaya was in the Sunset....45 minutes away and a 2 hour wait. 

AT this point, I figure, I cant really lose in trying a new place. Honestly, I was pleasantly surprised. With an extensive menu, it's nice to find some classics such as Takowasa, tempura, okonomiyaki, takoyaki, and random dishes (that's what makes izakaya fun). While the okonomiyaki was small, it was packed with red cabbage and tasty. I really enjoyed the shishito tempura and even the basic miso soup (packed with veggies). 

Perhaps the classics were even more heightened with the presentation. Despite the small table space, the plating was well thought out. 

The sake selection is bleh, but they do have Coedo beer and Asahi (all bottles, no draft). 

The onigiri are at a happy hour price and are filling. The buta kimchi was rather bland as the kimchi was not sour enough, but the helpings of pork plenty were awesome. 

Long story short, I'm definitely a fan of this izakaya and will surely return.
author: Wendy L.

description:
I cannot emphasis how much i LOVE THIS PLACE.!!! Once you step in, it has a very zen feeling though not a hippy vegan place. You can eat meat guilt free here :) 

Pro tip: There's always a queue so either go early or later (lunch time) ... or order via the take-away app for an express pick-up. 

I choose the salad noodle option, served with a small side of light brown rice? They also have the rice ball and rice bowl options. 

Toppings: Decided to get the bang for my buck and go for the meats!

1. Unagi (fish) - LOVED IT!!! wish they gave more though... sooo good! 

2. Teriyaki (chicken) - YUMMY!!!

3. Soboro - honey ginger soy braised angus beef - GOOD but I think it was minced beef so don't except thick, chunk slices... haha... after all it's only approx $10 for a combo. 

I would eat here everyday if I didn't have food in the office. It's so delicious and healthy too :) Your body would thank you. WIll be back here again soon!!!
author: Amanda L.

description:
I'm a fan.  Big fan.  Since the day I had my first one at OTG, I was hooked.  And now they have a restaurant just a hop skip and a jump away from me -- love.

Spicy shrimp ... teriyaki chicken ... salmon -- these are my top three for my perfect lunch/dinner.
author: Juv C.

description: First time trying the onigiri and we felt in love. Great format and great flavor. Easy to eat, not messy at all. The staff is friendly and fast, very fast! We had Soboro (ginger honey beef), Spicy Shrimp, Snow Crab and Unagui. They were delicious and full of flavor. Please note that 3 units will be enough for your hunger as each comes with q good portion of rice.
author: Flavio A.

description:
OMGilly this place is so good! If you like sushi or fish (cuz it's not quite sushi :) they are definitely worth exploring. 

Signature seaweed wraps, beautiful salads, magical flavor combos, local organic selections, catchy Japanese character.....it's tasty. 

I especially like they have GF DF V options labeled. Nice staff too.
author: Rob B.

description:
I found this place while strolling down Kearny Street on my way to a hair salon. I love onigiri, so was very intrigued by the concept of a place that specialized in it. 

It looks like Onigilly caters to the Downtown lunch crowd -- at 1pm, there was still a long line up going out the door. I waited about 40 minutes from the time I got in line until I got my takeout order. The wait was a bit of a bummer, but was worth it to try something new.

I was impressed by the amount of choice they brought into their onigiri fillings -- I tried bacon, salmon skin (special of the day), miso salmon (special of the day), sukiyaki beef (special of the day), terriyaki chicken, and prawn poke (special of the day). On the appearance side of things, their rendition of the onigiri is a little different from the traditional way they are done. Traditionally, onigiri fillings are inside the rice triangle, with seaweed wrapped all around the outside. Onigilly's onigiri are topped with the fillings you choose and the seaweed is wrapped around the rice triangle and topping to keep everything together -- sort of like a paper bag holding your groceries. 

As for taste, the toppings were good, but not necessarily super amazing. Again, I like the different concepts for toppings they have, so the variety makes it special. The rice was a little hard and cold -- I like my onigiri with warm sticky rice :)

Overall, a great concept and I did enjoy the food. Price wasn't too bad either -- it worked out to be $22 for all 6 of my onigiri choices. I was probably looking for a more impressive taste experience, especially given the amount of wait time.
author: Mel M.

description:
I honestly like this place but truth be told, it's pretty mediocre. You can grab a much better onigiri at Super Mira for a little over a dollar any day of the week, and they've been sitting out all day long. Unfortunately, I don't work anywhere near Super Mira, so that's just not an option.

What do they do wrong? Well, their rice is neither cooked nor prepared very well, the extremely thick nori isn't toasted, so it basically turns to leather when it starts absorbing moisture, their interpretation of tsukemono seems to involve simply sprinkling salt on fresh celery, and nobody but small women and children will feel they've gotten enough food in exchange for their $10 when they're done eating. I also can't figure out why the dude who usually works the register--who actually does appear to be Japanese--insists on mispronouncing everything on the menu. Maybe they say "nay-do" instead of "natto" in Okinawa or something. I dunno.

But the meats are pretty good, as is the natto, however they choose to pronounce it. I go here on days when I don't really want anything hot but a salad sounds dull and I'm usually out the door pretty quickly. You definitely shouldn't avoid it, but unless you work in the neighborhood, you'd be crazy to go out of your way to get here.
author: Nicholas J.

description:
I got the Spicy Shrimp and Snow Crab 'Onigilly' and they were both pretty decent... but not amazing or anything. They do skimp on the filling a little--while I was watching them make it I noticed they only put filling on the very upper-most corner that peaks out from the seaweed wrap lol.

On a sidenote... who else had their plastic fork break numerous times while trying to eat their meal?! Ate here with a friend and we both broke our forks 3+ times.. Food--3 stars. Forks--0 stars. Haha :P
author: stephanie f.

description:
If I could I would give more than 5 stars! I absolutely love this place and the staff is super nice. Their onigilly rice ball wraps are very yummy and inexpensive.  My favorite are Soboro, Teriyaki chicken and shiitake.  The miso soup is delicious too.

You should absolutely try this place if you are in the are.
author: Daniela B.

description: Excellent, unique, tasty sushi! All utensils are recyclable. Great staff. Recommended!
author: Gili G.

description:
So, I heard about Onigilly from a friend of a friend, and I'd been really curious to go there and check it out. The Yelp hours posted are/were wrong so that was part of what kept me from going here. That said, I finally got down there for lunch and was pretty excited about the menu.

I ordered the lunch special, in which I got 3 Onigiri - Cod Roe (yum!), Salmon and I think Ume, and a little salad. It was extremely tasty, and I enjoyed every bite of it.
However, I'm a big eater so it was a little small. It was around $9 with tax, so not the cheapest lunch around but perfectly fine for the area.

If you're not familiar with Onigiri, I suggest you change that, and Onigilly is probably a good spot to start.
author: Tom S.

description: I got a tuna one.  Delicious!! Fast and friendly service. They give a lot of filling.  Brown rice.  Cheap
author: Emma C.

description:
I had no expectations before I tried this place because I have never had rice balls, but was pleasantly surprised. I try and eat in FiDi during what I like to call "random times" (aka off-peak hours) since I don't mind waiting as long as my chocolate drawer at work is full. 
I got the lunch set with unagi, eggplant (my favorite!) and sake. Portions were just right in my opinion; the set comes with a salad and edamame and is nicely presented. Then again, I do have a chocolate drawer.
author: Wendy L.

description: Dropped by for my lunch break and was super excited to try from all of the reviews. I decided to order the rice bowl and it definitely filled me up! I got with the snow crab, unagi, and bacon which definitely added totally about $12. It was still tasty and worth the try! The wait was quick and was in and out about ten minutes. Will be back to try more!
author: Steph C.

description:
Awesome option for lunch. I got the Onigilly Set (3 choices + edamame and pickles) because I wanted to try a bunch of flavors. LOVE that they mark what's gluten-free and vegan. I got the spicy bacon, the salmon, and a seasonal flavor - raw sesame kale. All were awesome GF options. The bacon is legitimately spicy, in a good way. 3 onigilly is kind of a lot of rice (and a lot of filling - these were loaded!) so I'll probably get the 2+miso set next time. 

Oh, and my edamame were kind of small and hairy. Not impressed. 

Other than that, I love this place. Will definitely be back.
author: Kate W.

description:
I was super excited even when I was waiting in a long line. 

I tried "seafood duper", a combo of Eel / Crab / Shrimp tempura. That was very awesome. The default side menu, edamame and salad were better things than I expected. The atmosphere of the store was also great. It took almost 10$, which was reasonable for me. 

The only reason I didn't give 5 star, instead of 4, is the quality of the rice.  I grew up in Japan so I have a solid feeling about rice. I bet the rice was not the best one. 
I would like to strongly recommend to provide an option of better rice.

Also, it would be great if the store is also opening at evening -- yes, I'm a fan of  Onigilly.
author: Shuichi I.

description: Oishidesu!!!!!!!!! Wow, incredible, one of best places I have ever eaten, the shiitake mushroom onigiri is incredible, it's cheap, healthy, and the flavors are unique and delicious in San Francisco, a 6$ lunch in unheard of 15 is pretty common, so to find this good of food for this price is too good to be true, this will become my favorite lunch spot for fidi. Go here. The end.
author: Scrapp H.

description:
I had their triangle-shaped rice thingy with spicy shrimp last week at an event -
It looked great, so I decided to order it,... this was by far one of the best "rice-ball wrapped with seaweed" thing EVER !!! I went back and ordered 5 more (for me and my friend" !!!  This thing was so absolute freaking ridiculous unbelievable off-the-hook perfectly delicious !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  I am going back to their main restaurant and try to maybe get around this shrimp thing and try something else (MAYBE)!!!
If everything in their restaurant is this delicious, I might NEWA EWA eat anywhere else when I am downtown or their food cart is somewhere close!!!

Check those guys out,...the Japanese chef and his colleague where super nice and friendly, and I wish them the best of luck to grow and be even more successful(as long as they keep the high "deliciousness" up !!!!!

You guys are great!!! 



went there at night,... think 8.30ish, and was told they were closed :-(((  But the guys where super nice and apologized that they are closed and told me to please come back. So guess I will ;-)
author: Sfo993 B.

description:
what i ordered... miso soup, unagi onigilly and snow crab onigilly

unagi onigilly was nasty, chopped up unagi slithering in a pool of bbq tasting sauce
crab onigilly was like eating plain steam rice and having crab salad as an entree
miso soup was ok tasting but was just warm

ambiance... ok (a nice hole in a wall)
service... good (cashier was nice and smiley)
cost... $- (fair)
author: Gors P.

description:
Okay, I try to be frugal with five star ratings, especially on my frugal vacation to San Fran, but like finding a $10 bill in the street, thus did I end up having an unexpected and delightful dining experience at Onigilly. There specialty is rice balls which is a ball of rice, with some other toppings, but not too much, in a seaweed wrap. It is Japanese but even there the ones I had were generally pre-packaged and not the delightfully fresh rice ball experience provided at Onigilly.

The fact that the group who started this restaurant started out running a food truck probably explains why things are so streamlined.You pick the initial layout (rice ball, rice bowl, noodles) and then you pick the three standardized toppings (I had number four, chicken, then eggplant, and spicy shrimp) and you pay, I assume cash only which is what I paid, and then you either get take-out, or if there is a table, and I was lucky to find one, you can eat-in. The three rice balls came with a wonderful side salad and as I had water i think the whole meal was around $10....

Is it worth it? Well, let's just say, with all these food options around here, when my friend comes in today to join my frugal vacation experience, I'm taking her to Onigilly for lunch, besides, you fill out the survey and when you come back you get $2 off - I did say it was a frugal vacation, didn't I? :-)
author: George L.

description:
I finally had an opportunity to stop in at Onigilly today.  The line was pretty short, so I took the chance and waited my turn.  The ordering part is a bit confusing, as others have said, but since you will have at least 5 minutes before your order is taken, you'll have plenty of time to chose what you want.  What I found a little difficult about ordering is the weird handwriting of the person who wrote out the menu.  It's a bit hard to read.

After a short wait, I placed my order for the 3 onigilly/salad combo and chose the seafood combo.  It was ready in a minute or two.  I bit right into one of those little packages and it was delicious!  The Nori wasn't hard or soggy yet (as others have complained) and the rice was delicious.  The toppings included miso tuna salad, shrimp and hijiki.  Of the three, I liked the miso tuna salad best.  The side salad was a nice size - just what you need - and I enjoyed the edamame that they threw in, but they need to hold the salt on the edamame - wow, sodium overload!

Onigilly will definitely be on the rotation, but probably just every once in a while since I try to stay away from carbs, and the onigiri are in truth, mostly rice.  Delicious, but again, mostly rice.
author: .Hon H.

description:
I walked by Onigilly today, and my husband and I thought it looked good. I have been hearing about the wonder of rice balls for so long that I had to try them.

My husband doesn't like sushi, but he agreed to indulge me and try the rice balls. Both of us were glad he did.

I had the teriyaki chicken one, which was moist and delicious. I had the eggplant one, which was probably my favorite. And I had the tempura shrimp one, which was good, but probably my least favorite of the three (I would still eat it again though). The seaweed salad was the best I ever had. The little side salad that comes on the plate is delicious, with a spicy dressing and mixed greens. The chicken is organic. They serve Frog Hollow peaches. Seriously? And oh  yeah, it was $9.

I wish I worked downtown so I could eat Onigilly every day.
author: Marissa K.

description:
There's room for improvement, but ... (1) I love the spirit of this place. They went from truck to brick & mortar and are clearly doing all they can to smooth out any starter wrinkles. (2) I love the concept. Choose your own adventure. So many variations means it won't get old too fast (3) I love the ingredients. With a few exceptions the quality of all I've tried has been pretty top notch and it's my favorite flavors all under one roof, and...(4) I love the attention to detail.  Namely, the sides, which aren't just an afterthought. Well cooked edamame & fresh salad & seaweed sprinkles. Excellent touches. 

favorite selection: the rice bowl. This is your winner if you're worried about leaving hungry. It's really tasty and satisfying. Especially if you're not afraid of togarashi seasoning. 

My least fave selection: oddly enough, the onigily. I love the idea but there's too much rice for my taste, not enough sauce.  Granted, I am a condiment fiend. 

Favorite sides: tofu, renkon, eggplant, and salmon (salty and not a generous helping but delish) 

Least fave sides: I didn't love the crab or shrimp. It didn't have the level of freshness I like. But I haven't tried it since week one so it's possible it has improved. 

Also... It's a little confusing. Until you're a seasoned customer, and the other customers are also more practiced, it might take awhile to get thru the line. To me it's worth the extra few mins. 

All in all, a great addition to the area for lunch and a must try for anyone w a little bit of patience.
author: Sophie D.

description:
If you go to any grocery store that sells onigiri (at least one in Japantown, or either Berkeley Bowl, or any of a ton in LA), you will get ones that are way better.  

Here's how to make Onigiri at home:
- make rice, ideally Japanese short-grain
- Grab a ball of it and wrap it around something small and yummy, like some pickled plum or fish or whatever
- Shape it into a triangle
- wrap it in seaweed
It costs almost nothing and is easy.

Here's how to make and serve "Onigilly":
- Cook long-grain brown rice with too little water so it is really dry and not at all sticky
- Get too much of something gross and put it in the middle (I asked for the server's favorite 3, so I tried a cross-section)
- Poorly wrap it in really stale seaweed, for optimal lack of structural integrity
- serve 3 of these with a few overcooked edamame from frozen and some salad for $9 in a neighborhood where you will probably see someone peeing on the street while you eat
