I had Onigilly twice -- once from a food truck a year or two ago near the Ferry Building, where I think it was 2 stars.  This review is for my experience from the SF Food Lab on Market Street near Civic Center Bart, which was 1 star.  I now steer clear of it and encourage others to do the same.  Please let me know if they ever start to make them differently, and I might try again.

I'm giving it 2 stars instead of 1 just cause I haven't tried this location.
author: Beth B.

description:
I paid $10 for a Noodle Salad and I left this place still hungry! :P

Maybe I came into this restaurant with expectations that were a bit too high. I thought the menu setup was interesting, and somewhat confusing. You basically pick how your food to be made (noodle salad, rice bowl or onigilly, which is the rice ball), then you pick what toppings you want on your food.

I ordered the Noodle Salad with the Miso Tuna, Eggplant and Chicken Teriyaki. I ordered Miso Tuna expecting it to be raw fish; but instead I get a tiny tiny portion of tuna, that's not raw but that has the texture of canned tuna. I barely could tell that they added chicken teriyaki and eggplant into my noodle salad. Oh, and they forgot about my onigilly, but my sisters were complaining that the rice in the onigilly was very dry. Overall my noodle salad tasted very bland.

Just a warning though, seating spaces are limited and lines can get long! I would consider coming back here if they gave a bigger portion of food! Oh, and I didn't notice this until after I finished my food, but there were bottles of dressing for your salad by where the utensils are located.
author: Selina T.

description: Terribly disappointing. See the photo I posted - ordered a salmon dish and got about 20 grams of salmon, barely enough to fill a tablespoon. Look, I know quality food is expensive and we all need to make a profit, but that's just not enough food to get through the day.
author: Eater S.

description: Found this little place on yelp while in Chinatown area. Yummy "sushi sandwiches" that's not the official name but that's how I would describe them. I tried 4 different meat options, all tasty. Will try the veggie next time. Very filling.
author: Teneka C.

description:
This is a great restaurant for novelty-seekers. Prices are low, portions are small, and there's plenty of choice. The quality of the ingredients is very high. The food itself is only good (instead of great) but it's hard to do innovative and great at the same time.

The only complaint I'd have is that it's freezing inside and the onigillies that I love so much for lunch are not available at suppertime.
author: Amy T.

description:
Onigilly, you've stolen my heart and wrapped it in some nori. 

My mom is from Hawaii, so I grew up engulfing my face in gigantic rice balls with seaweed (musubi). I've never eaten a peanut butter and jelly sandwich, but my childhood was filled with musubi lunches (much to the detriment of my already-faltering status on the elementary school social ladder).

When some coworkers and I stumbled upon the pop-up Onigilly stand in the ferry building one lunch hour, I was hooked. The musubi reminds me exactly of how my mom used to make them! I now make regular trips to their cute little store on Kearny for their A Lunch Set. I usually get the spicy shrimp (two!), and a sockeye salmon one. The small side of mixed greens is just the right size, too.

I can see how the musubi might seem 'bland', but I actually really like them. The service can be a bit on-and-off on certain days, but regardless the staff is quite pleasant.
author: Alyssa W.

description:
O h, it's truly hard to justify dishing out almost $10 for rice balls
N ot the most frugal work lunch option, for sure
I  yet somehow find myself coming back time and time again
G ot to admit, this restaurant's Onigilly Set has got me hooked!
I t comes with 3 onigiri (rice balls), tossed greens, pickles and edamame  
L a Cocina is a good "Prefix Combo" to try (teri chix, spicy shrimp, eggplant)
L iked the spicy bacon, tempura shrimp, kani (crab) and miso tuna, too
Y our best bet for a short line is after 2pm -- or go when they open at 11am!
author: Anthony N.

description:
I wish there were more places like these. I'm often in a pickle when searching for a quick snack. Usually the only viable options are something fried or unhealthy like a pastry. I needed something that wouldn't ruin my appetite for dinner. 

Onigilly to the rescue!

The shitake onigiri and snow crab onigiri are delicious! They're made with organic brown rice so you're not eating empty carbs!

It's a bit expensive but i think it's worth it.
author: Marian C.

description:
i was definitely hesitant before coming from here because their site states that they use brown rice, which i am not a fan of brown rice at all. my co-worker said it has become one of her fav places for lunch, so i decided to give it try after seeing that their rice doesn't actually seem to be brown rice. i tried the tempura shrimp (only at this location) and salmon rolls and wow...pretty good!! great flavors and great portion of rice and topping. whether or not if they use brown rice, i still don't know because it definitely didn't taste like brown rice. i actually went back and tried their rice bowls with 3 different toppings and i have to say...it's not as great as their rolls (which they are known for), but wanted to mix it up a bit. also tried the chicken karaage and really small -less than 10 pieces for $4 something is NOT worth it and definitely lacking some flavors there. 

tips: 
1. order online, so you skip the wait during lunch hour! 
2. stick with the rolls!
author: Marsha C.

description: A great place for little ninja snacks aka rice balls with fillings! I love how you can choose what you want, but sadly it is pricey.  I have to also say that the lunch deal for three and a small salad isn't enough to satiate my lunch hungers. Either way, i definitely appreciate it for yummy snacks.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
I liked it and I'll eat here again. I've had a lot of onigiri in Japan and Hawaii. I've been hoping for bodegas to start carrying them in the cold case since they are a great little snack / lunch items.

Onigilly has way more vegetarian/vegan options than I've seen before. I had three of them: lotus root, hijiki and garlic beet greens. They were all quite good, but the lotus root was particularly delicious. They use a lightly polished brown rice so it isn't as sticky as a short-grain white rice would be, but personally, I find brown rice to have a lot more flavor and a more healthy option.

The seaweed was wrapped a little funny because the onigiri aren't stuffed, but rather the toppings are placed on top so they have to do a full wrap of seaweed and it isn't as tight around the triangles as it could be otherwise.

As with all onigiri, the longer you wait to eat them, the softer the nori wrapper will be, so eat there or take it to go depending on what you like.

I'm not sure why people complain about the price. I had three onigiri and was full afterward. $9 for lunch in the Financial District is not a bad deal.
author: Jordan M.

description:
i remember walking past them at off the grid once and thought, "brown rice? no thanks, next"... anyways, i stumbled upon their kearny st location while looking for a place to eat dinner... walking in, my expectations weren't very high... brown rice??? in the end, i was surprised, here's what we ate...

starter:
steamed clams - wasn't feeling the ipa garlic butter soy for some reason... the good thing is that the food got better.


kamikaze tacos:
teriyaki chicken - chicken was cooked just right with a subtle hint of teriyaki. of the 4 tacos we tried, this one was my favorite.

spicy bacon - this one was good, but pretty spicy, avoid if you don't like heat.

kani - only took a bite, crab meat was fresh.

spicy shrimp - couldn't really taste the shrimp much on this one, and again, spicy means spicy... but not as much as the bacon

onigilly karaage slider - overall, i would say that this was the best of everything we ordered.


to end it:
us kobe tataki - very tasty
author: Barry H.

description:
Just filled my 10-punch card and enjoyed a free lunch from Onigilly, and with this much deliciousness I will definitely fill up more!

Artfully prepared food that's really healthy -- my go to on days when I want to feel nutrients course through my body.  All the fillings I've tried have blown my mind, especially the natto and spicy renkon.  GREAT vegan options: seriously tons of choices, thanks for hooking it up!  Really nice folks, fast service, cool second floor if you're up for dining in.  Highly recommended.
author: Alec F.

description: The most unique Japanese food ever had. Like the crunchy stuff. They are mostly sushi sandwich. Ask for recommendation from the cashier. They are super nice
author: Elva H.

description:
After waiting in line for 25 mins on a cold day (alright so its their second day amidst the fi-di lunch rush), I was disappointed. I pass by Onigilly on my way to work everyday and was eagerly waiting to try their food.

I am vegetarian, and I tried their set menu #2 (3 vegetarian rice balls). The seaweed wrapper was tough and chewy--could use a knife--I think they only had forks. There was way too much rice and not enough filling. All three fillings lacked flavor--teriyaki tofu, hijiki and eggplant. And to "top" that, my veggie eggplant rice ball had a piece of chicken in it :-(

Loved the side salad and edamame, and the place is done up really well. There is a mezzanine floor and the ground floor had a few tables.

I'd love to try it out again--maybe at their OTG cart, maybe they were rushed on their second day.
author: Soniya R.

description:
I ordered the noodle bowl which I enjoyed as a light meal. The noodles had a good texture and came on top of a bed of greens. It came with 3 toppings and I liked that I could pick any from their veggie, meat, and seafood sections. I ended up getting spicy shrimp, daikon, and albacore tuna. The liked the shrimp and daikon, but the tuna was too salty. I wanted to add a seasonal topping, but I didn't think it was worth an extra $2.75. Instead I upgraded my combo to switch my plain rice ball to one with crab meat. Rice to topping ratio could defintiely use some improvement.

Overall decent, but nothing amazing. I can see myself going back to try different toppings, but not often due to the price.
author: Alice J.

description:
I really am amazed that this place has 3 and half stars. 
I dont consider my self a "foodie" or anything. My friend and i simply wondered in here during the lunch time rush since this was one of the only places that had seating in the area with no line. I should have taken that as sign! The food is the most bland i've ever had! When i say bland, think a cup of white rice and tofu wrapped in seaweed because thats exactly what i had! For the $$ i thought they would have mixed it up with a few spices here and there but i guess i was wrong. I dont think i would return.
author: V I P.

description: Their food truck was at the J-Pop festival so I tried the lunch special. $8 for 3 onigiri and edamame (guess they were out of pickled ginger at the time?). I thought it was kind of expensive for what seemed like a small amount of food, but it was surprisingly filling. Tried the miso tuna salad, teriyaki chicken, and spicy garlic bacon. Mmmm. I could have had 3 of just those garlic bacon ones. Looking forward to trying them again.
author: Miffy Y.

description:
Depending on what toppings you get it can be hit or miss. 
All of the meat toppings are good while some of the fish toppings were rather salty and not appealing at all. Spicy crab is good and the Korobuta ham.
Kimchee is great and they definitely give you enough food even though it may not seem like it. I usually dont eat all the rice since it is so filling.
author: Lilia D.

description:
Downtown/Union Square for lunch...oh the choices for one that works here. Yet the caviet is you can easily find yourself spending $12 on a sando or salad. Enter Onigilly. For $9 you can get 3 onigiri (rice balls), and damn are they good! You pick your topping - so far my favs are the eggplant, terriyaki tofu, beef and shrimp tempura but I've never had a bad one - and it's made with brown rice and served with salad, edamame and pickles. And apparently the salad dressings change, plus there are daily specials and the cock sauce (Sriracha...mmm spicy) on the side.  Healthy AND yummy. 

There are also the options of noodle salad or a bowl, neither of which I've tried but I've seen people order them and they look good, as well as a large variety of sides from miso soup to seaweed salad to chicken karage. 

Today is my third day in a week eating here...enough said. My tip is to go just before noon or after 1:30 to miss the lunch rush. Also they're working on the upstairs portion to have more seating.
author: Melissa C.

description:
Oh how I love rice because I am Asian :P

The food here is so tasty, fresh and well prepared! 

There are three options to choose from. 3 Onigilly, a rice bowl or noodle bowl.

I usually go with the rice bowl and it comes with a spring mix salad and edamame. 
If you get a rice bowl, try the Meat Complete, it comes with three meat toppings and is absolute salty goodness. Their spicy bacon topping is my favorite. 

The inside is very cute, the cashiers and cooks are very friendly. There is seating at the side and upstairs also (super cool)
author: Teresa W.

description: Delicious and convenient. Perfect rice ball in snack or lunch size. Delicious vege toppings. Yum an fun!
author: Joe M.

description:
This place excites me. 

Tarako + Nasu + Spicy Bacon + Rice Bowl = One Happy Mofo.
author: Kelly G.

description: My favorite lunch spot! There's usually a line around lunch time but it moves quickly. Lots of vegan options and always the best customer service. I also love that there's no issues with cross contamination here with the meat/fish/veggies unlike some other places. The fresh handmade mochi are vegan and SO delicious - would highly recommend.
author: Andrea N.

description:
The guy who mans the register (tall, mellow, wears glasses) is always superrrr nice and patient, especially when someone like me walks in and needs to have every aspect of their order customized.

They have little mochi desserts, salads, rice rolls with plenty of fillings, and a few other options that incorporate their Japanese-modern style of food. Prices are fair, wait time is pretty fast, and there is a small amount of seating inside, but most orders are usually to-go. Overall hygiene is pretty great, I don't see anything alarming in that aspect, and I have not had any negative experience here.

The food is made in front of you since the separator between customers and cooks is made of glass. Everything is made on the spot so you get to see and customize anything you like or don't like.
author: Kristine N.

description: YES! Finally a place that sells ichigo daifuku where you don't need to sit down for a meal (Eiji). Plus Eiji limits you to one. The strawberry mochi was very good and I love how they pack it in a little cup so it doesn't get smashed. Totally worth the price because mochi is a pain to deal with.  I can make these myself but it's a lot of work (at least for me) and my kitchen always end up in a mess. The strawberry was sweet. I've always had not so good tasting strawberries from Two Ladies Kitchen. I also had the unagi onigiri which was very good.  The cashier is super friendly.
author: x x.

description: This my go-to "healthy" lunch in the FiDi.  Fast, tasty, cheap but nothing special.  Still, I'll continue to return because quick, healthy options are few and far between. The Snow Crab is my favorite.
author: Olivia W.

description: Yes, yes - there is nothing special about onigiri (rice ball), but it is simple and filling. Plus, Onigilly makes their onigiri pretty good (more on the salty side). Oh, and FYI, their strawberry mochi is scrumptious (and they are testing out new flavors right now). Lastly, they use Leapset (to order ahead) and have a stamp/punch card system for your onigiri sets (after card is fill, you get a free set).
author: Christina L.

description:
Not bad.  The shrimp tempura, teriyaki chicken, and eggplant onigiri were good.  I was disappointed with the spicy shrimp tho...needs a bit more flavor.  I found the portion meager (only 1 shrimp tempura?  really?), but overall tasted good and didn't feel too heavy even tho it's a lot of rice consumption (at least it's brown rice).  The line gets long around noon, but if you go a little earlier it's fine.

I usually go with the onigiri, but the rice bowl is good too.

Not much seating, more of a to go place.
author: C A.

description:
I'm pretty new to the onigilly scene and I only heard about the concept once my coworkers started talking about this place since its down the street from our office. I decided to check it out with a couple of colleagues after multiple recommendations. The line at 1pm on a Monday was surprisingly long, but we decided to stick it out and wait. I ordered the onigilly set, which came with three of my choice, plus a side salad. I chose the soboro, unagi, and shrimp tempura. 

The food itself was decent; I feel like they could have put more filling in the rice balls.  The soboro was delicious, as was the unagi and the shrimp tempura. The catch was that the rice got in the way (literally and figuratively) of me fully enjoying the "meats" in the onigilly.
author: Denise Z.

description:
I love love love Onigilly! I go multiple times a week because I can't think of anything else I'd rather have for lunch. I usually go to their Onigilly Express location because it's closer to my office, but I favor this one much more. 

A quick rundown of their food: Onigiri's are rice balls and a filling of your choice all wrapped in seaweed. They're supposed to be like a little triangular, on-the-go rice sandwich that you can eat with your hands. At first, I was skeptical that the food in the restaurant could constitute a meal, but I was pleasantly surprised by what they had to offer!

One of the main draws of this location as opposed to the other one is that it's much larger and there's seating inside. As well, I really enjoy the complimentary Japanese tea they have. Each time I've visited, the staff have also gone above and beyond to provide great service. If it's your first time there, feel free to ask about their menu options (the staff will be more than happy to explain) because it can get overwhelming once you go in.

Now for the fillings. In the last few times I've been there, I've managed to sample a wide selection of their options:

-Spicy shrimp - My favorite! The flavors aren't too spicy or overpowering, and the shrimp is tender and juicy. I love the aioli they marinade it with.
-Miso tuna salad - I love this one as well. There isn't much of a miso taste to it, but I still really liked the flavor. 
-Snow crab - Seems to be a very popular option. Personally, I thought they added too much aioli and it made me feel sick after. However, its popularity makes me want to give it another try because most people seem to really enjoy it.
-Salmon - Very yummy and light. This one doesn't have a heavy marinade unlike a lot of other fillings, so I would really recommend it if that's what you're looking for.
-Soboro - Another favorite for a lot of people. The meat tasted very tender and moist.
-Spicy bacon - I actually preferred this one to the soboro. However, it tastes very "meaty" and a lot of the rice was also marinaded in the chili, so don't get it if you aren't a fan of that salty taste. 

Although I love the concept and the flavors, I have to knock a star off for the pricing. They have a set deal that is 3 onigiri's + edamame + pickles for $10. I usually only get two onigiri's because I just want a light lunch. However, if I wanted something more filling I would get the set which is on the pricier end considering what you get. Regardless, I love Onigilly and I can't seem to stop coming back for lunch!
author: Sunny H.

description: Definitely not a traditional Japanese eatery, but for a light and not too expensive lunch, I highly recommend coming here. IMO you have to get the onigilly set, which comes with three rice balls, filled with whatever you'd like. They have choices ranging from meat to seafood to veggies. Its a fun place to spend your lunch break! Only downside, its quite small.
author: Samantha C.

description: Had a taste of the sushi wraps from the food truck at Fort Mason's food truck excursion every Friday. Pretty yummy and fairly priced. However if the seaweed were a little more crunchy and a little less chewy, it'd be better. Nonetheless, still a great filling snack!
author: Siv L.

description: I wish onigilly replaced sushirito on new Montgomery street. Love their brown rice idea and choice of fillings. Really need to go back to try more flavors! Their tamago was below average, that I would not get again.
author: Amber S.

description: Fresh fruit mochi is delicious! The seaweed on the riceballs was a bit too much for me unfortunately :/ On the plus side, they have a variety of vegetarian options so if you're in the mood to try something new/different, this is the place to go in fidi!
author: Malika R.

description: My favorite place to go for lunch in FiDi.  Amazing Onigilly rolls.  Get the Snow Crab, Unagi for sure.  Really good salads and very reasonably price.  Not much space on the inside but a lot of take out so there's usually a table when I'm in there during lunch.
author: Jay H.

description:
One of the more popular/convenient lunch spots near financial district.

I would say, if you never had rice balls (onigiri) before, you should try this place.  Otherwise...  

I think this is a one-time deal for me.   The price is average for what's around the area (except for Chinatown), but if you think about what you're getting... then it's definitely not worth the money.  

Onigiri = a couple pieces of meat/veggie/fish with a huge chunk of rice wrapped in seaweed.  

I tried the miso tuna, the chasu, and the pork belly.  The miso tuna was the best because it was flavorful and non-solid enough that you can kinda mix it with the rice when you eat it.  The chasu and pork belly, on the other hand, not so much.  They're very separated from the rice and just did not go well together.  I couldn't even tell the two apart, even though the pork belly was more expensive. 

If you order the combo, you also get pickled cabbage and a salad.  Salad dressing is good but ti's probably VERY fattening.  

I tried the green tea lemonade.  It tastes exactly as it sounds: a green tea lemonade.  It was very refreshing, but ... probably won't bring me back.
author: Emily W.

description: Ordered the soboro and grilled salmon riceballs. Both were delicious. The salmon more so but I like salmon so I'm just a bit biased.
author: Christine D.

description:
The food was good. Got the onigiri set of shiitake, unagi and tempura shrimp. I recommend eating the shiitake with the daikon that comes with it, makes it less salty.

The service was good. The cashier was very friendly. 

Coming back for more. Would like to try every single onigiri on the list!
author: A A.

description: I'm not a mean person, but I want to be honest with others. I cannot say their onigilly is traditional Japanese onigiri/omusubi. I would say these are American-style rice balls. Also miso soup was bland and had no UMAMI. Hmmm....
author: Maki N.

description: I ordered an Unagi Onigilly which was the perfect amount to hold me over for a little bit instead of forcing myself to finish a large portioned, heavy American meal. Freshly made and with the complementary tea, it was a great peaceful perfectly sized mini-meal for me. Next time I'll order a set of 3, but I love that it's snack sized and healthy.
author: Sandy T.

description: I wasn't in to it. Its unique. But pretty much taste like Chinese food wrapped up like sushi
author: Dakshina T.

description: I was looking forward to trying this place for a while, and sadly I set my expectations a bit too high. It's a cheap, quick lunch with very friendly service--the cashier explained many of the menu items to me and my compadre. However, and maybe this was just unlucky ordering on my part, I found the fillings to be heavy on the mayo to the point where it was overpowering. I like the idea, so I'll probably be back. I got all fish fillings last time, I'll diversify a bit next time.
author: Ashlee C.

description: Pretty quick and reasonable for the price. The food is alright, could be a little fresher maybe.
author: Jess B.

description: Yummmmooooo. The salmon special was little dry, but the spicy bacon and snow crab was on spot. Keep it up.. you've got a fan.
author: Tyrone L.

description: I love this place because it's consistent, delicious and the guy who is always at the register is so nice! He always gives really great customer service despite the lunchtime rush. It gets crazy in here - so I order ahead and it's much better than trying to find a spot to wait in this little place.
author: Megan C.

description: very good onigilly. I'm a fan. I'll definitely be back tomorrow. and i just went today.
author: Meredith L.

description: Onigilly was at the 2013 Eat Real Festival today and I had to get the spicy shrimp onigilly. Still my favorite thing on the menu. I think today's onigilly had bigger pieces of shrimp than the ones I've had in the past.  Also ordered the chicken teriyaki but it was only average. It needed more teriyaki sauce.
author: D B.

description: Interesting flavors, good quality. A bit pricey thought
author: Radoslaw D.

description: The rice balls here are fantastic but I can't believe or ignore all the flies in the restaurant.  If you're going to try this place out; do a take out..
author: Alex B.

description: First off, the cashier is very welcoming and polite! I ordered the set, snow crab, chicken teriyaki, and soboro (the honey sweet beef). The snow crab was the best one and the other two were okay. Decent price for what you get. I would come here again but as a treat.
author: Beverly L.

description:
Bite size.

Often times ridiculous: http://shine.yahoo.com/shine-food/the-small-plate-conspiracy-how-nice-restaurants-are-swindling-us-2454229.html

Every time delicious: Japanese street food on Kearny.

One is about the size of two or three pieces of sushi. Individually made so you can try multiple items on a very good looking menu.

Went with teriyaki tofu in one and onion with sesame seeds and plum sauce in the other. Add brown rice and a seaweed wrapping and you're ready to go. 

Each tasted better than the $3 price. Each left me wanting them to open more locations so I could go back for more.

Judging by how busy this small little space was there will be more.
author: Jason B.

description: I was so excited to find this place and stood in a long line to get two onigiri and a cup of soup. Menu line up is very good, authentic Japanese + twist, the miso soup was delicious.  But disappointed in the way the rice balls are made.  They just make triangle shape rice, put the ingredient/topping in the middle and cover with another triangle shape rice, almost like a sandwich. The whole point of rice ball (onigiri) is you squeeze and make a ball (or triangle) shape. The pressure you squeeze the rice is very important to make a tasty rice ball. Other than the way the rice balls are made, the topping tasted good. I'd like other menu (like soup) but will probably not get rice balls any more. It was too disappointing.....
author: May S.

description: Good deal for good quality. Service is quick. Food, the rice is delicious. It's not the cheapest for rice balls but it's good quality and it's cheaper than most Asian food in the area. I'll definitely go eat there again!
author: Venus H.

description: Onigilly catered lunch at my company.  I got really sick.  'Nuff said.
author: Irene A.

description: The food is great, pretty quick and the people who work there are super friendly and sweet. Great place to go for a decently healthy option.
author: Brad W.

description:
Rearry?  

I did a double take as I cabbed past this spot that makes a soft pretty play on the Japanese word "onigiri" or rice ball on the way to the Bentley Reserve this morning and had to give them a whirl.  I took my new friends that I met at our sake certification course for a quick lunch.  I had my heart set on this place as I thought the concept was out of this world and so brilliant.  We got there and there was a line out the door and I immediately told my buddies that we could go somewhere else but Onigilly piqued their interest too.  The line went quickly and I was served before I sat down, no joke!   They have a very efficient way of running things or making onigiri to be specific and I was thoroughly impressed. 

Just when it was my turn to order, I was going to whip out the G-card and be that annoying person, "What do you have that is gluten-free?"  but luckily I didn't have too.  The pretty brunette in front of me who had the same purse as me ordered gluten free and I felt so relieved.  I'm severely allergic so I had to ask about the pickles and salad dressing that came with the lunch special (I ordered the 3 onigiri combo) and I had nothing to worry about.  So happy to hear that they had made a fresh vegetarian (actually vegan) vinaigrette that was simple, refreshing and tasty.  The pickles were simple and cabbage soaked in salt with a hint of fresh grated ginger... very traditional Japanese.  I couldn't have been happier.

I get my plate, I snap a pic (I always do, I know it's annoying but someone's got to do it) and I smiled when I saw their style of onigiri wrap, it was like  the  Diane von Furstenberg of onigiris.  It reminded me of her famous wrap dresses - classy,clean cut with a nice deep v-neck cut that shows just enough but not enough for your boobs to pop out.  I ordered the  Wild White Tuna (Albacore) Aioli, Tarako and Bacon w/Spicy Sauce which all stuck out near the top end of the onigiri, adorable.  Although they weren't marked GF on the menu I had a pretty good inkling that the last two were gluten free friendly as well and they confirmed the good news.   The owner went out of his way to check the label of a sauce for one of my other allergies and I was in shock.   The rice had a light brown tint and I knew immediately it was a brown rice strain which is packed with nutrients well more than the naked white over milled short grain rice that we are used to.  The salad didn't have a leaf of our watery friend iceberg but a nice portion of mixed greens and there were even a few pods of edamame with a hint of sea salt.

Besides the fact that their food is tasty, well prepared, affordable , I'm quite impressed that they are helping introduce a popular Japanese snack that has been around for hundreds of years in Japan to mainstream America... the financial district in San Francisco is an amazing place to start this food revolution!  Nice work Onigilly!
author: Shiho F.

description: Love this place! The food is tasty and they have the best customer service!
author: Cynthia Y.

description:
This place will leave you feeling unhealthy and ripped off. A meal here will leave you full of mostly rice. Despite having delicious toppings to add to your onigilly, they barely give you a teaspoon of topping, and you're left with at least a 1/2 cup of white rice in each. Not healthy and not flavorful. Such a tease. 

Also, you're lucky if you get a single piece of tofu in their tofu noodle soup.

This place is a rip off!
author: Reena S.

description: It was my first time there and they are all super nice. The workers greetef us politely and explained their menu! I would say it is a bit pricey but the food is different and unique. I would say the filling is a bit salty thats whyvi gave it a four. Haha, I would totally bri ng a friend next time;)
author: Christine L.

description: I have walked by this place several times, and had wanted to try. The restaurant (more like a cafe, as seating is rather limited) serves 'onigiri' (odd play on the r/l confusion in the name), which means rice ball. This is very humble comfort food--the stuff that my mother and grandmother would make as a casual snack or light meal. It is also what volunteers prepared and served to the countless victims of the 3/11 Tohoku earthquake and tsunami. Yes, very humble stuff. Maybe like what sandwiches are in the US? And no, this is NOT sushi (as the restaurant spells out on their menu board). The food preparers were speaking Japanese and appeared Asian, so I assumed this is a Japanese run/owned place? (with a name like Onigilly, I would think so, but maybe that doesn't matter). Anyway, the fillings list is what convinced me to try, because they were, for the most part, my childhood comfort foods. I usually either make these myself or grab them at local Japanese markets, but it is nice to eat them freshly made and warm. Plus, how hard can it be to mess up rice balls? Well, first the positives. The ingredients are high quality. They make it a point to tell people that they use koshihikari rice (high quality Japanese rice), they toast the nori (so no chewy stuff such what one might find at places that do not know that the details count when it comes to Japanese food preparation) and the fillings that I tried were delicious (tarako or cod roe, kani or crab, takana or seasoned vegetables--all standard Japanese fare). But when I got my order, I noticed that the onigiri was actually more like a rice sandwich. They took the expensive rice and prepared what looked like dried out rice slices--as though they formed the rice into a triangular solid, then sliced it into convenient pieces--sliced?? The filling was put in between two of those rice slices, then everything was wrapped in nori. To me, it looked more like a rice sandwich than onigiri. The whole point behind onigiri is that the rice is shaped by hands which are salted, so that the salt is transferred to the rice and gives it a nice flavor. The hand shaping also helps to keep the rice together, so the onigiri maintains its shape. What I got was unsalted flavorless rice that was on the dry side. When I bit into the onigiri, the rice all fell apart. Tasty, but they sure cut a lot of corners putting everything together. It was also expensive! Usually, one onigiri costs about a dollar at Japanese convenience stores, and maybe no more than two dollars at a very casual eatery. The ones I ordered were upwards of $3 each! Wow!! I also order a set, which included some crisp but under salted edamame and 3 slices of takuan (very basic yellow daikon pickles). I think the set cost maybe another 1-2 dollars extra on top of the cost of the onigiri. Not really worth it, since these items are usually complimentary, and there was nothing really exceptional about these condiments/sides.
author: 和子

description: I work in the Financial District and am always looking for a quick bite which is affordable, and not too heavy so I can remain productive in the afternoon and not sleepy come 3pm. Onigilly is my go to for all of that, and it is also delicious. I'm addicted to the ume (pickled plum), and was told by the owner of the restaurant that ume is traditionally used in Japan for a boost in energy. The unagi and spicy shrimp are also excellent. I've taken friends here, and if you get there before, or after the 12:30 rush, you should be able to find a couple seats. If you're taking it to go, it's a pretty quick turnaround as well. I haven't really experienced more than a 5 minute wait. Staff is very friendly as well.
author: Zach P.

description: Onigilly is one of my all time favorite lunch stops! They've got a great menu, and a delicious variety of fillings - all very tasty! Everything about this place keeps me coming back. :)
author: Rylee R.

description: One of my favorite spots for quick food. Healthy and tasty, I like the spicy shrimp, miso tuna salad, and eel (imagi).
author: Lexi M.

description: Great place to grab a quick lunch!  Super friendly staff and the food is tres tasty.  Spicy bacon says it all!
author: prior O.

description: Love the food here, but the line is ridiculous during the day. And not enough seating :(
author: Camille D.

description:
The people that work here so nice, and the food is so reasonably priced! This is a perfect place for a healthy, unique snack if you're walking around. 

I loved the beef one I tried. The tuna was not so good, though. Ask for their advice before you order- they'll happily point you in the right direction.
author: Kristen C.

description: Great place ate there with my friend who is Japanese and we both loved it , can't wait to go back again and try different flavors
author: Sky I.

description: I love the salmon rice balls. That is all I ever get, but it is perfect for a quick inexpensive lunch!
author: Adrienne G.

description: I Love coming in here! Rodrigo, the cashier is just awesome, he greets you with a welcoming smile. On top of that the Onigilly here is just tasty. I love my Snow Crab, Tuna or Spicy Shrimp. It's always fresh and fast! It's great for on the go people like me!
author: Winnie F.

description:
True Izakaya. Possibly my favorite place on Kearny.  Fresh, authentic Japanese food made by a friendly, efficient Japanese staff.  Frequented by Japanese clients. My favorite things:  at lunch:  noodle bowl or tofu soup.  Dinner:  miso soup, baby octopus, kale, agedashi, kamakazi tacos, zucchini with wasabi, hot sake.  Items vary due to seasonality/locality.  Gluten free available.
Very reasonably priced.  I had a 4 course dinner including hot sake and 30% tip for $24.
author: E. E.

description: I came here with a co worker and tried the meat complete. It was recommended as a bowl but I had to go with the onigilly. How often do you eat rice and and meat in a triangle shape? I really wanted to like it but i just felt like something was missing. The meat was flavorful but the whole thing tasted rather dry. I needed something to dip it in. Curry, maybe? It didn't WOW me enough to want to come back and try again. Maybe. My co worker seemed to really enjoy the vegetarian ones.
author: Nicole H.

description: Great Onigiri (Japanese rice ball)! I tried Karaage (Japanese fried chicken) and that was fantastic as well!! I like they serve very quick. I'll definitely come back.
author: Shar S.

description: Very good onigiris, but I actually liked their appetizers more. We had tempura avocado -- duh, of course that would be delicious! And their miso eggplant was amazing. I hear they have great noodles too. Next time.
author: L. M.

description:
unagi onigilly taste good but a bit small.
also ordered tamago yaki on the side.
will come back again to try more flavor
author: Rina C.

description: Delicious!  Nice and simple but very flavorful.  Chicken Karaage was so yummy!  Too back the Onigilly Express doesn't have the karaage as it is closer to my work.  Their green tea lemonade is delicious.  The miso soup was a bit strange for me because it had carrots and I thought it tasted more like chicken noodle soup without the noodle.
author: Yun C.

description: I ate here for lunch and ordered the miso soup combo - 2 onigilly and a miso soup for $7. I got the salmon which was fantastic and the tuna which I thought would be more like sushi tuna but instead was mixed with mayonnaise and tasted exactly like tuna salad from a can. Nevertheless, $7 is cheap for lunch in this area and everything else was great!
author: Lydia H.

description: Finally made a visit to Onigilly after my boyfriend had been raving about the spot. I went at 2pm on a Thursday and there was a lineup out the door, but it was well worth the wait. I got the miso combo, you get two onigiris and a miso soup for under $9!! I tried the ginger beef and snow crab, they were both flavorful and very filling. I can't wait to come back and work my way down the menu.
author: Anisha A.

description:
Checked this place out today and was pretty happy with the experience. Waited less than 10 minutes and ordering was efficient. I did have to sign for less than $10 on my credit card though, i love when you can avoid that.

I ordered the 3 rice ball lunch with tofu, spicy shrimp and beef. The tofu and shrimp where more ground up, the beef was still in pieces. Overall, I really enjoyed everything I had. The ingredients were super fresh - you get a side salad along with it and the tomatoes were great, fresh cucumber and corn. You can add your own condiments. i thought for the price, it was a good amount of food. The advertise that it's brown rice, but it looked like white rice to me though - maybe you need to specifiy when ordering? I'll check next time as I'll definitely be back.

There are a few tables for dining in and a bench to sit on to wait for your food - I think I waited for 2 minutes. Once you order, it's really fast.
author: Lauren M.

description: We really enjoyed this for a quick lunch that was reasonably priced and quite good. The cashier  made excellent recommendations, as we asked for the most popular dishes. It's a small place with limited tables.  We'd go back.
author: Joyce B.

description:
I really liked the unagi one. You really can't go wrong with fresh eel. The rice was warm and the food tasted like it should. The crab and salmon were alright, but the salmon seemed a little dry. I must've not eaten it fast enough because the seaweed was really hard to bite through. Their edamame was not very good though. Really hard. Maybe a little salt would have been better.

I think it's great to bring this type of food to the bay. Variety is always a good thing.
author: Brenton F.

description:
i will admit, when they were just a cart in justin herman plaza i didn't think too much about them and thought onigiri wouldn't be filling so it never seemed like an exciting lunch option.

when i discovered they opened up a brick and mortar and they had online ordering and options outside of onigiri i decided to give it a shot.  i ordered online via leapster and went to pick up my order 30 min later at my scheduled pick up time.

it was quick, easy and delicious.  they have a decent number of vegetarian options and i enjoyed the teriyaki tofu (AND i was glad it wasn't of the fried tofu variety) and the hijiki.  i got a side of avocado just because i wanted the creamy fat.

all of it was really really good and there was no subsequent food coma!  score!

i'm sorry i ignored you when you were a little baby cart.  (the carts are still around!)  i never should have underestimated the power of rice balls.  brown rice balls to boot. 

say it with me.  balls are delicious.
author: Jen I.

description: I was really excited to see one of my favorite food carts turn full blown restaurant. Three pieces and salad is quite a filling lunch! I don't have a specific suggestion since everything I've tried is good! Can't wait to go back and try more.
author: Sarah Z.

description: Delicious and healthy lunch. Tried their Seafood Duper onigili. Very good, especially eel one. Can't wait to try their salad.
author: Anna T.

description: Omg. Love at first bite. I can't believe I just now discovered this place. I ordered the Spicy Shrimp and the Unagi rolls. There's so much flavor packed in each roll! I cannot wait to try more. Great service, great food, and decent prices. What more can you ask for? I definitely recommend this place!
author: Tida P.

description: Great little place to walk in for a quick bite. The spicy shrimp & tuna salad are great!
author: John g.

description: So delicious! Makes me wish these were easily accessible in convenience stores like in Tokyo. I just wish they had better hours. Every time I'm craving one or I walk by it seems like they're closed. At least expand the hours until 6pm so that I can get my fix as an after work snack please!
author: Ash G.

description:
I love Onigilly even if other people can't quite figure out how they feel about the food. It's Japanese, but not the kind you are used to. In my opinion their food has interesting flavors and i like that they use seasonal ingredients and have a simple but artful food presentation. 

I like the surf n turf lunch set and the brussel sprouts, spicy bacon, onigiri and chicken kaarage. Their salads have a nice and light dressing which I really enjoy!
author: Paula U.

description: Had to wait but the line moved pretty quickly.  Went for the Lunch set A $8.45 3pc onigilly set with salad.  Tried the Miso Tuna which was delish.  The spicy bacon was interesting and did have a nice kick.  The soboro - ginger honey soy braised ground angus beef was ok.  The ginger ale was a really good choice of drink for the meal.
author: she q.

description: Nice quick, healthy meal.  The brown rice is 30% milled so it's almost like white rice.  The eel was great and there were a lot of choices.
author: Chester S.

description: Got the seafood combo lunch set - 3 onigiri and salad.  Just a snack.  A light snack.  Tasty - but i should have ordered double.
author: Jaime O.

description: So good! The soup lunch special is perfect! And the spicy bacon is my favorite! They've done such a good job with their restaurant, and the quality doesn't change when you get it at a farmers market or Off the Grid! One of my favorite lunch spots in town :)
author: Stephen M.

description:
The portions are small but the onigilly are delicious!

I highly recommend the bacon one and the green tea lemonade. The people who work here are always pleasant and helpful - especially since the menu can be a bit confusing. You might want to check out the menu online before you go. All around a great lunch spot!
author: Melissa O.

description: Great healthy lunch spot in FD
author: Nicole K.

description:
Friendly service and really flavorful food made this evening stop a win for me. The ungai taco, takoyaki and fried squid legs were all very good as was the onigilly (not sure what flavor)

Love the relaxed atmosphere and even the other guests were very friendly. Already recommend to a friend who works close to the other location as a perfect easy lunch spot!
author: Luna R.

description: Tempura shrimp origiri and unagi are my favorite. Decent miso soup. I always go for miso soup set. If you like mushrooms, try the shitake onigiri!
author: Elsa L.

description: Great little place that serves a variety of onigilly! I got the edamame set with spicy shrimp, teriyaki chicken, and spicy kogi.  I was pleasantly full and enjoyed the flavors greatly! Will be back soon!
author: Obar L.

description: Out for an 'adventure lunch' and we've walked past Onigilly dozens of times and saw a line out the door, but today just happened to have no line and we walked right in!  After attempting to figure out a somewhat confusing menu, (Think Chipotle-ish where you pick out a style, then your toppings, except we've got some crazy toppings, no pulled pork here!) My friend tried the Onigilly set, like super-sized sushi rolls and tried 3 specials off the menu, loved every one of them! I went with the Meat Lovers Rice bowl and it was fantastic!  Great flavors, all sustainable, and the staff was very nice and food came out 30 seconds or so after ordering, absolute phenomenal!  Try the Amazake!
author: Will H.

description: We stopped in here while doing a scavenger hunt  in SF and boy was the onigiri delicious.  Great customer service, delicious food, and Adashi helped out pick out the best onigiri on the menu.  Thanks man!
author: Tony P.

description:
I discovered this place because I went to a food fair and their food truck line was so long it was the only one I didn't get to taste. A couple of days later I discovered they had a restaurant on Kearney! Hurray!
They serve rice triangles or rice bowls topped with different flavors. My favorites: mahi mahi with ponzu sauce (seasonal); chicken teriyaki (amazing), and plum (not for everyone - tart and salty. YUM.) 
They have great service and a staff that is happy to help give you advice.
author: D Z.

description:
Had a craving for musubi and came here.

Super tasty options, but pricey all things considered.  $2.75 for a rice ball?  Oh well, it's the price of brick and mortar vs food truck.

That said, had the lotus root/chili, ginger-honey braised beef and unagi.  All were complex and flavorful.  Would go again when looking for something simple.
author: Hilary C.

description: Oishii...New look for a new year and I like the changes.  Friendly staff to help with your selection or make recommendation more stuffing inside the rice ball,  mmmmm.  My go to is the lunch set with my favorite soboro and just tried the snow crab, a seasonal topping, and it was delicious.  Also they have a punch card now so go try it again if you haven't been for a while, you'll see some good changes!
author: Justin S.

description: Had the seafood trio of onigiri (excellent) plus a okonomiayki (sadly undercooked). The side salad is actually quite awesome. Getting a few edamame in the box was a nice surprise too.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Tried to get into Akiko's around the corner and they were very off-putting and rude so we decided to try Onigilly for the first time.  WHAT AN EXCELLENT RESTAURANT AND WONDERFUL, HELPFUL STAFF.  i'm vegetarian and found many great options.  I ordered about 5 small dishes and loved them all.  Would definitely go back.
author: Mike F.

description: i like this place, its good food. the onigiris i had was delicious! im surprise people gave this place such a bad review. i guess its SF for you. people have high expectation for food here.
author: Linda A.

description: Delicious, healthy, Japanese-inspired food. Pick your meats, vegetables and salad/brown rice and your set. I go with the crab and unagi.
author: Yen T.

description: i don't know why i waited so long to try this place. i love it! unagi and smoked salmon are both the bomb, and the mustard greens one was really good too. love the free tea, and the addition of edamame and pickles. and the guy who works the register is both very nice and very fast/competent.
author: Erica W.

description: Love it,  a great break from your typical salad or burrito for lunch.
author: Erik J.

description:
I had their triangle-shaped rice thingy with spicy shrimp last week at an event - 
It looked great, so I decided to order it,... this was by far one of the best "rice-ball wrapped with seaweed" thing EVER !!! I went back and ordered 5 more (for me and my friend" !!!  This thing was so absolute freaking ridiculous unbelievable off-the-hook perfectly delicious !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  I am going back to their main restaurant and try to maybe get around this shrimp thing and try something else (MAYBE)!!! 
If everything in their restaurant is this delicious, I might NEWA EWA eat anywhere else when I am downtown or their food cart is somewhere close!!!

Check those guys out,...the Japanese chef and his colleague where super nice and friendly, and I wish them the best of luck to grow and be even more successful(as long as they keep the high "deliciousness" up !!!!! 


You guys are great!!!
author: John M.

description: Great place!  Fresh and healthy ingredients, fast and friendly service.  I have never had onigilly before...loved it!  I ordered the lunch plate with 3 rice balls, salad and edamame.  I came starving and left stuffed.  I will be back, especially if I need a quick healthy snack. 1 rice ball would be perfect for that.  The place is small, so be prepared to get takeout if the tables are full.
author: N K.

description: Fresh ingredients, innovative menu and something they call a bacon rice ball. whats not to love?
author: Joe S.

description: I have not tried their rice balls -- only the chicken karaage (twice) and tamagoyaki (once).  In general, I love chicken karaage and tamagoyaki and have gotten them frequently at other Japanese restaurants.  Here, though, they tasted kind of unusual or off - perhaps intentionally, as a twist(?), but I didn't like it.  I couldn't quite place what made the chicken karaage taste different, but the flavor was a bit strange to me.  The tamagoyaki was overly sweet.
author: K L.

description: Absolutely delicious! I love coming to this place for a quick lunch. My favorite toppers are soboro, tempura shrimp, and their sake. Their food is really great, and I've never really had a bad experience with them. They tend to draw a lunch crowd, though, so be warned!
author: Em F.

description: Tasty, refreshing, and appropriately priced.  The spicy bacon, soboro, and salmon are excellent! I've been back 3 days in a row now and I've tried the individual rice balls and the rice bowl and they're both great.  The line out the door is definitely worth the wait.
author: Patrick G.

description: Fast, convenient and healthy food for lunch!  Working through lunch in the Financial District?  Just want to order and pick up something quick and healthy?  If you want a quick grab-and-go lunch, this is the place to go!!!  They have good food with no fuss.  I would recommend this place if you like onigiri (they call it rice balls but I like to describe it as traditional rice TRIANGLES with meat/fish and veggies wrapped in seaweed) and you are in the Financial District looking for a quick lunch.  It seems they are only open a few hours during lunch anyways so I assume their target customers are professionals in the area looking for a good alternative to sandwiches and salads for lunch.  The only problem is...they don't seem to take phone-in orders to pick up?!?
author: Phuong T.

description: Went to try this place out after seeing the big crowd outside, a shift from the ramen place next door to this new joint. I went there at 1:30p and there was still a short line. The wait wasn't long, though, and the stuffs they are making aren't that complicated. Now on to the food. The short version of this is, they are simply simple handroll in three-dimensional triangles. What you have are the rice, seaweed, and whatever thing you picked for it.  Their salad was fresh but didn't like the fact that they tossed the edamame right by the side so you will have to carefully take them away before consuming the salad. Also, they placed the "rice balls" so close to the salad that some of the dressing got on to the them. It's certainly something to try but I won't be going back there unless I really want a light lunch after a heavy breakfast.
author: Picky E.

description: It was a different style of taste that I've never had before, friendly service on recommendations, small quaint store but overall good! :) Not too pricey, my cousin had this in Japan and its a daily thing the Japanese eat between meals
author: Connie V.

description:
I've always liked the cart -- just well-made food with great local ingredients, at least all the vegan options I've tried, so was happy to see this new location in prime FiDi lunching territory.  Glad to say the food quality still holds up, so I don't think the restaurant will have to worry about holding its own amongst all the other establishments here.

I had what I think is one of Onigilly's most unique and compelling options, which you probably won't find anywhere else.  This is the salad with tofu noodles (which comes with one "plain" onigilly rice ball).

I'm pretty sure the "tofu noodles" are tofu shirataki noodles, which a special high-protein noodle that doesn't have a ton of flavor, but a nice texture, and will please those who like Onigilly's offerings but are trying to go a little more low carb.

All in all this vegan is still pleased and will probably be back for lunch.  Only improvement I can think of for the salad option would be if you could upgrade the plain onigilly for one with filling, for an extra dollar or so.  The flavored fillings (which come as toppings on the salad, and all the vegan ones are great) are the real star at this place.  The menu might seem confusing at first, but just remember that you get to pick three flavors no matter what you get (and the menu is very helpful in identifying vegan and gluten-free choices).

The servings are pretty large here.  Two friends had two Onigilly balls instead of one of the lunch sets, and seemed satisfied.  Everyone I've talked to love the veggie options, with less enthusiasm for the chicken.
author: Tamara F.

description: I am so happy to have a new lunch place!!!! The register guy was so sweet! He helped me decide what to order! I plan on trying everything!!! Everyone looks cool, and was so nice! Love the space! Can't wait to come back and try more!!!
author: Kamilla H.

description: They changed the portion of ingredients and how they make the meals. Still great place.
author: Flo P.

description: Wow this place is amazing. Warm, soft, chewy onigiri with flavor. Just found my new favorite place for lunch in FiDi!
author: George L.

description: For onigiri junkies, a quick and tasty way to get your fix. These aren't your traditional, hand molded onigiri, but a "fast food" version that brings a sure-fire variety of savory fillings to satisfy any craving. The staff are friendly and accommodating, the place is cozy and clean, and I have yet to find anything to dislike about their fillings. The edamame that came with our sets were cold and unpleasantly slimy, but I went for the onigiri. Try their specials! The eel was excellent, notable for not swimming in sauce, as is common elsewhere. Gets crowded for the lunch rush, show up right as they open!
author: Michelle L.

description: Gross and a rip off.  $10 bucks for 3 scoops of rice and a dab of inedible shrimp (tasted spoiled) and chicken (basically a piece of cartilage) on top.  Really bad.  I wonder what place can use their equipment for the next restaurant that will take over this place in six months when it closes.  Awful.
author: Christian P.

description: very nice, healthy if you want that, indulgent if you don't.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Blah.  Wouldn't return.  Super duper bland.  Ate the top from the "onigilly" triangle and was left w/ 95% of the triangle which was super bland rice.  Salad was underwhelming too.   Still hungry and unsatisfied.
author: Rainforest C.

description: This place is really good! I love all their meats, especially salmon, eel, and spicy bacon. I love that you can choose to have the rice balls or noodle salad.
author: exploradare G.

description: I don't usually carry around a frequent diner card, I don't really do that kind of dining.  That said, I have a full one from here plus another one started.  I love this place.  I don't do a lot of repeat dining, there's so much great food in the Bay.  But I'll come back again and again.  The food is fresh, good service, delicious tumeric drink, great prices.  I'll be back, be sure of that.  I highly recommend to anyone and everyone.
author: Paul W.

description: Ate here for lunch today. I had 3 sides: beet salad, fried chicken and wok asparagus. Came to $10. My friend had a rice bowl w/ unagi. Fast, fresh and friendly staff; come early though since a line forms for lunch time. More seating upstairs. They specialize in triangular sushi rolls with a variety of fillings if you like nori.
author: Shana L.

description: Menu is a little overwhelming for the speed required for the quick downtown lunch. The onigilly are excellent.
author: Megan M.

description: I really wanted to like this place and I will definitely go back to give it one more shot.  I ordered the rice bowl and I was disappointed by the portion size.  I ordered tofu, pork, and a pickled vegetable.  The pork was three very very thin slices.  There was a lot of rice with little substance.  I did order one onigilly and that is what I would get next time as well.  I had the chicken choice and it was very tasty.  Next time I will skip the rice bowl and stick with the basics.  I wish I loved it but as of right now I feel it's just satisfactory.
author: Allison M.

description:
for me, this hits the spot.  since Medicine closed down, i've been looking for a place that has tasty, balanced, healthy, and thoughtfully conceived and sourced food.  this hits a lot of those buttons.

the amount of protein they give is much much smaller than I imagine most people expect  --- there are certainly other places in the FiDi to get more meat or fish, but i suppose it's more of a garnish for the rice, and it is hard to find well sourced protein around here.  Basically it's filling, balanced, and healthy.
author: morgan g.

description: Fun to try but I won't be back for a second meal here. There was just not enough flavor (and way too much rice) in the rolls. The salad was good though. I ordered the green tea lemonade which sounded so delicious (and was) but it was $1.75 for a small cup that wasn't full and was almost all ice...I think I ended up with about four sips. When I asked for a refill because of all that they said no ... perhaps $1.75 isn't a ton of money but it felt like a rip off.
author: Ellen K.

description: food is pretty tasty.  price is around what the neighborhood charges. people are nice.  one thing they have to change is they need to find a better way to wrap the onigiri for take out cause putting it in a box with the pickled vegs doesn't work.  one good thing about onigiri is the crunch seaweed, when it's all mushy and soggy, it's disappointing.  otherwise, flavors are good and rice has a nice chew to it.
author: Food Is L.
